fields.headline: Transfer shake-up set for July
fields.trailText: A new transfer system giving players the right to break contracts and compensate smaller clubs for the time they have spent on a player's development is likely to be in place by the start of next season.
fields.body:
A new transfer system giving players the right to break contracts with a period of notice and compensate smaller clubs for the time they have spent on a player's development is likely to be in place by the start of next season.

European Commission officials and the game's world governing body Fifa met yesterday as part of continued negotiations on how the transfer system can be amended to comply with EC laws.

After 3 hours of negotiations in Brussels, Fifa's general secretary Michel Zen-Ruffinen said that some issues still needed to be resolved but that the EC had agreed "in principal" to the proposals submitted by a joint Fifa/Uefa task force on how the system can be changed.

Fifa, is optimistic that the EC will approve its new transfer system in March and that it will come into effect in July.

Officials of Uefa, the European game's body, said compensation would be based on a number of "objective" criteria, such as training costs, age, number of appearances, length of contract and future prospects, and would aim to filter money down into the lower reaches of football.

Uncertainty also remains about contract duration and at what point players can seek to negotiate their way out of a deal, Zen-Ruffinen said.

The general secretary said the task force would meet again early next week to draft "counter-proposals" to a document issued by the Commission before returning to Brussels for another meeting next Wednesday.

webTitle: Esson error lets subs take Rangers out of the woods

fields.headline: Esson error lets subs take Rangers out of the woods
fields.trailText:
Rangers 3 - 1 Aberdeen
Esson error helps Rangers out of the woods.
fields.body:
Aberdeen held the lead for a quarter of an hour here last night, but eventually the weight of talent, ambition and wealth told. An error by the teenage goalkeeper Ryan Esson granted Michael Mols an equaliser and second-half goals from the substitutes Billy Dodds and Jörg Albertz completed Rangers' recovery and cut Celtic's Premier League lead to 10 points.

As if the task of surviving a visit to Ibrox was not already difficult enough, Aberdeen left out their forwards Eoin Jess and Alex di Rocco, after they had accused the club of lacking ambition. "I told the club they would need to show ambition before I would sign the new contract offered to me," Jess told the local Evening Express. "We finished bottom of the league last year and haven't signed any new players."

Aberdeen had already survived a difficult opening spell when they took the lead - from their first genuine attack.

Rangers created a number of chances in the first 10 minutes. Michael Mols's touch to a Neil McCann corner was hacked off the line, Kevin McNaughton had to concede a corner to stop Ronald de Boer barging through and McCann almost put Kenny Miller in.

Then Rangers caught rather too much of the Christmas spirit. Claudio Reyna gave away one corner, Arthur Numan another. The defence then collaborated in giving away the goal. Chris Clark's corner kick found its way through a forest of defenders to give Arild Stavrum the simple task of firing past Stefan Klos.

The home fans vented their frustration after McNaughton brought down McCann on the edge of the area, but they did not have to endure much more. After Philip McGuire headed Numan's clever ball away at the expense of a corner, Esson failed to take Ronald de Boer's kick and the ball dropped for Mols to smack into an empty net.

Dodds put Rangers ahead when he diverted Barry Ferguson's shot under Esson. And two minutes from time Albertz finally made sure when he crashed a shot into the roof of the net after Dodds had cut the ball back from the byline.

webTitle: Fifa flags up sponsorship deals for referees' shirts

fields.headline: Fifa flags up sponsorship deals for referees' shirts
fields.trailText: Sponsorshsip logos will be worn by referees in Britain and elsewhere in Europe next season after a major relaxation of the rules by Fifa.
fields.body:
Sponsorshsip logos will be worn by referees in Britain and elsewhere in Europe next season after a major relaxation of the rules by Fifa.

The world governing body's executive committee has decided to allow another lucrative commercial avenue into the game when, from next March, officials will be permited to advertise both products and companies.

The Spanish FA has already lined up a cable television company for a block sponsorship deal, and the English FA is to begin a search along similar lines rather than allow its top officials to negotiate individual arrangements that could lead to charges of elitism.

High-profile referees will still stand to benefit most from the changes, as much of the cash injection will find its way into their pockets.

Fifa is determined to continue closing the gap between the earnings of referees and those of the £50,000-a-week players they are charged with controlling.

A series of large increases has seen the Premiership match fee rocket to £1,200, whereas Champions League officials command £1,500. A sign of the times is Fifa's intention to pay referees $20,000 [about £13,800] for taking part in the 2002 World Cup in Japan and South Korea.

 Arsenal have signed much-travelled Lithuanian striker Thomas Danilevicius after taking him on trial more than six months ago.

webTitle: Huddersfield rise from depths as Gallen double fells Forest

fields.headline: Huddersfield rise from depths as Gallen double fells Forest
fields.trailText:
Nottm Forest 1 - 3 Huddersfield
Gallen double lifts Huddersfield off the bottom.
fields.byline: Adrian Milledge  at the City Ground
fields.body:
Huddersfield Town continued their mini-revival with a victory that lifts them off the bottom of the First Division table and also denied Nottingham Forest the chance of reaching their highest position since being relegated from the Premiership two seasons ago.

Forest could have gone second had they won 4-0 but the defeat was not just a slap in the face for David Platt's side but also the 28,000-plus crowd, many of whom had been lured to the City Ground by the cut-price £5 admission price.

Forest's ineptitude proved too much for a supporter festively attired in a Father Christmas hat.

"This has cost me two pints," he moaned with unseasonal ill-will before opting to spend the last five minutes of the first half in the bar. What he made of the second half is unknown. It can hardly have been polite as the visitors established a 3-0 advantage within 20 minutes of the restart.

Peter Ndlovu started the deluge in the 56th minute with a first-time left-footed shot following Kevin Gallen's headed knock down.

Then Gallen himself got in on the act, delivering the coup de grace after John Dyson's header had slipped through David Beasant's hands before firing right footed on the turn past the hapless keeper.

And Gallen was on the mark again after 65 minutes to put the match firmly beyond Forest's reach.

They belatedly emerged from their torpor 20 minutes from time when Andrew Reid tapped the ball home after Nico Vaesen had parried Ben Olsen's shot.

But long before the goals finally came, the casual observer would surely have come to the conclusion it was Forest rather than their visitors who were on First Division's skid row.

Buoyed by two successive victories after 19 abortive attempts Huddersfield, with the on-loan striker Ndlovu full of purposeful running, continued where they had left off in defeating Wolves on Saturday.

Curiously, he could have been lining-up for Forest if a proposed swap deal that would have taken Andy Johnson across the Midlands earlier in the season had not foundered for financial reasons.

Platt remains keen and an early header from the Zimbabwean international that was just wide of Beasant's right-hand post followed by a snap shot that was just over the crossbar, not to mention his opening goal, will have done little to dampen his interest.

Nottingham Forest (3-5-2): Beasant: Edwards, Bart-Williams, Calderwood; Olsen,

Scimeca (Gray, 76min), Prutton, Jones, Foy; Reid, John (Harewood, h-t).

Huddersfield Town (4-4-2): Vaesen: Heary, Dyson, Gray, Jenkins: Baldry, Holland, Armstrong, Thornley (Vincent, 86); Gallen (Facey, 78), Ndlovu (Gorre, 89).

Referee: C Wilkes.

webTitle: Nielsen gives Dons more home discomfort

fields.headline: Nielsen gives Dons more home discomfort
fields.trailText:
Wimbledon 2 - 2 Grimsby
Nielsen gives Dons more home discomfort.
fields.body:
Wimbledon's manager Terry Burton has suggested that his team's poor home form is down to the excessive sex enjoyed by his players on the eve of matches. No prizes then for guessing what John Hartson and co were up to on Tuesday night.

This draw left Wimbledon with only one league win here this season, though with better finishing they would have won. Grimsby, who refused to buckle under late pressure, remain in the bottom three despite this rare away point.

Wimbledon's home form has let them down this season but few in this tiny crowd can have expected anything but a home win given that Grimsby arrived on the back of five straight away defeats.

Presumably no one at all expected much atmosphere. With around 80 Grimsby fans narrowly outnumbering the stewards at one end and another stand completely empty, there seemed a good case for introducing the fans to the players before kick-off, never mind the other way round.

The pitch was in impressive condition given that Tuesday night's Worthington Cup match here between Crystal Palace and Sunderland was called off because of waterlogging.

Not that they were complaining when they scored in the 20th minute from only their second shot on target. Wimbledon's keeper Kelvin Davies flapped at a Menno Willems corner and, after David Nielsen hit the post, the centre-half Richard Smith poked in the rebound.

With Grimsby matching their opponents physically and looking to launch attacks down the channels, they had their moments but it was Wimbledon who enjoyed the better chances. Before Smith's goal they should have been ahead.

Hartson, who has been linked with a move to virtually every club in Britain except Grimsby in the past fortnight, forced Danny Coyne into two early saves and probably should have scored with the first. His strike partner Jason Euell, another multi-million pound man, had a header stopped before the pair got their angles right.

Euell's ball sent Hartson into the area and the Welshman crossed for Euell to tap in. The Wimbledon fans were just getting over that Euell-tide cheer when the second arrived just before half-time, Trond Andersen heading in Par Karlsson's corner.

Neal Ardley was given a chance to increase Wimbledon's lead not long after the interval but shot wide from just outside the area, and Damien Francis should certainly have scored in the 56th minute. From Euell's excellent cross, though, he glanced a header wide.

The 21-year-old was to pay for that. Two minutes later a neat Grimsby move sent Stuart Campbell scampering down the left wing and from his low cross Nielsen, on loan from Copenhagen, scored emphatically.

webTitle: Houllier out of luck as Reds run into Roma

fields.headline: Houllier out of luck as Reds run into Roma
fields.trailText: Liverpool's path to the Uefa Cup quarter-finals is blocked by an old enemy - they must face their 1984 European Cup final adversaries Roma in the fourth round.
fields.body:
Liverpool found their path to the Uefa Cup quarter-finals blocked by an old enemy yesterday when they were paired with the Italian League leaders Roma in the fourth round.

The Merseysiders, unseeded in the draw, will meet the Serie A leaders in Rome's Olympic stadium on February 15, with the second leg at Anfield seven days later.

The return leg should have been in Rome but Uefa insisted on a switch as Roma's rivals Lazio are involved in a Champions' League fixture on February 21 and so have first claim on the Olympic stadium.

Liverpool have happy memories of their last competitive meeting with Roma. They defeated the Italians in the Olympic stadium to win the 1984 European Cup, a match possibly best remembered for the bizarre, wobbly-kneed antics of their goalkeeper Bruce Grobbelaar during a penalty shoot-out.

If Liverpool overcome Roma they will enter the last eight with understandable optimism because in the draw for the quarter-finals, which was also made yesterday at Nyon in Switzerland, they would face the winners of the tie between Porto and Nantes - with the second leg at Anfield.

But the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier was unimpressed with the draw. "This really is the one we wanted to avoid at all costs," he said. "Roma are definitely the strongest of the 16 teams left.

"It is the most difficult draw we could have had and it will constitute a really enormous test for us. You only have to look at where Roma are in the Italian League to appreciate how difficult it will be."

Many would say it could have been worse. AEK Athens have the dubious distinction of taking on Barcelona.

fields.headline: Cancer charities consider merger
fields.standfirst: If leaders in charity field agree a deal, it would create UK's largest fundraising body with a joint turnover of £222m to back research
fields.trailText: The two biggest cancer charities in Britain, the Imperial Cancer Research Fund and the Cancer Research Campaign, are considering a merger which would make them by far the largest fund-raising body in the United Kingdom.
fields.body:
The two biggest cancer charities in Britain, the Imperial Cancer Research Fund and the Cancer Research Campaign, are considering a merger which would make them by far the largest fund-raising body in the United Kingdom.

The organisations, already the third and fourth highest fund-raisers in the country after Oxfam and the National Trust, would become a colossus in the charity world and potentially a more powerful driving force in cancer research even than the government.

The merger would throw into question the future of some of the hundreds of tiny cancer charities often set up in memory of relatives who died of the disease.

The ICRF has a turnover of £115m a year, and the CRC of £107m, making a potential joint turnover of £222m. Between them they will be spending about £175m on research this year. The government has always lagged behind in its spending on cancer research but has now promised to match the voluntary sector within a few years.

Yesterday, Sir Paul Nurse and Gordon McVie, director generals respectively of the ICRF and the CRC, made a joint announcement that they were in discussions. Although the talks are at an early stage, the organisations are in no doubt that closer collaboration, if not full merger, will happen. Trustees will meet in the new year to discuss detail.

Behind the move is a sense that progress is being made towards better diagnosis, treatment and even cures for cancer thanks to the human genome project which should enable researchers to identify the genetic changes that can lead to the development of cancerous cells.

"There is a public excitement now that something is going to happen," said Prof McVie. "People have got wind of the excitement of the human genome project. We are looking for real human benefit down the line. But the cancer research we are talking about now is big money stuff."

"We have established what we call a post-genomic biology unit," said Sir Paul. The project is a joint venture, based in the Sanger Centre in Cambridge - the institution which was responsible for mapping the genome in the UK. "We have put aside £1m a year for five years in the first instance."

It is the sort of research small charities could not dream of funding. The two charities operate in different ways. The CRC funds scientists in academic departments and other institutions to carry out research, while the ICRF has its own research centres and staff. They are responsible for the pay packets of almost 1,400 researchers each.

That dual arrangement would probably continue, said Sir Paul, as it did at the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda in the US. The new organisation, which could possibly scoop the cancer fund-raising pool with the all-embracing name of Cancer Research, would still have nothing like the funds of the NCI, which is given $5bn of state funds, but could play a similarly directive role in making key decisions about the sort of research to be backed.

There are 620 cancer charities in the UK. Prof McVie is quite clear that it is not helpful to have so many. He has succeeded in persuading two to amalgamate with the CRC. "I have approached another 10 and am still talking to two or three and have been totally rebuffed by two or three others.

"You can't stop people setting up a charity, even if what you are doing is already covered by 55 other breast cancer charities. The Charity Commission say it is a real headache.

"There is evidence of double funding and stuff we turn down being funded by other charities."

Sir Paul and Prof McVie said yesterday that there was no reason why a merger should result in closures of their charity shops.

There are 620 cancer charities in the UK. Prof McVie is quite clear that it is not helpful to have so many. He has succeeded in persuading two to amalgamate with the CRC. "I have approached another 10 and am still talking to two or three and have been totally rebuffed by two or three others. "You can't stop people setting up a charity, even if what you are doing is already covered by 55 other breast cancer charities. The Charity Commission say it is a real headache. "There is evidence of double funding and stuff we turn down being funded by other charities." Sir Paul and Prof McVie said yesterday that there was no reason why a merger should result in closures of their charity shops.

fields.headline: Console yourself at Christmas
fields.standfirst: Four games machines are slugging it out for the seasonal trade.  Steve Poole  puts them through their paces to see which would be the best to find in your stocking this year
fields.trailText: Four games machines are slugging it out for the seasonal trade. Steve Poole puts them through their paces to see which would be the best to find in your stocking this year Four games machines are slugging it out for the seasonal trade. Steve Poole puts them through their paces to see which would be the best to find in your stocking this year
fields.body:
It has been an awfully long time since there were four videogame consoles vying for consumers' cash at Christmas.

Your choice of hardware will always be partly determined by what you want to play on it - the best games are usually exclusive to a certain machine. But this is also a transitional time for the videogame industry, with older machines reaching the end of their natural lifespan and two major new consoles arriving next year.

So buyers must also consider how much juice is likely to be left in the box they choose. The Nintendo 64 (£74.99) is a case in point. Though technically superior to its rival PlayStation, it has always suffered from a lack of software support.

Even now, it can boast no top-flight beat-'em-ups or driving games. Yet if its back catalogue is small, it is also glorious: Goldeneye, Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, Super Mario 64, Wave Race.

Like its predecessor the SNES, the N64 has been bowing out in style this year, with the flawed but impressive Perfect Dark, the wonderful Mario Tennis, and now the latest masterpiece from Japanese legend Shigeru Miyamoto, Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask.

Those who already own the machine will be more than happy, but only die-hard Pokémon nuts - Pokémon Stadium and Pokémon Snap aren't available for any other console - will actually go out and buy one for the first time now.

What of Nintendo's old rival? Sony's PSone (£79.99) is a repackaged version of the original PlayStation, in a smaller, rounded white box, and with a snap-on LCD screen promised for next year. The PlayStation is now cheap enough to be a toy. But the technology inside it is still five years old, and showing its age with warped textures and coughing framerates.

There is of course a new Lara Croft vehicle out this Christmas (Tomb Raider Chronicles), but there will be no more ground-breaking games on this format. The back catalogue, even so, is wide and impressive, with such benchmarks as Gran Turismo, Metal Gear Solid, Tekken 3, Time Crisis et al available at reduced prices.

Since PSone's technology is now so well understood and relatively cheap to develop for, the console might yet enjoy an Indian summer as the medium for inexpensive, experimental videogames, such as this autumn's bizarrely fascinating Vib Ribbon, or the new Incredible Crisis.

Gamers looking for the cutting edge, however, will know it is time to move on. I only hope there are not too many tearful children on Christmas morning unwrapping one of these when they wanted a PlayStation 2. Beware of tragic parental confusion.

So should you go for a PlayStation 2 (£299)? It's kind of a moot point, since Sony managed to ship only 165,000 of the beasts to the UK. If you haven't already got one, you won't officially be able to buy one until well into the new year - but there are some enterprising companies out there offering to sell mysteriously acquired machines at a premium.

The PS2 is certainly a sleek and sexy beast: ribbed black, with understated highlights, it resembles a serious slab of hi-fi entertainment gear. It also plays back DVD movies, although the quality is not stunning.

Connectivity-wise, it's pretty future-proof: USB and i.Link ports, a promised broadband internet adapter, a promised slot-in hard drive. But it's criminal that Sony has provided only two controller ports, forcing you to spend an extra £30 on a multitap to play three-way or four-way games.

So what can you play on it? There's the rub. Of all the games available from now until the new year, the only "must-have" product is Timesplitters (Eidos). Programmed by Free Radical Design, who were part of the original Goldeneye design team, it's an uproarious first-person shooter with a beautifully fast and smooth four-player mode.

Because PS2 is backward-compatible with original PlayStation software, it has a ready-made library of old games, but it will take a while before developers exploit the full potential of its idiosyncratic computing architecture. That might not happen, in fact, before next autumn's Metal Gear Solid 2, a game already so desirable that a five-minute DVD trailer for it has been selling like hot saké in Japan.

But by that time, Sony will have to fend off the twin challenges of Microsoft's Xbox (currently selling itself on unproven polygon numbers) and Nintendo's Gamecube (wisely not claiming any numbers at all).

My guess is that it will do just fine, once the price is cut to something more sensible, but for now only gadget freaks really need one.

And so we come to Sega's Dreamcast (£149). It had some teething troubles when it launched a year ago: notably, the slipping of high-profile games and the failure of its internet service. But since then, things have started to go right.

It is still the only console to ship with a built-in modem, albeit a slow 33.3kbps model (a 56k unit is promised next year), and so out of the box it can function as a basic email and web-browsing unit. Owners of the excellent Dreamcast port of Quake III: Arena can participate in multiplayer fragging contests online as well.

Despite the PS2 hype, the Dreamcast has always been a very capable 128-bit machine itself, and its software catalogue is now superb. The evergreen Soul Calibur is still eye-searingly beautiful; there are perfect conversions of Sega arcade games such as House of the Dead 2 and Crazy Taxi; and recent major launches such as Metropolis Street Racer, Jet Set Radio and Shenmue, as well as the delicious maraca-shaking party game Samba de Amigo, have consolidated its position.

Dreamcast is by no means certain to be blown out of the water by the new boys next Christmas either. Consider also that current high-street bundles around the £149 mark offer the console with two or three free games, and that for £299 or less you can also get it with an excellent multi-region DVD player (the Encore DV-450S), and there is really no contest. Sega is the undisputed champion for videogamers this Christmas.

 Steve Poole is the author of Trigger Happy: The Inner Life of Videogames (Fourth Estate, £12)

webTitle: Is Chris Smith out of his element?

fields.headline: Is Chris Smith out of his element?
fields.standfirst: Chris Smith is creative and likeable, but the subtleties of culture, media and the arts may elude him when regulating UK media.
fields.trailText: December 14: Chris Smith is creative and likeable, but the subtleties of culture, media and the arts may elude him when regulating UK media, writes Maggie Hyde, the Media Medium.
fields.body:
In astrology, each element - fire, earth, air, water - represents a particular orientation, and the world of art and culture belongs primarily to air, the element of communication and human interaction.

Alarmingly, Chris Smith, the secretary of state for culture, media and sport, does not have one breath of air among his personal planets. No coincidence then that Norman Lebrecht in the Daily Telegraph has suggested that the arts are "fatally asphyxiated" by Chris Smith's New Labour, politically correct, social engineering approach.

Chris Smith, with a stack of fire and earth, is not in his element in his current brief. This requires the clear, light touch of astrological air, especially when it comes to regulating arts and media.

Despite his bland public persona, Chris Smith is a fiery Leo (July 24, 1951) with Mercury, the planet of communication, also in this creative sign, giving him such personally warm and likeable qualities that, it is said, "nobody has it in for him".

Astrologer Alan Leo gives an upbeat analysis of the Leo lion: "A determined, governing, organising and controlling mind, with power to take large and extensive views, coupled with a somewhat dogmatic tendency: there is much positive assurance, and a high degree of faith and conviction in noble ideals. It denotes a confident, ambitious, persistent and at the same time intuitive intellect."

The most striking feature in his horoscope is the opposition of expansive Jupiter and Neptune, with the Moon also part of this configuration.

The remaining planets fall on one side of this opposition, which therefore cuts the chart in half to create a one-sided pattern known as a 'bowl'.

Negatively Neptune and the Moon give a potential threat of scandal, but there is no obvious indication of this breaking in the next few years.

More positively, Jupiter and Neptune suggest a religious attitude, tinged with socialism and a care for the underdog.

Brought up as an Anglican, Chris Smith continues as a practising Christian whose beliefs inform his politics. Mars, the action planet, connects with these religious leanings and pushes them into worldly expression, and he has the potential to be more radical than his current job allows.

Leo is a byword for loyalty, and his personal commitment to Tony Blair should safely ensconce him in the next Labour cabinet.

With Cancer-Virgo influences, he would be competent in his former shadow posts in health or environment, but the same Jupiter which represents his religious belief also signifies travel and foreign affairs.

Foreign secretary appears to be out of his reach but he could do surprisingly well in a Euro post, and a beefed-up role as Minister for Europe is worth a flutter.

Apart from hiccups in March next year, the coming period looks smooth enough. His boats won't rock until early 2008 when Jupiter hits a square of Uranus, and if he is weary of politics by then, a new calling could await him.

Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: CRC head discusses merger plans
fields.trailText: Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, talks to Nicola Hill about the possibility of a merger with the Imperial Cancer Research Fund and what the implications would be
fields.body:
Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, discusses the possibility of a merger with the Imperial Cancer Research Fund and what the implications would be

How likely is a full merger?
It is entirely up to the trustees. So far they have agreed to consider recommendations by a team composed of trustees from both charities. There will be further meetings in January and an announcement in mid-February. I think something will happen and the minimum outcome I will be happy with is the integration of scientific research between the two charities. If public opinion and fundraising specialists agree then there is the possibility of merging to form one charity. Obviously that would result in one chief executive but I am quite sanguine about that.

Who initiated the talks?
The two director generals of the charities initially started talking about three years ago. Since then we have involved the two chairmen. We have had two or three joint meetings. There has been enough support from trustees for us to go public.

What is the motivation?
The key one for me is to integrate science. Both [ICRF director general] Paul Nurse and I feel the very strong burden of providing better cancer care for the public and things should happen quicker. It is all about speed, and together we could do things more quickly. For once it isn't technology that is holding us back - it is money and organisational infrastructure. It is absurd that two organisations should be forking out £1-2m on the same piece of equipment to clone cancer genes for example.

What implications will this have for fundraising?
There is a fundraising folklore that two charities raise more than one but this has never been rigorously tested. We have written to all our shops, supporters and volunteers and discussed the issue with a representative group and they thought that there is no way forward without collaboration. There is a good match with our fundraising strengths and weaknesses and finally people will stop asking why there are two cancer charities competing against each other.

Who have you approached already to merge with and who has rebuffed you?
We have successfully merged already with the North of England Cancer Research Campaign and the Bradford War on Cancer. However, the Roy Castle Lung Cancer Fund, CLIC, Breast Cancer Campaign and Yorkshire Cancer Research have all refused to continue talking but maybe they will change their minds after this news. The door is always open.

What would be the impact on staff?
It would not be a cost-cutting exercise, we will keep all the shops open as long as they are making a profit. And we will continue with our intramural scientific work, which ICRF conducts, and the extramural research that we do - ie in-house research and grant making - will allow maximum flexibility.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From George Mason
fields.trailText: I visited a friend in Hong Kong last year and had an amazing time. Two things you absolutely HAVE to do - go to the top of Victoria Peak at night (obvious but good - the later the better) and have something to eat in the Cafe Siam
fields.body:
Hi Milly,

I know its going to be a while until you're in Hong Kong, but I'm going to be travelling by then too - following much the same path as you via Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand - and can't guarantee that I'll remember to email you my hints and tips closer to the time!

I visited a friend in Hong Kong last year and had an amazing time. Two things you absolutely HAVE to do - go to the top of Victoria Peak at night (obvious but good - the later the better) and have something to eat in the Cafe Siam on Lyndhurst Terrace in Central (on the assumption that you like Thai food). The meal I had in Cafe Siam was probably the best meal I have ever eaten in my life...

I've got tons of other suggestions but I'll send them when I think of them.

Hope you enjoy your travels - I'm green with envy! Take care.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Louis
fields.trailText: In Namibia, you'll need a car. Be ready for many hours of driving through austere country on dust roads; whenever you see a petrol pump, be sure to fill up.
fields.body:
These are two of my favourite places and I've been there often.

In Cape Town (where I'm from, although I live in London) you need a car. See a sunset at Llundudno beach (on west side of the peninsula near the city). Kirstenbosch Botanical gardens are gorgeous. The drive to Cape Point and into the nature reserve is beautiful (although don't go on a windy day). My favourite beer is Windhoek lager, and it's cheap like all beer in South Africa.

In Namibia, you'll need a car. Be ready for many hours of driving through austere country on dust roads; whenever you see a petrol pump, be sure to fill up. The Fish River Canyon (second in size only to the Grand Canyon) and the Sesriem Camp (entrance to the Namib) are must-do's. The long road down to Luderitz has some spectacular scenery.Take malaria pills if you're going further North than Windhoek.

Best regards.

fields.standfirst: From Anna
fields.trailText: Keep the diary entries coming, they make a great read on a dull, cold December afternoon!!
fields.body:
Sue,

It sounds like you're having a fantastic time, and it's making more and more excited about getting myself in gear to go travelling next year.

I've been saving since the beginning of the year and reached my first thousand pounds yesterday - yippeee!! This is a real milestone for me and I just wanted to share it with a real traveller!

I'll let you get back to the elephants for now!

Keep the diary entries coming, they make a great read on a dull, cold December afternoon!!

Go get 'em gal! Love Anna xxx

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Bette Phimister
fields.trailText: It sounds fun, but isn't it a bit voyeuristic? I think that travel is something that allows you to be you in a different space, to be unplugged. To experiment on being anonymous and living in an existential space, free of ties
fields.body:
Dear Milly,

It sounds fun, but isn't it a bit voyeuristic? Why do people give websites and television programmes the audience and emails that they get for this kind of thing? Do you feel at all claustrophobic with people emailing you with suggestions and invading your reality? Do you feel obliged, in any way, to live your life differently to how you might if you were unplugged? Any obligation to your the people who've emailed you?

I would think that travel is something that allows you to be you in a different space, to be unplugged. To experiment on being anonymous and living in an existential space, free of ties.

Good luck.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Ali
fields.trailText: Kathmandu is wonderfully atmospheric, especially the main square at sunrise as it starts to come alive, with its temples, priests, beggers, rickshaw drivers, tea stalls and flower sellers. Surprisingly, it also has great cake shops!
fields.body:
Hi Sue

My first thought on seeing that you were in India (apart from wildly jealousy and nostalgia!) was to advise you to go to Jaisalmer, the most magical place I went to on my three trips to India (and there are many), but I see reading your report from Bombay that you've already received the same advice from someone else. Go there if you have time. It's amazing!

Unfortunately you'll be in Nepal out of the trekking season, otherwise I would've recommended a wonderful trek from Kathmandu to the Langtang valley, but I suppose you wouldn't have time for it anyway with your hectic itinerary. Anyway, Kathmandu is wonderfully atmospheric on its own, especially the main square at sunrise as it starts to come alive, with its temples, priests, beggers, rickshaw drivers, tea stalls and flower sellers. Surprisingly, it also has great cake shops!

There's also a huge Tibetan Buddhist temple just outside the city that you can reach on bicycle (if you dare! Roads in Nepal are possibly worse than in India!) that is incredibly beautiful and atmospheric. A must-see. fields.headline: Domi: Football365 story 'a total distortion'
fields.trailText: Didier Domi has attacked a report on website Football365.com, which claimed he wants to leave Newcastle because of Bobby Robson's old fashioned training sessions, as "a total distortion."
fields.body:
Didier Domi has attacked a report on website Football365.com, which claimed he wants to leave Newcastle because of Bobby Robson's old fashioned training sessions, as "a total distortion."

The website claimed that Domi wanted a move back to France because Robson's methods were behind the times and not helping his game.

But in a hastily-arranged press conference at St James' Park this morning, Robson read a prepared statement from Domi, which angrily refuted the claims.

"The stories are a total distortion. I have not made any such statements to any members of the Press criticising the training methods of Mr Robson, who is highly regarded throughout the world of football," said Domi.

"The extracts which appeared in the Football 365.com are a total fabrication of an interview I did with Le Parisien.The contents of that website are neither fair nor accurate and I think it only right that the public should be made aware of that," he added.

Several of the morning papers carried the initial story, in which Domi appeared to criticise his manager.

"With Bobby Robson, the training sessions are like those in days gone by," he reportedly said. "I need to work a lot, but we don't train much and I'm not at the top of my game.

"I'm not going to fulfil my true potential at Newcastle. Does that mean I want to fulfil it elsewhere? Why not? At the moment I am a Newcastle player, but anything is possible."

webTitle: In brief: Billy Elliot cleaned up for half-term

fields.headline: Billy Elliot cleaned up for half-term
fields.standfirst: Plus: Jim Carrey and Renee Zellweger to split after a year; Sir Elton's movie struggles to find a distributor; BBFC relaxes censorship ratings in line with new guidelines
fields.trailText: Plus: Jim Carrey and Renee Zellweger to split after a year; Sir Elton's movie struggles to find a distributor; BBFC relaxes censorship ratings in line with new guidelines
fields.body:
 A cleaned-up version of Billy Elliot is set to hit cinemas in the United Kingdom next year according to Variety. The film's producers have removed all 35 f-words in the film so that the rating can change from a 15 certificate to a U. The film, about a 12-year-old boy with a talent for ballet, is due to be re-released during next February's half-term holiday or over the following Easter holiday when the original version is released on video.

 The Daily Express reports today that Renee Zellweger and Jim Carrey have split up after spending a year together since meeting during the making of Me, Myself and Irene. Zellweger is said to be heartbroken after Carrey decided to call it a day after a series of rows and has moved out of the Los Angeles mansion she shared with the 38-year-old comic. Zellweger's publicist, Leslie Sloan, confirmed the split. "They're no longer in a relationship. They wanted separate things and sadly neither of them could resolve their differences." A 'friend' of the couple is reported to have said, "When Jim told Renee it was over she was devastated. She thought they were going to get married and start a family."

 Peoplenews.com reports that Sir Elton John's first film project, Women Talking Dirty, has been given a big thumbs-down by Hollywood movie chiefs and is struggling to find a distributor. The £3.5m comedy about female friendship, which stars Helena Bonham Carter as a single mum, was produced by Sir Elton's long-term partner David Furnish for the singer's Rocket Pictures production company. "We're still waiting for a distributor," admitted a spokesman for Rocket. "Until we've got a distributor we won't be showing it." However, the editor of Screen Daily seems less optimistic. "If you're being charitable, you could argue that Rocket are trying to get it right," he told the site. "If you're being nasty you could argue that the film's no good. The truth is probably somewhere in the middle."

 The British Board of Film Classification has started to relax its censorship ratings in the wake of new guidelines issued in September. Films such as The Terminator and The Last Temptation of Christ have dropped from an 18 rating to 15 for their DVD release. The latter caused outrage amongst some Christian groups when it was first released in 1988 for its so-called blasphemous content. A BBFC spokeswoman admitted that people's levels of taste and tolerance have changed over the years. "With a lot of the films, things that seemed shocking when they were classified in, say, the 1970s, are not quite so shocking now. People have become more sophisticated." The new BBFC guidelines suggest fewer cuts for movies with an 18 certificate, while the rules for 15-rated films will also be relaxed, notably for sex scenes shown as part of a loving relationship, although there will be a tightening up of the rules regarding depiction of drug use.

fields.headline: The great outdoors
fields.standfirst: Milly samples snowboarding, peanut butter and banana toast and honey lager, meets a runaway, and chews over the freedom of broadcasting
fields.trailText: Milly samples snowboarding, peanut butter and banana toast and honey lager, meets a runaway, and chews over the freedom of broadcasting
fields.body:
hi !
Having sacrificed breakfast to write my weekly report last week, I returned to Team Commonwealth van (I objected to the name Team Ozzie) to complete the long trip to Banff. It was so cold that the water in the van had frozen - we were all anticipating cold times ahead.

Lake Louise was one of our first major places to visit. It looks like a postcard, with the Rockies huge and snowy behind it. The lake itself was totally frozen so we (that is, me, Ange, Nic, Lisa and Hayden) ice-skated across it (look at the picture gallery) in trainers until our feet went numb and we had to go into the hotel to thaw out.

Carrying on to Banff, the town itself is as beautiful as Louise was. However, the cost of living in Banff is very high. We stayed at the HI Banff, which for the price had none of the atmosphere or even facilities of Vancouver's Global Village. In the evening we went looking for a good spot to drink and ended up in an Irish-style pub. We met some total oddballs from Quebec, but had an ok evening anyhow.

The next day I did start to wonder whether Banff had been a good idea. It was expensive, freezing, and I still had to return to Vancouver. I blame my morning's mood on excess drinking, because I soon realised that if I hadn't come I would have regretted it - after all, I still plan to see everywhere if possible!

That afternoon myself and Lisa booked a snowboarding lesson for the next morning. Feeling more positive, I had a home-cooked meal of spag bol - courtesy of Nic, and an early night.

Our boarding lesson the next morning was pretty early, and we managed to get there late, but it didn't matter. This is the first time I'd ever been boarding, and everybody had warned me it would be a painful day! Not to mention that it was now -20C outside, which is cold enough to get frostbite. The lesson was pretty frustrating, as I spent half of it falling on my arse, but I was determined to get the hang of it. After lunch and a rest I went back up the hill, and though I can't claim that I got good, I certainly got better, and had a lot of fun along with it (look at the picture gallery).

In the evening we had our last 'family' outing to the pub, as I had decided to return to Vancouver for my last week in Canada, Lisa was off to Toronto and Nic and Ange had found jobs. They managed to get work in just two days - I would definitely say have a visa if you want to work in Banff.

That evening at the pub I had a mini panic, because the ATM there refused to accept my visa. Although we reckoned on it being a temporary problem, Nic said she'd pay my part of the car hire cost, and I could give it to her parents when I got to Sydney. There you go - that's a pretty public IOU!

The night bus back to Vancouver was long, and I was sat next to a kid who'd been booted out of school and home, and was in the midst of a 92-hour journey to California! Everyone I meet seems to have a story to tell - there are so many weird and wonderful people round the world.

When I returned to the Global Village hostel on Monday morning I had every intention of resting. Which I should of known never happens! I met an Aussie named Will after five minutes, who introduced me to the delights of peanut butter and banana on toast (it really is incredibly good). He put the idea of working for Fox Studios at Sydney into my head, then he invited me to meet up with a friend of his who worked at CBC (the Canadian equivalent of BBC) for lunch. In the end we met up with two others, Yanick and Jacques, who were lovely men from Quebec. The four of us had lunch and discussed the differences between English and Canadian TV, freedom of broadcasting etc. So I have had some intelligent conversation since I left home!

In the afternoon Will and I went to Deep Cove, which is basically a crystal clear lake backed by the mountains. We had eggnog latte and banana cake for dinner, and then went to The Roxy, which is a terrible club, its only virtue being that it's free if you're from the hostel, and you get a free beer (which wins us over every time).

I took a trip to Granville Island the next day with Ken, an English hosteller. Someone has written asking for my opinion on the best beer at the brewery, so I felt it was my duty to find out! The tour itself was small but intimate - as Ken and I were the only two on it. The guide, Larney was lovely - he really knew his beer. And for the record, their best two are unquestionably honey lager, and their seasonal Christmas ale.

Now with five days left in Vancouver I've decided to go to Victoria Island tomorrow. It was a wrestle between my want and my wallet, but in the end my desire to see the place, and the many recommendations I've received won, so I'll be up early!!

Until next week (when I may finally be warmer),
Milly

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Rebecca
fields.trailText: Here are some suggestions for things to do in Sydney which I wouldn't have known if I hadn't gone there with someone who lived there! Make sure you go to Balmoral Beach which is a beautiful little town and a natural beach, complete with little island and rock pools.
fields.body:
Dear Milly,

Here are some suggestions for things to do in Sydney which I wouldn't have known if I hadn't gone there with someone who lived there! Make sure you go to Balmoral Beach which is a beautiful little town and a natural beach, complete with little island and rock pools. When you go to Bondi do the Bondi to Bronte walk which starts from a cliff path near the main street and is quite an easy walk with amazing views and a clifftop cemetry where the white gravestones look surreal against the blue Pacific.

The best places to go out are along Oxford Street, which is through Hyde Park and there are loads of cheap restaurants with really good food and bars which stay open until the early hours. Also some 'interesting' shops which also stay open late, and are worth a look if only for a laugh...

Have fun

fields.headline: Proof that Santa exists
fields.standfirst: How does Father Christmas get everywhere in one night?  Henry Gee  explains
fields.trailText: How does Father Christmas get everywhere in one night?  Henry Gee  explains
fields.body:
In his book, Unweaving The Rainbow, Richard Dawkins boasts that he tried to tell a six-year-old child that Father Christmas didn't exist. His argument was that Father Christmas would not be able to climb down all those chimneys and tiptoe noiselessly to the bedsides of hundreds of millions of children, all in one night. There simply wouldn't be enough time, even if reindeer were hypersonic.

Well, apart from being a somewhat cruel thing to do to a small child (the distinguished professor for the public understanding of science should pick on someone his own size), the argument is, to be charitable, an incomplete explanation. Dawkins may be no slouch when it comes to evolution, but he knows (by his own admission) rather less about physics. Of course Father Christmas exists, and he can visit arbitrarily as many children has he pleases in as short a time as is convenient, barring mid-air reindeer pile- ups. The reason is that Father Christmas is a Macroscopic Quantum Object.

Let me explain. It is a feature of the quantum world that particles - such as electrons - can be in more than one place at a time, provided that nobody is watching. In a famous experiment known as the "two-slit" test, physicists have been able to fire a single particle at an opaque plate with two separate slits in it. The diffraction pattern seen on the other side of the slits suggests that the particle passes through both holes at once and interacts with itself. However, if detectors are placed at the slits, to see which slit the particle passes through, the diffraction pattern disappears, and the particle can be seen to pass through either one slit or the other, but not both.

The key lies in the fact of observation. Provided that nobody seeks to measure the effect with more than a certain amount of precision, the particle keeps all its options open. But if someone looks too closely, the particle makes its choice. In the language of physics, its quantum wavefunction collapses.

Now, let's think of Father Christmas as a particle, obeying the rules of the quantum world. Following the logic of the two-slit experiment, it is perfectly possible for him to visit all the good children of the world simultaneously, provided that he does so unseen. If he is spotted, his wavefunction will collapse and he will be revealed as your Dad with a comedy beard after all. The quantum nature of Father Christmas explains the taboo against seeing him do his job - which Dawkins does not explain.

But there's more. It is possible to object that Father Christmas is far too large, rubicund and jolly to be a particle. In the real-life, macroscopic world of people, elves and flying reindeer, the quantum behaviour of each of the squillions of particles from which we are made averages out, so what we see is the everyday phenomenon of causes preceding effects, and people who can never be in two places at once.

Cynics might attribute this last consequence to the deficiencies of Railtrack, but it is a fact that real people, even bearded men with red hats and big boots, tend to be found in discrete locations, irrespective of whether they are being watched or not.

This objection doesn't wash, however, because it is possible to have macroscopic quantum objects that are larger than single particles. Scientists have managed to choreograph large clusters of atoms to behave as if they were just one particle, in a kind of nanoscopic Busby Berkeley routine. Admittedly, these clusters are too small to see with the naked eye, let alone qualify as cheerful red- faced men with sacks full of gifts, but the point is made.

Importantly, these macroscopic quantum objects observe the rules of the quantum world when cooled to within a whisker of absolute zero - minus 273 C. Any warmer than this, and the choreography breaks down and the clusters behave like any old bunch of atoms.

Nevertheless, in this frigidity might lie an explanation for another feature of Father Christmas that Dawkins neglects to explain - the undeniable fact that Father Christmas traditionally inhabits cold places, such as Lapland or the North Pole. OK, so neither of these places gets as chilly as absolute zero, but it must count for something that no deserving child would address their wish list to hot places such as, say, Borneo or Brazil. The very idea is quite ridiculous. QED (which stands for Quantum Electrodynamics, as any fule kno.)

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature.

fields.headline: Richard Sambrook's email to staff
fields.trailText: Click here for Richard Sambrook's email to staff
fields.body:
"The coverage of the Social Affairs reorganisation in this morning's papers is, as I hope you all realise, substantially wrong and misguided. We are actively seeking to redress errors and to put the record straight with the press on the reasons for the changes.

"Just to remind you, the review of the Social Affairs unit involved more than 6 weeks of consultation with correspondents and programmes. It is designed to build stronger relationships between specialists and programmes and give greater clarity about correspondent roles.

"In particular we wanted to strengthen the service to radio, online and News 24 -- all of which are vitally important services for us.

"The review also sees the introduction of seven new posts to the unit which will help us serve programmes better.

"At the heart of the plan is a strengthening of specialism, ensuring we continue to cover stories with insight and authority, an improved service to programmes and clarity of roles for hard-pressed correspondents.

"I hope anyone who has maliciously briefed the press will reflect on the damage they have done to themselves and to their colleagues."

Richard Sambrook
Deputy director
BBC News

fields.headline: Is God dead?
fields.standfirst: Paul MacInnes laments the decline of Robbie Fowler, an almighty star on Merseyside
fields.trailText: Last night, Liverpool beat Fulham in the Worthington Cup. It was a close - not to say dull - match, but it sparked into some sort of life in the 74th minute when Gerard Houllier brought on Michael Owen. But while Owen did well, scoring the opening goal, it was not his performance that caught the eye but the contrast between the birthday boy (many happy returns, Michael) and the man he replaced, Robbie Fowler.
fields.body:
Last night, Liverpool beat Fulham in the Worthington Cup. It was a close - not to say dull - match, but it sparked into some sort of life in the 74th minute when Gerard Houllier brought on Michael Owen. But while Owen did well, scoring the opening goal, it was not his performance that caught the eye but the contrast between the birthday boy (many happy returns, Michael) and the man he replaced, Robbie Fowler.

At this point, I should reveal a vested interest. I am a big Robbie Fowler fan. Always have been, since he burst into the Liverpool side in 1993. Roughly the same age as me, he had all the cheek and the flair I would have liked had I been any good at football. He scored great goals with effortless ease in a league which was otherwise pretty mediocre - an age when Anders Limpar was still considered a luxury player. What's more, he seemed a good laugh, and once wore a politically contentious t-shirt.

So watching Robbie last night and, to be honest, over the past couple of years, was like having Father Christmas bludgeoned to death in front of you. Sluggish, slow and with his head constantly down, Robbie looked nothing like the world beater I always thought he would become. He wasn't fast enough to find space and often didn't even attempt to - standing still when he should have been running, hanging back when Emile Heskey needed his support up front.

Even more galling was his lack of imagination. I remember Fowler scoring when nobody expected him to. One of his two goals against Aston Villa in the 1996 FA Cup semi-final sticks in the mind: Fowler standing at the right-hand side of the Aston Villa area, looking like crossing the ball, but instead leaning back and with the outside of his golden left foot, curling the ball past Mark Bosnich and inside the far post. He was known at Anfield as God. Last night, Fowler's most creative moment came when he smashed a ball off Steve Finnan in the hope of getting a corner.

Whatever happened to the likely lad? Well, there's the usual extenuating circumstances trotted out whenever Fowler is mentioned nowadays. The long periods out through injury, the publicly-denied rumours of cocaine addiction (which persist to this day), the disbanding of the Spice Boys and in particular the departure of best pal Steve McManaman. But that was all supposed to be in the past by now, and with Gerard Houllier nursing "the most natural finisher in Europe" back into the first team, we should have seen the old Robbie once more.

But the fact is that we haven't. And it's been a long time since we have. Fowler may have only scored five goals this season - including three against Stoke - but his totals over the last three seasons are 13, 18 and four respectively. He has never shown signs of forming a partnership with Michael Owen, who by contrast, pairs up with Heskey as easily as Nicole Appleton with high-profile rock stars. He also looks to be testing the patience of Gerard Houllier, whom Fowler interestingly describes on his website as his "greatest influence".

I have spent many hours lately wondering what the problem is. Perhaps in the new spangly Premiership, Robbie has become just another player - something I refuse to believe. Perhaps he is just slowly feeling his way back to form, although a year-long cruciate injury didn't slow Roy Keane any. Perhaps, after so long out of touch, he's lost confidence in his ability. Perhaps, despite all the protestations to the contrary, he isn't at ease with Gerard Houllier's new regime and must leave the club to succeed elsewhere. But perhaps we will never actually see the old Robbie again. Perhaps, just perhaps, God is dead.

fields.headline: The day the music mag died
fields.standfirst:
Comment: It was the first magazine to be dedicated to music and its death will be much mourned. From jazz through to rock 'n' roll and punk, Melody Maker charted the length and breadth of 20th century music.
Melody Maker axed
fields.trailText:
Comment: It was the first magazine to be dedicated to music and its death will be much mourned. Claire Cozens on the rise and fall of Melody Maker.
Melody Maker axed
fields.body:
It was the first magazine to be dedicated to music and for decades was a must-read for music lovers everywhere.

The death of Melody Maker is much mourned by Paul Lester, features editor between 1993 and 1997 and associate editor of the music magazine Uncut.

"It's always been a fantastic magazine and it's sad to see it go," he says. "But there is just too much choice out there now - there is no longer a sense of us and them.

"When you can read about music in every national newspaper and hear newsreaders talking about rock stars on the BBC it squeezes the life out of it.

"It's hard to get excited about the latest on Oasis when you can pick up a copy of the Sun and see Dominic Mohan schmoozing Noel Gallagher."

The first Melody Maker rolled off the printing press in 1926. The early Maker was dedicated to the burgeoning jazz movement and its pages were graced by such legends as Duke Ellington and Miles Davies.

But as new music trends emerged, it successfully adapted and by the time Elvis Presley came onto the scene Melody Maker was already the rock'n'roll bible.

From then on, rock was the Melody Maker's thing. In the late 60s the magazine embraced the new vein of psychedelic rock emerging from the west coast of America.

But the 70s were the magazine's heyday. By the early 70s, the magazine was championing the progressive rock movement, featuring bands such as Genesis and ELO, and by the mid-70s it had a circulation of over 250,000.

Mr Lester said: "I remember going into my local newsagents in the mid-70s and the man behind the counter talking about the Maker as the music lover's bible.

"Before punk came along it was the undisputed king of music journalism, riding the crest of the rock wave and getting scoops on icons such as The Stones and The Who."

Even the arrival of Sounds magazine in the 70s didn't chip away at the Maker's lead.

At that time it was neck and neck with the NME, but then punk came along and the Maker was slow to catch on, allowing the upstart magazines to steal a march.

The NME was very quick off the mark - you had people like Gary Bushell who was very in with Paul Weller, while the Maker was still doing rock.

It was the magazine's first false move and heralded a decline in its fortunes.

In the early 80s it started to do pop, writing about the likes of Wham, Spandau Ballet and even Kajagoogoo.

But when Alan Jones became editor all that changed again and the magazine started championing people like REM and The Smiths, marking a return to its rock roots.

By the late 80s the Maker was back on track. It was covering the bands that would become chart-toppers in the early 90s, like the Sugar Cubes, the Stone Roses and the Happy Mondays.

Next came grunge and Britpop and the Melody Maker was at the forefront again, featuring bands like Blur, Suede and the Manic Street Preachers well before its rivals.

But even though the magazine had its credibility back, sales were still in decline.

In a last-ditch attempt to revive the faltering title, the late 90s saw the Melody Maker transformed from a serious tabloid paper to an A4 glossy magazine that took into account the popularity of the boy and girl bands its loyal followers wouldn't dream of listening to.

The move backfired, succeeding only in alienating older readers without attracting younger pop fans.

By the time IPC announced its closure only a year after the revamp, Melody Maker had just 30,000 readers.

fields.headline: Debt-free United starts anew
fields.standfirst: United ditches new media brand
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: A revamped and debt-free United News & Media will start the year with £300m cash in the bank, writes Dan Milmo.
United ditches new media brand
fields.body:
A revamped and debt-free United News & Media will start the year with £300m cash in the bank, it said today.

United this afternoon made its final trading statement under its current name, stating that it expects full-year results to be "in line with expectations".

Its transformation from a media group into a business information company will be confirmed on Monday, when its name changes to United Business Media.

United has made £3.25bn from selling most of its consumer businesses, which included the Anglia, HTV and Meridian ITV franchises and the Express newspaper titles.

"It has been a tumultuous year, but that has been the same case for every media or internet company," said a United spokesman.

It is a dramatic role change from earlier this year, when United was on the verge of becoming the biggest player in ITV through a merger with Carlton Communications.

The deal was called off in the face of strong opposition from competition watchdogs, leaving Granada Media to step in and snap up the licences.

"In many respects we are a new company. We started the year as a media conglomerate with the intention to be the number-one player in ITV, and we are in a different position to where we thought we would be," the spokesman added.

He said that United will take £1.25bn in cash from Granada as part of the deal, which will then be handed back to shareholders in the new year.

Despite the frenetic selling activity, United still has a number of business-to-consumer interests, including a 35% stake in Channel 5 and 20% of ITN.

RTL, the pan-European media group which owns the rest of Channel 5, has openly expressed its interest in United's holding. United and BT have also put their LineOne internet service provider on the market.

"If RTL made us a good offer we would consider it, but at the moment we are very happy with our holding," the spokesman added.

Lord Hollick, United chief executive, now presides over a smaller empire which includes the CMP magazine business in the US, the United Information market research group and the PR newswire.

A big-money acquisition is unlikely in the short-term, but United is understood to be keen on a deal to cement its reputation as a business-to-business media company.

webTitle: Tory leader digs for election gold

fields.headline: Tory leader digs for election gold
fields.standfirst: William Hague's lurches to the right, the latest being today's attack on the Macpherson report, show that election fever is truly upon us, writes political correspondent Nicholas Watt
fields.trailText: William Hague's lurches to the right, the latest being today's attack on the Macpherson report, show that election fever is truly upon us, writes political correspondent Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
William Hague's advisers, who all hail from the Tory right, were delighted with themselves this morning.

On the day that radio and television bulletins should have been entirely dominated by the outcome of the US election, they had secured a decent billing for Mr Hague's provocative speech on crime.

The "condescending liberal elite", as Mr Hague dubbed supporters of the Macpherson report, are on the run and Britain's "decent law-abiding majority", as he dubbed everyone else, are flocking to him.

The Tory leader believes that his interventions on crime, which follow a familiar populist pattern, pay dividends at the polls.

Mr Hague performed reasonably well in this year's local elections after his first two lurches to the right on crime. Hardcore Tories whooped with delight when he promised to lock up all asylum seekers and pledged to "overhaul" the law to protect the likes of the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin, who was jailed for the murder of a teenage intruder.

Sadly for Mr Hague, his speeches merely reach out to core Tory supporters and fail to reach out to the centre ground voters who will decide the outcome of the next general election.

Mr Hague's success in the local elections were long predicted because the electoral cycle dictated that Tories would start bouncing back after the dismal failures of the early 1990s.

The Tory byelection defeat at Romsey on the same day as the local elections was a far more significant illustration of the party's poor standing at a national level. Romsey was true blue territory, but the Tories were defeated by the Liberal Democrats after Charles Kennedy took a strong, principled stand against Mr Hague's stance on crime.

Mr Hague dismissed the Romsey result as a local blip and voiced confidence that he speaks for Britain's mainstream majority.

However, shadow cabinet ministers admit in private that their job in the run-up to the election is to tap into grassroots Tory voters who abandoned the party in 1997. Expect more speeches such as today's, they say.

Some Labour strategists have, in the past, worried in private that Mr Hague may have a talent for tapping into the thinking of Middle England.

But Tony Blair showed no such qualms yesterday when he dismissed the Tory leader's speech dismissed as "desperate and disreputable". Election fever is well and truly upon us.

webTitle: Wilson to be appointed editor of Scotland on Sunday

fields.headline: Wilson lined up for Scotland on Sunday
fields.trailText: 5.15pm Andrew Neil is set to appoint a second Englishwoman as editor of one of his Scottish newspapers, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Andrew Neil is preparing to appoint a second Englishwoman as editor of one of his Scottish newspapers.

Margot Wilson, currently director of magazines at Scotsman Publications, is expected to be unveiled as editor of Scotland on Sunday, stablemate to the Scotsman and Edinburgh Evening News.

Her appointment follows the hiring of Rebecca Hardy as editor of the Scotsman earlier this year.

Ms Wilson was brought up from the Sunday Times in London by Mr Neil to edit Scotland on Sunday's Spectrum magazine. She was later appointed to oversee all three titles' magazines.

John McGurk, formerly editor of Scotland on Sunday, was appointed editorial director of Scotsman Publications last week. He is expected to become the public face of Mr Neil's titles north of the border.

webTitle: Frank tale, Fairy story, and Flight of fancy

fields.headline: Frank tale, Fairy story, and Flight of fancy
fields.trailText: WELL I'VE BEEN WORKING HARD TO REACH ME TARGET, TO EARN A FEW BOB TO PURCHASE GARETH SOUTHGATE
fields.body:
WELL I'VE BEEN WORKING HARD TO REACH ME TARGET, TO EARN A FEW BOB TO PURCHASE GARETH SOUTHGATE

Appy Arry Redknapp didn't get to the top of a massive concern like Appy Arry's Ammers without learning how to juggle a few balls at once. For example: he can insouciantly pull his team out of relegation bother without once looking up from the Racing Post; he can effortlessly give post-match interviews while letting his face gently melt to the floor; and he can keep Paolo Di Canio ringfenced from wandering Italian hands - Lazio are alleged to be back in with a £4m bid - while he makes a few tasty deals of his own.

You see, Arry's been on the blower to football's Mr Mohair Coat, John Gregory. Flush with cash after selling off the family silver, Arry reckons his chances of landing Gareth Southgate, especially as Aston Villa are chasing chinless midfielder Frank Lampard. And with Arry's reputation, there's no wonder the grapevine's been rustling with the news that the Villa have offered £7m for Lampard, or even a £3m-plus-big-lipped-England-defender package.

Arry, of course, responded with a rant. "It's a load of nonsense," he said. "I'm not going to swap Frank for Gareth - there's no way I'm selling Frank!" Of course, if you believe that elaborate east-end double bluff, you'll believe anything. You'll even believe he hasn't just offered Southampton £6.75m for Marian Pahars. "It's just a load of crap! I've not made an offer, and Pahars never even crossed my mind!" Lummee, he can't half bark that one.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 14: click here

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE LITTLE SVENNIS

Once upon a time, Svennis had two of the biggest jobs in football. He liked having the two jobs and thought he was the luckiest Svennis on earth. On Sundays he would watch Lazio and shout things at the players, and on Wednesday he would meet his friend Tord and ask him whether that Alan Shearer was any good or not. That made Svennis very happy.

But not everybody was as happy as Svennis. Sometimes Sergio Cragnotti would get upset when he looked at Lazio's listing on the Italian stock exchange. Sometimes Sergio would think that, despite having spent lots and lots of his hard-earned money, Lazio were not winning enough games. So, one morning, before a very important match with Roma, Sergio went to the Lazio training ground and said: "This is the most important derby since I became president. The match will be crucial for our season." Then Sergio's son Massimo turned up. And he said: "I hope Eriksson is right when he says all will be right with the team."

This made Svennis a little scared. He did not want to go to England just yet, he liked the sun in Italy and the FA hadn't had time to sort out his office. So Svennis decided to pretend he wasn't worried about losing his job, and told the men who worked for the newspapers: "The derby is important, but not decisive." The men from the newspapers all laughed, and went off to prepare pages with black borders. Poor little Svennis.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"No one individual is bigger than the club and I will be making that message very clear" - Aberdeen manager Ebbe Skovdahl trots out the old cliché, and just as he was about to sign Figo too.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DAUM TIME

Thanks to the power of modern technology, a flight from Orlando, United States, to Bogota, Columbia now takes a mere five hours and 35 minutes. A fact that might just tickle the fancy of Dyson-nosed German manager Christoph Daum - if he wasn't so busy doing something else. Like using his "new laptop with email access" to tell "his fans" how popular he is, for example. Today Daum - who has been bunkered up in Florida after testing positive for a Siberian winter's worth of cocaine - let it be known that Jesus Gil, the chairman who makes Kuddly Ken Bates seem strangely sane, wants to him to coach Atletico Madrid.

"It is a concrete offer and they want me to join straight away but I have decided to start working again only next summer," a nonchalant Daum claimed at 7.19am this morning, just before nicking the last sunbed by his Florida pool. webTitle: Redknapp dismisses Southgate - Lampard swap deal

fields.headline: Redknapp dismisses Southgate - Lampard swap deal
fields.trailText: Harry Redknapp has dismissed reports that Aston Villa have offered Gareth Southgate and £4m in cash for Frank Lampard as "a load of nonsense."
fields.body:
Harry Redknapp has dismissed reports that Aston Villa have offered Gareth Southgate and £4m in cash for Frank Lampard as "a load of nonsense."

And the West Ham manager also laughed off reports that he made a £6.75m bid for Southampton striker Marian Pahars as "a load of crap." "It's a load of nonsense," Redknapp claimed when asked about the possibility of a Southgate - Lampard switch. "I'm not going to swap Frank for Gareth - there's no way I'm selling Frank. I think Gareth Southgate's a good player but there's going to be no deal there."

Redknapp also added that a report linking him with a Pahars was also "not true". "It's just a load of crap - I've not made an offer, and Pahars never even crossed my mind," he insisted. "The search goes on!"

webTitle: We must plan for elderly migration

fields.headline: We must plan for elderly migration
fields.standfirst:
The migration of elderly people from cities to the coast is an increasing trend which will stretch the resources of small communities to the limit, says Greg Spencer, of the planning and strategy consultancy Local Knowledge.

Interactive guide: Ageing England - the rush to the coasts
fields.trailText: The migration of elderly people from cities to the coast is an increasing trend which will stretch the resources of small communities to the limit, says Greg Spencer, of the planning and strategy consultancy Local Knowledge.
fields.body:
When you look at a map of England in 2021, the most striking aspect is the migration of older people from cities to the coast.

Although people have traditionally left urban areas for the countryside when they have finished their working lives, this trend is forecast to increase as people live longer and enjoy a greater affluence.

The map shows that over the next 20 years, rural areas will tend to have much older populations than urban areas. The main reason for this is migration.

Young people tend to migrate to cities for economic opportunities and the urban lifestyle. Retired people tend to migrate to rural and coastal areas for the slower more relaxed pace and the natural beauty.

In between in suburban areas suits the needs of people in mid-life who have young families. A further migratory factor is that immigrants tend to settle in urban areas and also tend to be younger with children.

These general migration patterns, along with a population that is ageing, means that rural and coastal areas will experience the greatest amount of age-related problems.

An older population presents many problems including strain on the state earnings related pension scheme, higher healthcare costs and a shortage of working age people.

The office for national statistics predicts that the proportion of the population of England over 65 years of age will grow from 15.6% in 2000 to 19.2% by 2021.

West Somerset will have the highest proportion of retirement age people in 2021 at 30.7%. This contrasts with Tower Hamlets, where it is expected that slightly less than 9% of the population will be over 65.

Although the increase is not as high as other EU countries such as Germany or Italy, it does represent potential problems.

These extreme examples highlight the rural/urban split of the ageing population in England.

Rural and coastal areas are also characterized by other traits that pose potential problems to older populations.

 Access to basic services such as food shops, banks and post offices is more difficult in rural areas due to a more dispersed population.  Average distances to these basic services are greater. A second trait of rural areas is that public transport is not as effective.  Thinly populated areas cannot support efficient public transport. Add to this an older population that tends to have mobility problems and you have a potentially serious problem.  Local labour shortages are also a potential problem in areas with high proportions of retirement age people. In places like West Somerset, less than half of the population will be of working age.  Add to this a probable increase in demand for healthcare due to the ageing population and you have another potential problem.

So what can be done? It is unlikely that the migration patterns can be greatly altered. Increased levels of immigration will keep the populations of countries like the United States younger as a whole, but as mentioned earlier immigrants overwhelmingly settle in urban areas where populations are already young.

Immigration may help solve problems related to national pension schemes but it does not address the problems of local areas with significantly older populations.

Since many of the problems of an ageing population relate to access to services innovative ways to improve transport and delivery of services need to be sought.

Recent advances in information and communications technologies offer possible solutions to some of these problems. These technologies have the potential to reduce the travel needs of citizens.

The internet can offer information services as well as a way in which to purchase and then receive delivery of goods and services direct to peoples' homes. Transactions that would otherwise have required a journey to the nearest town centre can now be done with a click of a mouse. While services currently available on the net may be crude, in 20 years' time they are bound to be much more effective.

Sceptics might also argue that the elderly do not tend to use the internet. While true, again in 20 years today's IT savvy workforce will be retiring creating a new generation of wired-up pensioners.
