fields.headline: Bectu leader slams Davies appointment
fields.standfirst:
Dec 14: Davies named BBC vice-chairman
Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
4.30 pm update: Gavyn Davies' appointment as BBC vice-chairman has been branded "astonishing" and of great concern to staff, writes Jason Deans.
Dec 14: Davies named BBC vice-chairman
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
Gavyn Davies' appointment as BBC vice-chairman has been branded "astonishing" and of great concern to staff.

Gerry Morrissey, Bectu assistant general secretary, described the appointment as "astonishing", adding that it left the government open to "allegations of cronyism".

Mr Morrissey said: "Only 18 months ago Gavyn Davies proposed privatisation for large sections of the BBC. He was ultimately defeated on this proposal but our members will be concerned that he might wish to reintroduce his ideas for privatisation."

The Liberal Democrats and broadcasting union Bectu have both criticised the move because of his links to new Labour.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat media spokesman, said people in public positions such as BBC governor "have got to be seen to be politically neutral as far as possible".

Mr Baker added: "I would be very concerned about anyone in such as a position who's got a track record of involvement with a political party."

He said: "The BBC says it wants to be impartial and above politics. But it has got to play ball and appoint people who are not seen as being linked to one party or another".

webTitle: United News & Media ditches Xilerate in cull of consumer websites

fields.headline: United News & Media ditches Xilerate in cull of consumer websites
fields.trailText: 4pm: United News & Media has ditched its new media arm Xilerate and is looking to sell the remainder of its consumer websites, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
United News & Media has ditched its new media arm Xilerate and has confirmed it is looking to sell the remainder of its consumer-focused websites.

Whatever remains of the moribund division after the cull will sit within a new unit called United Business Media International.

MegaStar and Rapture TV are certain to be among the consumer brands sold off to make way for more investment in business-to-business titles. United's 50% stake in LineOne has already been put up for sale and uTravel was recently closed down after failing to make a mark in the online travel market.

Andrew Nugee, the chief executive officer of the new United Business Media International division, said the move had been on the cards since United sold its TV business in July. "It's about putting things in order with the rest of the group and specifically going forward, focusing on investments in the b2b market," he said.

Mr Nugee declined to elaborate on the statements made in the press release but suggested that all consumer-related websites, including dotmusic and its stakes in sub-club.com and spaced.co.uk, could be sold off if the price was right.

"Dotmusic has the benefit of being tied in heavily to Music Week but its 1.2m users are consumers after all. We're quite happy managing for value at the moment but we're a sensible grown up business and if someone came up with a tremendous offer we could sell."

Mr Nugee is now tasked with a whole new role - rather than building up Xilerate into a consumer and business giant, he has to rationalise and integrate media business of trade shows, professional magazines and remaining online activities.

Xilerate was set up with £270m in funding at the start of the year in preparation for United's merger with Carlton. After that deal fell through and then Express Newspapers was sold, United, left with no consumer business, had no power to cross-promote consumer websites. United's investment in the whole of its business-to-business new media activities in 2001 is now expected to be around £60m.

fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB has abandoned the launch of internet bank Evolvebank.com in Britain and will instead create a bank for Goldfish, Centrica's quirky credit card brand.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB has abandoned the launch of internet bank Evolvebank.com in Britain and will instead create a bank for Goldfish, Centrica's quirky credit card brand.

The announcement was immediately embroiled in controversy when Centrica's 50-50 partner in Goldfish, HFC, pointed out its contract was still in place and it could not be assumed that Goldfish's 1m customers belonged to Centrica. Centrica wants to transfer them to the new venture, to be known as Goldfish Holdings, next year.

The venture is intended to break even by 2003 and have 2m customers by 2005 when cheque books and current accounts will be available.

Evolvebank.com was scheduled to open in the coming weeks after launching in Spain last month. Lloyds TSB said it was unlikely to reconsider taking it live until at least May.

Centrica is retaining control of Goldfish, with a 70% stake and Lloyds TSB is taking 30%. The ownership structure prompted speculation that the new bank will eventually be spun off.

fields.headline: Blair warns Bush of 'awesome responsibility'
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today told George W Bush that he was "assuming an awesome responsibility", as the Texas governor was finally  confirmed as the next president of the United States of America.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today told George W Bush that he was "assuming an awesome responsibility", as the Texas governor was finally confirmed as the next president of the United States of America.

In an eight-minute transatlantic telephone call from Warwick University - where Mr Blair is speaking with the US president, Bill Clinton - the prime minister said that he personally, and the UK as a whole, would be a good friend and supporter to Mr Bush.

Downing Street said that during the conversation, Mr Bush stressed that he was "very aware of the special relationship" between Britain and the US.

He added that he was pleased that this was the first telephone call he had received from a foreign leader since becoming president-elect.

Both leaders looked forward to having a "very close" working relationship and agreed they should meet as soon as Mr Bush settled into the job, Downing Street said.

Mr Bush "recalled fondly" a visit he made to Scotland when he was working in the oil industry, No 10 added.

Later, Mr Blair paid a fulsome tribute to Mr Clinton in his speech at Warwick University, describing him as a "true leader of the western world".

And he added: "He has been a friend and a counsel to me and many other political leaders right round this world."

Of Mr Bush, the prime minister said: "I know he will be a friend of Britain and Europe ... Britain will be a friend to him and America.

"The world needs a strong America and America is strong today, and I'm sure under president-elect Bush it will continue to be so.

"I offer to President Bush, on behalf of a country proud to call itself America's strongest ally, our unwavering support."

The Texas governor was today attending a morning service of worship and music at an Austin church - his first act as president-elect after his muted victory speech.

His adviser Karen Hughes said: "The governor decided that he wants to start this on a message of prayer and healing,"

A ceremony was scheduled for later today opening the doors of a government-run transition office to the Bush transition team headed by the vice president-elect, Dick Cheney.

Opening his speech at the university, Mr Clinton paid tribute to the "unusual" friendship between himself and Mr Blair and their respective families.

Earlier, Mr Clinton complimented Mr Bush on for the "generosity" of his remarks and urged the nation to "follow vice-president Gore's lead" and unify behind Mr Bush and his new administration.

Mr Clinton, who was up past 3am watching the concession and acceptance speeches from Chequers, Mr Blair's country retreat, invited Mr Bush to the White House during a four-minute phone call.

Mr Bush and Mr Gore are to meet on Tuesday in Washington.

Mr Clinton said: "I pledged to president-elect Bush my efforts and the best efforts of every member of our administration for a smooth and successful transition.

The president also spoke with Mr Gore.

Mr Bush is expected to move quickly to name a White House staff and a prospective cabinet, with top billing going to retired general Colin Powell as the secretary of state.

He has already picked Andrew Card, transportation secretary in his father's term, as his White House chief of staff.

fields.headline: Davies report: main points
fields.trailText: Forgotten the Davies report? Refresh your memory here
fields.body:
The Davies committee's main recommendations for the future funding of the BBC in August 1999:

 A digital licence supplement on top of the licence fee to be introduced from April 2000. It should start at £24 a year and fall to £12 by 2006.

 There should be no introduction of advertising, sponsorship or subscription to the BBC's core services.

 BBC Worldwide and Resources should be partially privatised.

 BBC accounts should be more transparent and open to greater scrutiny by the Office of Fair Trading and the National Audit Office.

 The licence fee discount for blind people should be increased to 50%.

fields.headline: Media Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 15.
fields.trailText: December 15: The government's white paper has generated frustration and praise among the media community.
fields.body:
The government's white paper has generated a mix of frustration and curious praise among the media community.

IPC Media has axed its digital arm, IPC Electric, a year after its creation, rehousing specific online brands - BeMe.com, NME.com, UnmissibleTV.com and Uploaded, within their relevant magazine publishing groups.

Attic Futura is launching a teen entertainment magazine linked to the successful children's TV programme SM:TV/CD:UK.

The Daily Star is launching a 56-page weekly TV guide called Startime on Saturday.

Kelvin MacKenzie is bidding for a package of premiership football rights for broadcast on the London macro of TalkSport.

Carlton TV has signed a £750,000 deal that will see Roche's indigestion treatment, Rennie, advertised next to 30 programmes over Christmas.

Flextech has poached Nicola Townsend, MediaVest's business development manager, to head up its new client sales division.

Profile of BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey on page 15. The accompanying photo shows her revealing a bit of inner thigh. Could this be part of her new populist approach?

webTitle: IPC Electric rumours 'totally and utterly inaccurate'

fields.headline: IPC Electric rumours 'totally and utterly inaccurate'
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: IPC Media has denied it has closed its digital division, IPC Electric, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
IPC Media has lambasted reports that it has pulled the plug on IPC Electric, its digital division.

Julie York, IPC director of corporate communications, said she was furious about a story that appeared in this week's trade magazine Media Week.

She said that reports that it was closing Electric were "totally and utterly inaccurate".

"We have absolutely no plans to shut down the division. Why would we do this after just getting an extra £15m in funding for the division?

"All we've done is move the business development teams to sit within their respective publishing brands. It made more sense to do this," she continued, adding that sales, IT and finance were still centralised within Electric.

The fresh investment, adding to the IPC Electric start-up investment of £25m in September last year, will mean that Electric can now launch new brands to add to BeMe.com, UnmissableTV.com, NME.com and Uploaded.

Ms York said Electric was now "charging ahead" with new sites, the first of which would be a lifestyle-based site looking at specialist hobbies.

webTitle: Byelection sparks Scottish TV political coverage order

fields.headline: Byelection sparks Scottish TV political coverage order
fields.trailText: 3pm: The ITC has ordered Scottish TV to give opposition parties extra coverage after this week's Ask the Prime Minister special, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Scottish Television has been ordered by TV regulators to give opposition political parties extra coverage in the aftermath of Monday's Ask the Prime Minister ITV special.

STV has fallen foul of political impartiality regulations that require commercial broadcasters to give equal coverage to all political parties in the run-up to a byelection.

The broadcaster has been ordered by the Independent Television Commission to give the Tories, Liberal Democrats and Scottish Nationalists extra peak-time coverage prior to the Falkirk West byelection on December 21.

Sandy Ross, STV managing director, said the broadcaster "was seeking clarification from the ITC and will take appropriate advice" before commenting further.

He added: "We take our responsibilities as an impartial and balanced broadcaster very seriously and decided to broadcast Ask the Prime Minister only after careful consideration."

Failure to comply with the legally binding ITC directive would be a breach of STV's licence.

Tuesday night's Ask the Prime Minister, a 60-minute peak-time Q&A with Tony Blair, has already caused a row south of the border with opposition parties demanding similar coverage from ITV.

But ITV argued that Mr Blair was appearing in his capacity as prime minister and not as Labour leader.

The broadcaster also said it was not bound by rules governing political impartiality, because Ask the Prime Minister was broadcast outside a general election.

fields.headline: 'Desperate' Hague attacks Lawrence report
fields.standfirst: Full text of Hague's speech
fields.trailText: William Hague was today branded "desperate" after claiming that the report into the racist murder of Stephen Lawrence has contributed to a "collapse" in police morale and recruitment.
fields.body:
William Hague was today branded "desperate" after claiming that the report into the racist murder of Stephen Lawrence has contributed to a "collapse" in police morale and recruitment.

The Tory leader linked the Macpherson report on the black teenager's murder to a sharp fall in the use by police of stop-and-search powers, and noted that since its publication street crime had soared.

Mr Hague's comments, in a speech to the Centre for Policy Studies in London, were condemned by the prime minister's official spokesman as a "pretty desperate and pretty disreputable" attempt at "casting around to get himself noticed".

Sir William Macpherson dismissed Mr Hague's claim that his report highlighting institutional racism in the police had led to a reduction in the police stop-and-search policy and a rise in crime. "I am simply most surprised that the Tory party should change its view, because at the time the report was written they, in common with the government, accepted the report," said Sir William.

Mr Hague denied he was "playing the race card". In his speech, the Tory leader said: "We have now had 21 months to assess the impact of the Macpherson report. In that period the use of stop-and-search powers by the Metropolitan police has fallen.

"In February 1999 the Metropolitan police made 18,752 arrests following stop and searches. In September this year, new provisional figures show that has dropped by more than a third to just 11,858 arrests. At the same time, street crime has soared - not just in London but around the country."

Earlier the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said people should show "gratitude" when they are stopped by the police. Miss Widdecombe said regular stop and searches showed that the force was doing its job and helping to fight crime.

Her comments came ahead of a meeting with Tory leader William Hague and the Chief Superintendent Simon Foy at Brixton police station, south London.

webTitle: Pinochet's drug link comes to light

fields.headline: Pinochet's drug link comes to light
fields.trailText: The Chilean army and secret police have spent almost two decades secretly flooding Europe and the United States with cocaine.
fields.body:
The Chilean army and secret police have spent almost two decades secretly flooding Europe and the United States with cocaine.

The trafficking began during General Augusto Pinochet's 17-year dictatorship, and continues to this day, a year-long investigation has established. Twelve tonnes of the drug, with a street value of several billion dollars, left Chile in 1986 and 1987 alone.

The drugs, destined for Europe, have often been flown to Spanish territory by planes carrying Chilean arms to Iraq and Iran. Distribution to European nations has been controlled by secret police stationed in Chilean embassies in Stockholm and Madrid.

There can be no doubt that Gen Pinochet, whose power was absolute between the 1973 coup and 1990, when he stepped down, was a party to trafficking. He declared in October 1981: "Not a leaf moves in Chile if I don't move it - let that be clear."

The secret police - originally known as the Dina and from 1977 as the SNI - was staffed by service personnel, and helped Gen Pinochet to torture and kill opponents. The general kept a close, day-by-day check on all secret police operations. The Dina's former director, Gen Manuel Contreras, told the Chilean supreme court in 1998 that he undertook nothing without Gen Pinochet's permission.

The huge profits from the drug deals went to enrich senior figures in Chile, with some going to finance the Dina/SNI operations.

Gen Pinochet, who is fighting arrest on kidnapping and murder charges in Santiago, has not clarified how he and his wife, Lucia, had more than $1m in their account in the Riggs Bank in Washington in March 1997. As commander-in-chief of the Chilean army his annual salary at that time was $16,000.

New evidence of Gen Pinochet's collaboration with Colombian drug dealers, first sketched out last year in my book, Pinochet: The Politics Of Torture, has emerged in The Thin White Line, a new book by Rodrigo de Castro, a former international civil servant in Chile, and Juan Gasparini, an Argentine journalist.

It quotes US court documents, Chilean police files and depositions by a former US marine, Frankell Ivan Baramdyka, who was involved in the trafficking. Baramdyka was extradited from Chile in May 1993 and convicted in California of narcotics offences. He worked for US intelligence in the early 80s, and was encouraged to traffic in drugs on condition that some of the profits went to the Contra terrorists in Nicaragua, who were supported by President Ronald Reagan.

After the US authorities raided his home in Los Angeles in 1985, Baramdyka fled to Santiago, where he set up a new trafficking operation. Later that year he was recruited by the Chilean secret police, and was soon overseeing the army's drug-export activities. The Observer

fields.headline: Global Megabucks plc faces setback
fields.trailText: A subtle shift has occurred in the lexicon of globalisation over the past 12 months. Before Seattle it was assumed there was an inexorable logic to the process and that the market supremacist model would benefit rich and poor alike.
fields.body:
A subtle shift has occurred in the lexicon of globalisation over the past 12 months. Before Seattle it was assumed there was an inexorable logic to the process and that the market supremacist model would benefit rich and poor alike.

This line of argument was, of course, attractive to those doing rather well out of globalisation, which - surprise, surprise - just happened to be the wealthy and the powerful. In other words, the same people who had done rather well out of the policies favoured by rightwing governments in the 80s and 90s, and could not see why people were making such a big fuss about mass unemployment and rising inequality.

Since Seattle the mood has changed. Globalisation is no longer viewed as a force of nature, but something that can and must be shaped by human endeavour and ingenuity. It has been recognised that there are inherent problems in a system where capital calls all the shots and has total freedom of movement, while labour is voiceless and has to stay where it is.

The release this week of the UK government's discussion document on globalisation is a step in the right direction, as is its title - Eliminating World Poverty: Making Globalisation Work for the Poor. Clare Short, the International Development Secretary, rightly says in the foreword to the white paper: "Cynicism and negativism are the enemies of progress. It is when people see that progress is possible that the demand for reform and advance is energised."

Making globalisation people-friendly requires two things - a closing of the yawning democratic deficit and a rebalancing of the lop-sided relationship between labour and capital. One proposal is that any future trade deals should contain a commitment to abide by core labour standards, with sanctions against those countries that breach the global code. Not surprisingly, poor countries are extremely hostile to this idea, seeing it as a backdoor form of protectionism, which it is. As Ajit Singh and Ann Zammit argue in a paper written for the South Centre, an intergovernmental organisation of developing countries, there is a better way.

The paper's argument is fairly straightforward. Labour standards improved in the West as countries became richer, not because draconian conditions were imposed on them from outside. The main factor preventing labour standards from improving in the developing world is poverty and economic hardship, not the wickedness of governments. Moreover it says that "adopting measures which are tantamount to forcing compliance with ILO core labour standards will not achieve the declared objective of raising labour standards in the south. Indeed, this would be quite the wrong way to go about achieving improved labour standards, both core and otherwise, in developing countries."

Even so, there may be some in the north who would say that workers in developed countries deserve to be protected, whether labour standards improve in the developing world or not. In fact, there is not much evidence that this would happen even if goods from developing countries were priced out of Western markets. Why? Because the most severe competition for advanced countries comes from the small number of newly industrialising countries whose productivity growth rate is much faster than that of advanced countries, not from countries that would be targets of trade sanctions.

Singh and Zammit say that in recent years there has actually been greater slippage in labour standards in the north than in the south. But they argue that the main cause of this malaise "lies in the current processes of economic globalisation, which emphasise free trade, free movement of capital, and labour market flexibility within national economies. Most analysts will agree that the last two characteristics disadvantage labour, north and south, and favour capital".

This is not the perception in the north, particularly in those industries, such as textiles, which are threatened with extinction by cheap imports. The lack of Western-style labour standards is seen as leading to greater import penetration, undermining efforts by northern trade unions to improve the terms and conditions of work and providing incentives to shift production to the south.

Imposing labour standards on developing countries would at best be an irrelevance and at worst positively harmful. For the really poor nations a code backed by sanctions would choke off export growth, worsening the balance of payments, and force growth rates to be lower to keep the current account in equilibrium.

The experience of the Asian tigers is that this would slow up the pace of structural change and hinder the improvement in working conditions. Real wages grew at 5% a year between the early 80s and mid-90s in east Asia and southeast Asia, countries that were repressive of trade unions in their early stages of development. But the pace of growth led to the expansion of the formal economy at the expense of the informal sector, leading not only to better labour standards but a very considerable expansion of unionisation.

Singh and Zammit say that higher labour standards in the south would require faster economic growth and structural change, which would involve measures to reduce poverty and inequality that would include labour market policies. Such a process would be helped if advanced countries themselves were growing faster.

Their solution, in short, is one where the burden of economic adjustment falls on creditor as well as debtor nations, where developing countries are given special and preferential treatment in trade agreements, where a floor is put under commodity prices and where controls on the free movement of capital permit more rapid economic expansion.

Those who have read the final volume of Robert Skidelsky's three-part biography of John Maynard Keynes (Fighting For Britain, Macmillan, £25) will know that such a scheme was proposed in the build-up to the Bretton Woods conference in 1944, but was rejected in favour of the more limited, and harsher, US alternative. There is a route to people-friendly globlalisation but there is a long struggle ahead. Having the right answers is not enough, because while Britain had the arguments, the Americans had the power. And that is what counts.

Before Seattle it was assumed there was an inexorable logic to the process and that the market supremacist model would benefit rich and poor alike. webTitle: Daily Mail set for circulation war with Express

fields.headline: Daily Mail set for circulation war with Express
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: The Daily Mail is ready for a tough circulation war with the new-look Express, reports Dan Milmo.
Dec 14: Mail owner braced for tough year
fields.body:
The Daily Mail is bracing itself for a tough circulation war following Richard Desmond's acquisition of middle market rival the Daily Express.

Peter Williams, finance director of parent company the Daily Mail & General Trust, said the OK! tycoon's move will stir up excitement in a market that the Mail has dominated for years.

"I think he has a good track record in terms of making profits out of print titles, but we have the high ground in terms of the best product and we intend to keep it that way," he said.

The Express moved to the left under previous owner Lord Hollick, but Mr Desmond has already made changes to its editorial stance by increasing the celebrity coverage with OK! tie-ins.

The Mail responded almost immediately by striking a deal with Hello! magazine, OK!'s bitter rival.

Mr Williams added: "Attack is the best form of defence. We do not want to be complacent, as he has paid a lot for these papers and he will want to make a return on his investment."

No expense will be spared in the battle against the Express group, which includes the Sunday Express and the Daily Star, despite DMGT reporting a 7% cut in full-year profits.

The Mail has an average weekly circulation of 2.38m, against around 1m for the Daily Express.

Meanwhile, Mr Williams brushed off fears that the group's Metro freesheet is proving a drain on finances. This year the company invested between £20m-£25m in the newspapers, which target commuters all over the UK, and have yet to make a profit.

"Metro is moving rapidly in the right direction and it is growing all the time," he added.

fields.trailText: Chronology of events in the US election race.
fields.body:
December 12
The US supreme court rules for Mr Bush, halting recounts of disputed Florida presidential ballots ordered by the Florida supreme court, after concluding in a 7-2 vote that the decision violates the US constitution's protections of due process and equal protection under the law. But the supreme court splits by a 5-4 vote along ideological conservative and liberal lines in deciding that new recounts should not be ordered to remedy the problem. Democratic National Committee Chairman Ed Rendell calls for Mr Gore to concede the election, although he later says the vice-president has "every right" to review the decision.

December 11
The US supreme court hears oral arguments in Bush v Gore.

December 9
Just hours after several Florida counties started the court-mandated hand recounts, the US supreme court grants Mr Bush's plea to halt them temporarily pending a hearing on his challenge to the recounts. All counting stops.

December 8
In a stunning reversal of fortune, the Florida supreme court keeps Mr Gore's hopes alive by reversing Judge Sauls and ordering a manual recount of 9,000 disputed votes in Miami-Dade County and any other disputed ballots in other Florida counties. But suits concerning absentee ballots brought by Gore supporters in two Leon County courts in Tallahassee are rejected.

December 7
The Florida supreme court hears Mr Gore's appeal of Gore v Harris.

December 4
The US supreme court sets aside the Florida supreme court ruling in the hand-count deadline, giving temporary victory to Mr Bush; Mr Bush also wins when Judge Sauls rejects Mr Gore's suit to challenge Florida's certified result. The Gore team appeals to the Florida supreme court.

December 2
Judge Sauls hears the Democrats request to overturn the state-certified election results in Palm Beach County, Miami-Dade and Nassau counties.

December 1
The US supreme court hears arguments over whether the Florida supreme court overreached when it allowed the hand recount of some Florida votes to continue; the "ballot caravan" travels through Florida to the Tallahassee courthouse carrying 654,000 votes from Miami-Dade County for a possible recount; the Florida supreme court rejects Mr Gore's motion for an immediate recount and also rejects a motion from Palm Beach citizens who objected to the "butterfly ballot" used in that county.

November 30
A truck carrying 463,000 ballots from Florida's Palm Beach County arrives at a courthouse in Tallahassee for a possible recount.

November 27
Al Gore contests the November 26 vote certification in Florida, challenging results in Miami-Dade, Nassau and Palm Beach counties. The case, Gore v Harris, is assigned to Leon County Circuit Court Judge N Sanders Sauls. The US general services administration, which acts as federal landlord and office manager, refuses to turn over transition office space to the Bush team.

November 26
Florida Secretary of State Katherine Harris certifies Mr Bush as winner of Florida's 25 electoral votes. Mr Bush claims victory and appoints Mr Cheney to head his transition team.

November 24
The US supreme court agrees to hear arguments in the Bush lawsuit challenging Florida supreme court's decision to allow continued hand counts of votes. Mr Cheney is released from hospital.

November 22
Officials in Miami-Dade County, the largest of three counties conducting manual vote recounts, abandon the effort, saying they will not meet the November 26 certification deadline. Republican vice-presidential candidate Dick Cheney suffers a slight heart attack.

November 21
As the court deliberates, hand recounts continue in three Florida counties. In Broward county, Al Gore gains 118 votes, fewer than Democrats had hoped for. Late in the day, the Florida supreme court rules 7-0 that Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, must include the hand recounts in the state's final result: this is the news Al Gore had been hoping for.

November 20
Republicans and Democrats present their cases to the Florida high court on whether the results of hand recounts should, after all, be included in the final result for Florida. Katherine Harris defends her claim that they should not be. Meanwhile, another judge declares that he lacks authority to call for a revote in Palm Beach.

November 19
Palm Beach county resumes its recount. Early indications suggest that the hand recounts are finding far fewer extra votes than expected for Al Gore. In a string of small court cases, Republican efforts to block the recounts are rejected.

November 18
An unofficial tally of the result including all postal votes puts George W Bush further ahead, with a lead of 930 votes. Democrats put their hope in hand recounts, which are expected to cut into this lead.

November 17
The deadline for receipt of overseas postal votes arrives. Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, makes it clear that she expects to declare a final result for the state the next day, regardless of any recounts under way. A local court approves of this decision - to the Democrats' dismay - but later the Florida supreme court blocks Ms Harris from announcing a result until the hand recounts are complete. A Republican appeal to a federal court to halt recounts is also rejected.

November 16
At the federal appeals court, Republicans and Democrats battle over the conduct of hand recounts. Meanwhile, a separate case at the Florida supreme court allows Palm Beach and Broward counties to carry on with their recounts - a key victory for Mr Gore. By now there are about 27 court cases under way involving the election.

November 15
Katherine Harris applies to the Florida supreme court to block all hand recounts. This application is denied, allowing the recounts to continue - although Ms Harris says she will render them irrelevant by ignoring all hand recounts when she announces the final results, due on November 18. Meanwhile, the Palm Beach recount continues and Broward county decides to conduct a full hand recount. A judge rules that Palm Beach officials can set their own rules on determining which ballot papers are valid - good news for Al Gore.

November 14
The Gore move fails when a Florida court upholds Ms Harris's right to enforce the deadline. However, after suspending its hand recount, Palm Beach county votes to resume it the following day, in defiance of the deadline.

November 13
The legal move by Mr Bush to block the counts fails, but he gets better news when Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, announces that she will not extend a 5pm EST, November 14 deadline for the final certification of votes in Florida. She announces that she will ignore the results of any hand recounts which miss this deadline. The Gore campaign announce that they will go to court to overturn her decision and protest that Ms Harris is an active Republican and known Bush supporter.

November 12
Volusia county and the larger Palm Beach county carry out manual recounts. Since manual counts allow more ballot papers to pass as valid than machine counts, this is good news for Al Gore. George W Bush applies to a federal court to block the counts.

November 10
The full machine recount of votes across Florida is declared. Some estimates put Mr Bush ahead of Mr Gore by only 327 votes.

November 9
Confusion reigns. Al Gore demands a hand recount of votes in four largely Democratic counties, including Palm Beach.

November 8
At 12am GMT polls close in Florida. Within an hour, Associated Press and major TV networks use exit polls to declare Al Gore the victor in the state. Bush supporters in Austin, Texas, cannot hide their dismay. Mr Gore appears to be on his way to the White House.

By 2.30am, actual returns from Florida show Mr Bush is doing better than the exit polls suggested. At 3am, TV networks admit that the Florida result is uncertain and withdraw it from the list of Gore victories. At 7.15am, the networks declare Mr Bush the winner in Florida, and announce that he has won the election.

Soon after Mr Gore calls Mr Bush to concede the election. He leaves his headquarters, intending to make a concession speech to his supporters - but on learning that the Republican lead in Florida is suddenly much smaller than expected, he returns to his headquarters and calls Mr Bush to retract his concession.

At 9.15am, major television networks withdraw their claim that George W Bush has won the election. Later, final tallies in Florida put Mr Bush ahead by 1,725 votes - close enough to trigger an automatic recount using the scanning machines which normally count votes in Florida.

In a development which initially receives lavish attention, it becomes clear that a complex "butterfly" ballot paper in one Florida county confused many voters: 19,000 votes in the county are disqualified and others go unexpectedly to Reform candidate Pat Buchanan. This leads to the first of many court cases, when Palm Beach electors demand a revote in their county. Later, this case fades from the headlines as other court challenges come to the fore.

November 7
Polling day - George W Bush is ahead in the polls but Al Gore has made up ground after a marathon campaign across battleground states.

fields.headline: BBC's new labourer faces criticism
fields.standfirst:
Accusations of political patronage have met Gavyn Davies' appointment at the BBC. But is he really just another of Tony's cronies?
Dec 14: Davies named BBC vice-chairman
Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
Accusations of political patronage have met Gavyn Davies' appointment at the BBC. But is he really just another of Tony's cronies?
Dec 14: Davies named BBC vice-chairman
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
New BBC vice-chairman Gavyn Davies is no stranger to being accused of new Labour cronyism in his dealings with the corporation.

The Tories levelled exactly this charge against the Goldman Sachs economist last summer, when the government advisory committee he chaired recommended a digital licence fee to meet the BBC's funding needs.

The accusation made by the Conservatives was that Mr Davies' new Labour credentials meant his review was not truly independent and the result therefore meaningless, because the chairman had already made up his mind that the BBC should have more money.

Mr Davies easily brushed off the criticism, saying the committee produced a "balanced report, not a new Labour solution".

However, there is no getting away from his close ties to new Labour and in particular chancellor Gordon Brown.

Nor is there any doubt about his broad support for the BBC's public service broadcasting remit, or - following his involvement in the funding review last year - his intimate knowledge of the BBC's sprawling media empire and the challenges it faces moving forward into the digital age.

Mr Davies' links with the governing party go back to the old Labour days of the 1970s, when he was economic advisor to prime minister Jim Callaghan.

These days his wife, Sue Nye, runs Mr Brown's private office.

He first set out his views on the future funding of the BBC in a 1997 co-authored essay for a pamphlet commissioned by the corporation, which advocated an increase in the licence fee.

But if after reading this tract, BBC insiders were expecting an easy ride in the review of BBC finances that Mr Davies chaired last year, they were in for a shock.

Although it accepted some of the BBC's arguments for extra funding, the Davies committee also urged further cost-cutting, the sell-off of BBC Resources, the sale of a minority stake in BBC Worldwide and for the corporation's finances to be opened up to National Audit Office scrutiny.

Sir John Birt, then BBC director-general, was certainly not pleased, accusing Mr Davies of authoring an illogical report that threatened the corporation's independence.

Long before he was drawn into the highly politicised world of BBC governance and funding, Mr Davies had fashioned a highly successful City career with leading investment bank Goldman Sachs.

He rose to become a partner in the firm and its chief international economist.

Last summer Mr Davies, along with other senior executives, became seriously rich from share options when Goldman Sachs became the last of the old-school Wall Street investment banks to go public.

fields.headline: Net brings new hope to Africa
fields.standfirst:
Following its bitter civil war, Rwanda is looking towards the web as a way of uniting and enriching the nation, writes Will Woodward
Net news
fields.trailText: Following its bitter civil war, Rwanda is looking towards the web as a way of uniting and enriching the nation, writes Will Woodward
fields.body:
In a classroom in the National University of Rwanda in Butare, students sit at computer screens, typing in records for a government project.

From piles of green plastic bags, they take long sheets of paper and record the names of those dead or missing from their communities in the genocide of 1994. The students get paid £5 a week for six mornings' work, logging in names such as Anatalie Mukasirire. A subsistence farmer aged 34, and the head of a family, she was killed with a machete in April 1994, in her home because of her ethnic group. In the row below her is the name of her daughter Nyirama, aged four, who died the same way, in the same place, for the same reason.

In the next room, one of the NUR's three internet cafes is humming and crowded. Final year students, who pay about 80p a month for a card which gives them an hour's use a day, are writing emails to friends, looking at chess problems, and researching.

Computers in Rwanda are used, as in the other room, for assessing the tragedy which struck the country, but also for reconstruction, education, looking forward. The university, along with the Kigali Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) in the Rwandan capital, has the cheapest, fastest internet access in the country, thanks to help from the Leland Initiative, a US scheme to extend internet connections to more than 20 African countries, which has given them a year's free internet access through the VSAT (very small aperture terminal) system.

The university has 160 computers now, of which 54 have internet access, and should soon have 250. Most NUR students had never seen the internet before they got here.

The new 31-student computer studies department is thriving and looking to expand and the department is planning to rent out the internet access to others in the city, to schools and foreign businessmen and NGO (non-governmental organisation) staff.

KIST is doing the same, and even offered free internet access to a cybercafe for six months to help it get on its feet.

The Rwandan government has latched on to information and communications technology (ICT) as an engine to deliver what would be a stunning transformation of its economy. "ICT are offering Rwanda a window of opportunity to leapfrog the key stages of industrialisation and transform her subsistence agriculture dominated economy into a service-sector driven, high value information and knowledge economy that can compete on the global market," said the government in February. "The vision for Rwanda - to be transformed into an information-rich knowledge based society and economy within 20 years."

Rwanda wants to become what it describes as the Dubai of east Africa, providing low-cost offshore banking, data entry and insurance services for small and medium sized businesses in Europe at a third of the cost, and exploiting the rarity of having both English and French as official languages by offering cheap simultaneous translation services.

The vision is born of an assessment as much of Rwanda's weaknesses as its strengths. "Rwanda has no natural resources. The only resources we have are human beings," says Albert Nsengiyumva, the head of NUR's computing centre. "The only way to promote the country is to provide skills for our people. We need to figure out how Rwanda, without natural resources, can provide some services so that we can improve our economy."

Landlocked, and with more than 90% of the population working on subsistence farms, Rwanda has hardly any geographic advantages. But if the internet can make geography irrelevant, that gives Rwanda a chance.

Claver Gatete, a senior adviser to president Paul Kagame, thinks ICT can also link the country's agrarian base to export markets. Whereas there is no competitive advantage in trying to export low-cost, high-bulk potatoes and bananas, Rwanda could find a market for cheap roses and carnations, for instance. The web can give the country more clout in tourism, by tempting visitors to Dar es Salaam and Mombasa to travel on through to Rwanda.

But in a country where six years ago a high proportion of educated and skilled people were killed or exiled, the digital divide is an ocean wide. So education is at the core of the government's ICT strategy.

Whereas in the development of the internet in many other countries education has often had to play catch-up with commerce, here it is in at the beginning. The government wants people to be both edu cated to use IT, and educated through IT. The potential shortcuts can be liberating, enabling students to access learning material, even top-quality lecturers, without them having to be imported at great expense.

"The internet means sharing, it means the cheapest way to communicate," says Nsengiyumva. "We need to train people, to sensitise people, how the internet can be useful in a country like Rwanda."

Britain is doing its bit, with Rwanda one of two lead pilots for the Imfundo project, which will be launched by Tony Blair next year, a government public/private scheme to help developing countries with IT.

Imfundo plans to support the development of the Rwanda Education Network (Rednet), linking education institutions with each other and to government offices. But its most ambitious scheme is to help launch an in-service training scheme for the country's 30,000 teachers, 25,000 of whom are untrained. It will develop courses through the Kigali Institute of Education, the main teacher training institution, which will be connected to 10 regional centres.

"We have got far apart from identifying the centres we are going to use," says Beatrice Mukabaranga, vice-rector of KIE . "We feel that if it succeeds it's going to bring dramatic changes."

The education minister, Emmanuel Mudidi, an enthusiast for decentralisation, sees it as a way of keeping people working within their regions, improving their skills and their earning power without having to rush to the cities. At NUR and KIST, there are already distance learning courses being conducted through the African Virtual University, a World Bank-inspired scheme, mainly delivered through video in Rwanda but with some internet links. But though the radio is the most effective form of communication in Rwanda, and will remain so for years, probably decades, the universities are not interested in running courses that way.

But the critical issue for the burgeoning IT industry in Rwanda is how to train people to run it, and how to keep them in the country once they are trained. NUR, KIST and Rwandatel, the state-owned telecommunications company which provides most of the internet access, each sent two people to the University of Maryland in the US recently. NUR also has links with Michigan State University. NUR's lead technician, Clemintine Nsanzineza, is going to Koblenz, Germany, to complete her training.

But this is expensive. Just as with the shortage of teachers, Nsengiyumva is looking towards the time when the stabilisers provided by foreign experts are gone. When he came here in 1997 to open the computer centre, he says, "people were never thinking about training technicians - they were all looking at just equipment. They now see that is a big mistake".

The scale of the vision can seem unlikely. The computers kept crashing at NUR in the summer because the dam producing electricity for the site was hit by a three-month drought. The government has very few computers, and many schools have none.

Merithe Nzaramba, head of the FAWE girls school, is very pleased with the four computers they were given by president Paul Kagame and is supportive of the ICT vision. But her first priority is more immediate: "You can't enjoy the internet if you don't have enough food for the students."

Some sympathetic British officials privately regard Rwanda's IT vision as worthwhile, but for less straightforward reasons. They reckon the Rwandan government has tapped into the worldwide craze for IT buzzwords; that it has calculated the most effective way to attract investment from abroad, from foreign governments and dot.coms with a conscience. Maybe - but does that matter? And Rwandans are far from pretending that IT is all the answer.

"When I am speaking with NGOs and so on, they say 'what are the government's priorities?'," says Claver Gatete. "And then you find that everything is a priority."

fields.headline: Melody Maker axed
fields.trailText: 3pm update: The death of Melody Maker, which has closed after 73 years, will be mourned as the end of an era, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The death of Melody Maker will be mourned as the end of an era.

The music title, which closed today, was always something of a little brother to IPC stablemate NME.

The 73-year-old music title never quite attained the iconic status of the NME, but at its height in the 70s it sold over 250,000 copies and was a must-read for anyone interested in rock and pop.

But with the rise of house music culture in the 90s, NME and Melody Maker both lost sales to a new generation of magazines including Mixmag, Muzik and Ministry.

Mike Soutar, managing director of IPC Music & Sport, said: "Market conditions in the indie rock music magazine sector are extremely tough, as evidenced only two weeks ago when Emap closed Select magazine.

"Over the last year Melody Maker's circulation has dipped to a point where we could also not sustain the costs of publishing."

Last year Melody Maker was reborn in a glossy monthly format and positioned as a rock/indie read. But this wasn't enough to save the title, which lost 21% of its sales in the six months to May.

IPC's decision to bite the bullet and fold the magazine into the more robust NME will be deeply regretted by many music journalists, but for more critical observers the paper's format was believed to be no longer sustainable.

Melody Maker and NME had their heyday in an age when young people cared about something called rock 'n' roll - an entity for a single constituency.

But the growing fragmentation of the music market has eaten away at the audiences of these once popular magazines.

IPC is thought to be set to reposition the NME as a more mainstream music title.

A number of jobs will be found for Melody Maker journalists on NME and NME.com.

webTitle: Hague to attack Lawrence report in call for more stop-and-search

fields.headline: Hague to attack Lawrence report in call for more stop-and-search
fields.standfirst: Full text of Hague's speech
fields.trailText: William Hague will today make a controversial intervention in the debate on law and order by attacking the Macpherson report into the killing of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence.
fields.body:
William Hague will today make a controversial intervention in the debate on law and order by attacking the Macpherson report into the killing of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

The Tory leader will call for a restoration of sweeping stop-and-search activities even though they were criticised in the report for being used disproportionately against black people.

In a Centre for Policy Studies lecture today, he will claim that Sir William Macpherson's report, with its allegations of institutional racism inside the Metropolitan police, has damaged the morale of the force and contributed to a fall in police numbers in London.

Mr Hague will attack the way he claims the Home Office used the report to bring about a reduction in stop-and-search powers in London.

The Tory leader is expected to say: "It is time to take on and defeat the liberal elite who now want us to believe the police are all racist."

The Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens, has recently claimed that there is a crisis in his service, blaming the fall in police numbers and the "self-inflicted" wounds of the Lawrence inquiry.

Sir William's criticism of the police for misusing stop-and-search powers was one of the most contentious aspects of his report.

Last night Sir William expressed sadness that Mr Hague had chosen to target the report and rejected any suggestion that it had been responsible for damaging morale in the force. "To say two years after the report that police morale had been damaged is a condemnation not of the report but of the police," he said.

"If anyone bothered to read the report they would see that at no point did it recommend a reduction of proper stop-and-search. But of course we were critical of discriminatory stop-and-search. We still are."

Imran Khan, the Lawrence family's solicitor, said: "The problem has not been the report itself, but the failure of the police in implementing the recommendations."

webTitle: Lawrence report hit Met morale - government

fields.headline: Lawrence report hit Met morale - government
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence did have an impact on morale in the Metropolitan police force, Home Office minister Charles Clarke said today.
fields.body:
The Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence did have an impact on morale in the Metropolitan police force, Home Office minister Charles Clarke said today.

The Home Office was publishing the latest figures on the numbers of police in forces across England and Wales today.

While numbers have stabilised in many of the regions, the number of officers in Metropolitan force has continued to drop dramatically.

In the past six months, the number of officers in the Metropolitan Police fell by 1,241 - nearly 5%.

But there are just seven fewer officers across all of England and Wales than there were six months ago - while there was also an increase in the number of constables. Recruitment of ethnic minority officers was also up - most significantly in the Metropolitan Police, which was responsible for half of the 11% increase in ethnic recruitment.

However, a leaked internal report by Sir Herman Ouseley, advisor to the Metropolitan Police, suggests that racism is still rife in the force.

One of the Home Office's own studies, also published today, found that people from ethnic minority communities were put off joining the police because they anticipated that they would be isolated and subjected to racism. Many also expected to face a level of hostility from their own communities if they joined the police. Members of black and Asian groups sometimes themselves had negative attitudes towards ethnic minority officers, the study found.

Mr Clarke said pragmatic action was needed - which was also recommended by Sir Herman's report. The minister said: "There is a 10-year programme for making changes, like in the number of black police officers, and we are making progress."

Scotland Yard said Sir Herman's report had been welcomed and was "balanced".

Mr Clarke said both he and the home secretary, Jack Straw, acknowledged that the Macpherson report had had an impact on morale.

But he dismissed as "scurrilous political tactics" claims by the Conservative leader, William Hague, and the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, that a decline in stop-and-searches following the Macpherson report had led to a rise in street crime. Home Office research had shown there was no link between the two, he said. "I think there is no doubt there were issues of self-questioning about how the police was operating following the report. But throughout Sir Paul Condon, then Metropolitan commissioner, the home secretary and I in my humble way have reaffirmed the message that stop-and-search is an appropriate tactic for police to use and should be used to inhibit crime."

webTitle: Macpherson: what did Hague say when the report was launched?

fields.headline: Macpherson: what did Hague say when the report was launched?
fields.standfirst: Is William Hague consistent? Here is the extract from 24 February 1999 following the publication of the report.
fields.trailText: William Hague: Does the Prime Minister agree that every decent person in the country, regardless of politics, will wish to show  sympathy and support for the family of Stephen Lawrence, and will feel shame and disgust that his murderers have not been brought to justice? Does he also agree  that, if some good is to come out of that appalling crime, we must all learn the lessons of what went wrong and commit ourselves to build a nation in which every  citizen, regardless of colour or creed, is treated with justice and respect?
fields.body:
William Hague: Does the Prime Minister agree that every decent person in the country, regardless of politics, will wish to show sympathy and support for the family of Stephen Lawrence, and will feel shame and disgust that his murderers have not been brought to justice? Does he also agree that, if some good is to come out of that appalling crime, we must all learn the lessons of what went wrong and commit ourselves to build a nation in which every citizen, regardless of colour or creed, is treated with justice and respect?

The Prime Minister: I agree entirely with the right honourable gentleman's sentiments. It is also important today to recognise that the report and its findings should not lead us to conclusions about only the police service, or any other service in British society; the report is about the whole of British society and its public services. It is also about what we must all do - collectively, across the political parties - to make sure that those appalling events lead to an improvement in race relations throughout the country.

fields.headline: AOL Time Warner merger through
fields.trailText: 6.15pmAOL and Time Warner have finally got the green light to go ahead with their merger.
fields.body:
After almost a year since they first announced they were planning to merge, AOL and Time Warner have finally got the green light to go ahead with their merger.

The Federal Trade Commission voted unanimously to approve the £70bn merger after months of wrangling about finite detail.

As part of the pact, Time Warner has been forced to open its network to rival internet firms, although AOL is expected to get preferential treatment.

The approved deal will now be passed onto the Federal Communications Commission for final approval, although this is merely a technicality.

EU regulators cleared the link-up in October, in an equally protracted study of the merger.

The merged company, AOL Time Warner, is either No 1 or No 2 in every market it operates in.

AOL Time Warner said it expected to close the combination by the end of December or in the early days of 2001.

webTitle: Sunday Business news editor mulls position

fields.headline: Sunday Business news editor mulls position
fields.trailText:
2pm: Sunday Business, news editor Frank Kane is considering his position following the appointment of Nils Pratley as editor, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Dec 14: Pratley speaks out about Sunday Business move
Dec 13: Pratley to edit Sunday Business
fields.body:
Sunday Business news editor Frank Kane is "considering his position" following the appointment of Nils Pratley as the paper's new editor.

"I like Nils. He's a friend and I taught him a lot about Sunday Business. But I applied for the job and I'm not sure I want to work for him," Mr Kane told MediaGuardian.co.uk.

Meanwhile, deputy editor Richard Northedge denied reports that he was planning to resign from the paper.

He said: "I'm very happy here and I've no intention of going."

The appointment yesterday of Mr Pratley has ended weeks of speculation after editor Jeff Randall announced he was joining the BBC as its new business editor.

Mr Kane and Mr Northedge were thought to have been recommended by Mr Randall. Other names in the frame included former Observer editor Jonathan Fenby and the Times's business editor, Patience Wheatcroft.

Mr Northedge said journalists at Sunday Business welcomed the appointment of Mr Pratley, who worked at the paper for two years before leaving to join doomed financial news site thestreet.co.uk.

He said: "Nils is a good story-getter, a good stock-picker. He's young and he's got a lot of ebusiness experience, which will be really good for the paper."

But insiders said they feared that Mr Pratley may lack the clout of Mr Randall in standing up to editor-in-chief Andrew Neil.

One said "Jeff [Randall] has been great at keeping Andrew [Neil] at arm's length. I think Nils will have more trouble."

Mr Pratley worked for Sunday Business since its relaunch in 1998, before joining financial news site thestreet.co.uk, which closed last month.

webTitle: DMG Radio wins Melbourne FM licence

fields.headline: DMG Radio wins Melbourne FM licence
fields.trailText:
1.45pm DMG Radio has won the FM licence for Melbourne consolidating GWR's position in Australia, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Dec 14: Daily Mail owner braced for tough times ahead
fields.body:
DMG Radio has paid £26m for the FM licence covering Melbourne in Australia.

The new licence will start broadcasting in the next 12 months.

DMG Radio was once one of the larger operations in the Daily Mail & General Trust group, which sold its UK, Hungarian and Sydney radio stations to GWR earlier this year.

GWR has a 25% stake in what remains of the radio assets of the Daily Mail's parent group, the Daily Mail & General Trust.

DMG Radio operates another 57 commercial radio stations in Australia.

GWR Group chief executive Ralph Bernard said that the win gave GWR a "strong presence in Australia's two major cities whilst further consolidating our excellent position in the total Australian market".

fields.headline: Spielberg's dinosaurs devour BBC competition
fields.trailText: The UK premiere of Steven Spielberg's The Lost World: Jurassic Park secured a respectable 8.5m viewers for ITV, helping it to a comfortable peak-time victory over the BBC, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The UK premiere of Steven Spielberg's The Lost World: Jurassic Park secured a respectable 8.5m viewers for ITV, helping it to a comfortable peak-time victory over the BBC.

Earlier in the evening, ITV's Emmerdale pulled in 10.7m viewers, while Coronation Street proved the star of the night with ratings of 13.9m.

But BBC1 gave ITV a run for its money at 10pm, as viewers switched over to BBC News to get the latest on the US elections.

By 10.15pm, ITV's figures had dropped to 6.6m while the BBC had 5.6m viewers.

The BBC proved the main beneficiary of Al Gore's decision to concede the US presidency, with BBC1's early evening news drawing nearly 7m viewers to give it a 33% share.

BBC2's Newsnight nearly doubled its usual viewing figures when 1.4m people tuned in to watch the show at 11.30pm.

ITV's Nightly News attracted 2.5m viewers, but lost out to the lure of the Eddie Murphy vehicle Boomerang on BBC1.

Elsewhere, The Weakest Link continues to perform well for BBC2, picking up 4.3m viewers at the difficult time of 5.15pm to give it a 26% share - higher than any of the other channels.

webTitle: Minimum wage lessons the government should heed

fields.headline: Minimum wage lessons the government should heed
fields.standfirst: The value of the minimum wage could be at the mercy of the whims of the political process, warns Sanjiv Sachdev
fields.trailText: The value of the minimum wage could be at the mercy of the whims of the political process, warns Sanjiv Sachdev
fields.body:
The Guardian recently reported that the minimum wage is likely to rise to £4 an hour. It is no coincidence that this is announced in the run-up to the general election. Currently, for adult workers it is £3.70 an hour and £3.20 for 18- to 21-year-olds. But nearly as important as the level of the minimum wage is the means by which it is raised - its uprating.

The issue is not new. Indexation of national minimum wages was a feature of the first minimum wages in Australia and New Zealand in 1914. But it is a neglected matter today, ignored by an opposition instinctively hostile to the minimum wage and quietly side-stepped by a government anxious not to alienate new found friends in business. However, without an uprating mechanism, the value of the minimum wage will be at the mercy of the whims of the political process.

Between 1985 and the 1997 general election, the Labour party had an automatic uprating mechanism for the minimum wage, based on the growth of male earnings. By 1997 this was dropped, being seen as too "rigid". It would instead be set by a Low Pay Commission.

Following parliamentary backbench and trade union disquiet at the current unsatisfactory ad hoc method of raising the minimum wage (it rose by 10p in October) the government has agreed to a "regular" review, but stopped short of an annual uprating as prevails in most European countries.

The government would do well to heed the example of US minimum wage when examining uprating. The USA has had a federal minimum wage since 1938. There is no automatic mechanism for increasing it; any increase requires a bill to be passed by Congress and signed into law by the president. Increases are infrequent.

The lack of an adequate uprating mechanism has severely diminished its value. As a percentage of average annual hourly wages, from a peak of 56.1% in 1968, it had fallen to 42.3% by 1997. This decline contributed to growing income inequality. The electoral cycle is a more important factor in any increase than the needs of working families. The working poor dependent on minimum wages have their income held captive to the whims of the political process.

Robert Reich, a former US secretary of labor, said: "Politicians don't want the minimum wage to be indexed because they like to fight over it. Democrats want to show their constituents, like labor, how hard they fight to raise the minimum wage. Republicans want to show their constituents, like small business, how hard they fight to prevent it from rising too much." As the election approaches, a similar argument may apply on this side of the Atlantic.

Moreover, the "shock" of irregular minimum wage increases, is greater than under a more gradual indexing approach as a significant hike is needed to compensate for the erosion in its value over several years. The US increases of 1990/91, though staged, were a 27% rise.

The virtue of an adequate uprating mechanism is that it should be reasonably predictable, enabling employers to anticipate and plan ahead. Without it, low-paying firms, already subject to significant instability, could be subject to greater uncertainty still. Indeed, an adequate uprating mechanism would encourage stability, certainty and long termism, virtues that the Chancellor has sought in his economic policy.

The nature of the uprating mechanism is also important. Tying minimum wage rates to increases in the cost of living defeats the very purpose of indexing the wage floor - to protect the earnings of low-paid workers not only from inflation but also in relation to more highly paid workers.

The French minimum wage, the "salarie minimum interprofessionnel de croissance" (SMIC), has an approach that is both flexible and more reliable than that of the US. There is a three-fold process of uprating: the minimum wage must rise with prices and with at least half the increase in the real value of average earnings, with provision for an additional annual increase to be made by decree.

The effect of this, as noted by the OECD, is that, while in most European countries the value of minimum wages relative to earnings has declined over time, in France "it has been relatively stable". The SMIC, which is partially automatic, is rendered adequate by occasional boosts from its non-automatic element, while retaining the flexibility absent from other formulas.

The issue of uprating will need addressing soon. The government should look across the Channel rather than the Atlantic for advice. The case for an adequate mechanism that maintains the value of the minimum wage, as the French approach does, is a strong one, as it avoids the pitfalls of other methods.

If Labour wins the next general election, there is potential for a new political consensus around an uprating mechanism that an future Conservative government, especially as it now accepts the principle of the minimum wage, might find hard to break. Instead, it could become part of the day-to-day landscape of life, uncontroversial and widely accepted. For low-paid workers this would be a welcome change.

 Sanjiv Sachdev is a senior lecturer in human resource management at Kingston University

webTitle: Bush must keep an eye on Putin

fields.headline: It takes a hawk to know one
fields.standfirst:
While Russian leader Putin seems intent on antagonising the US, reports Simon Tisdall, George Bush will have to stay one jump ahead

Special report: US election
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: While Russian leader Putin seems intent on antagonising the US, reports Simon Tisdall, George Bush will have to stay one jump ahead.
fields.body:
When Russian jet fighters swooped down over the US aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk in the Sea of Japan recently, the American crew did not see them coming until it was far too late.

Although the Pentagon later insisted the Russian planes had been picked up on the ship's radar, it was clear the Kitty Hawk had been caught by surprise. If the Russian pilots had harboured hostile intent, the carrier would have been sunk, figuratively if not literally.

The incident was one of several reminders in recent weeks that for all America's enormous complacency about its status as the world's sole superpower, its former Cold War rival can still present a challenge.

And that challenge is growing rapidly on a wide range of fronts.

There is general agreement in Washington that since President Boris Yeltsin stood down last March, US-Russian relations have been on the slide.

Like many others in the West, CIA analysts did not know what to make of the slightly sinister figure of Vladimir Putin, the ex-KGB officer who took charge in Moscow.

Perceptions were coloured by Mr Putin's brutal prosecution of the war against Chechen separatists while prime minister; and by assumptions that as president, he would focus on domestic issues.

Washington found in Mr Yeltsin a biddable partner. But while still stressing the importance of good relations with the West, the much younger and more energetic Mr Putin, aged 48, is increasingly taking on the US around the world.

Since becoming president Mr Putin has recommenced arms sales to Iran, which Mr Yeltsin had agreed to withhold under US pressure. He has been assiduously rebuilding commercial links with America's great foes, Iraq, helping it to develop its oilfields in defiance of UN sanctions. And he has intervened in the US-led Middle East peace process, recently hosting Yasser Arafat in Moscow and courting Arab opinion.

In Asia, Mr Putin caught the US by surprise last summer with a fraternal visit to the "rogue state" of North Korea. The alleged threat posed by Pyongyang is one of the principal justifications for America's development of its controversial national missile defence (NMD) system.

The Russian leader is also presiding over a big increase in military and weapons exports to China, identified by President-elect George W Bush as the biggest potential 21st century threat to American security.

By his visit to India last autumn, where he again signed lucrative arms export deals, Mr Putin directly challenged American attempts to cement ties with Delhi that began with trip there by President Bill Clinton last spring. During the Cold War, India sided with Moscow.

Mr Putin is clearly trying to revive those links now; while America has "lost" its former South Asian client, Pakistan, with the arrival last year of an obdurate and inflexible military government in Islamabad.

Elsewhere, Mr Putin has been seeking to reassert Russian commercial, investment and political links in other former Soviet "client states" like Angola. At the same time, he seems intent on charming key US allies like Britain.

Only two weeks ago, Tony Blair was enjoying drinks with his "friend" Vlad in a Moscow bierkeller. Mr Blair is clearly very impressed with his new pal - but is possibly being a little naïve. To cap it all, Mr Putin is today visiting Cuba, on America's southern flank, with the ostensible objective of re-establishing trade and business links. But he knows the symbolism of this renewal of Russian friendship with Fidel Castro after a gap of 11 years will not be lost on Washington. This new assertiveness in Russian foreign and security policy requires urgent attention by Mr Bush. But Washington is not lacking a few aces of its own.

Mr Putin fears a NMD deployment, for example. He knows it could totally undermine Russia's security. But he also knows he cannot afford to match it, either financially or technically. Instead, he has offered to make further, deep cuts in Russia's strategic nuclear arsenal - but only if an acceptable deal can be reached on NMD.

Washington has the whip hand here. It knows Russia can barely afford to maintain its existing rockets, let alone build new ones to protect against NMD.

The Americans also know that Russia needs its help in dealing with growing destabilisation in central Asia, stemming from the terrorist bases and hardline Islamic tenets of the Taliban regime in Afghanistan.

Russia and the US have been discussing shared operations to fight terrorism of the sort that was responsible for the recent attack on the USS Cole in Yemen.

General Henry Shelton, chairman of the US joint chiefs of staff, signed a deal to create a joint working group during a visit to Moscow this week. Some analysts believe this could be a prelude to renewed US military attacks on Afghanistan - with Russia's tacit blessing.

Although Russia and the US fell out over the West's bombing of Serbia and Kosovo last year, and while Russia continues to oppose the eastern expansion of Nato, Washington also figures that the Russians probably want to normalise relations with the Western Alliance.

Moscow knows full well, after all, that the Warsaw Pact is no more. Bridge-building talks will take place at Nato's HQ in Brussels today.

Most of all, Washington calculates, Moscow still needs IMF, World Bank and private sector western loans and capital investment if Russia's still dire economic situation is to improve. There is much room for leverage in this area - although it may diminish as Mr Putin's global search for trade, exports and business proceeds.

It is clear that Mr Bush and his new administration will have to keep a closer eye on Mr Putin in future. Like the crew of the Kitty Hawk, they need a much sharper lookout.

Although Russia and the US fell out over the West's bombing of Serbia and Kosovo last year, and while Russia continues to oppose the eastern expansion of Nato, Washington also figures that the Russians probably want to normalise relations with the Western Alliance. Moscow knows full well, after all, that the Warsaw Pact is no more. Bridge-building talks will take place at Nato's HQ in Brussels today. Most of all, Washington calculates, Moscow still needs IMF, World Bank and private sector western loans and capital investment if Russia's still dire economic situation is to improve. There is much room for leverage in this area - although it may diminish as Mr Putin's global search for trade, exports and business proceeds. It is clear that Mr Bush and his new administration will have to keep a closer eye on Mr Putin in future. Like the crew of the Kitty Hawk, they need a much sharper lookout. fields.headline: Davies takes BBC vice-chairman role
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: New Labour's favourite economist, Gavyn Davies, has been appointed BBC vice-chairman, writes Jason Deans.
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
New Labour's favourite economist, Gavyn Davies, has been appointed as the BBC's new vice-chairman, in a move bound to stir up a new row about the corporation's political independence.

One of chancellor Gordon Brown's closest confidants, he will take over from Baroness Young in January.

The appointment of Mr Davies, 50, who is chief international economist at leading investment bank Goldman Sachs, was welcomed by the BBC.

He will take on the number two position on the board of governors, under chairman Sir Christopher Bland.

Last year Mr Davies conducted an investigation into the corporation's finances as part of a government review of the BBC.

His report recommended the continuation of the licence fee. However, Mr Davies' controversial proposal to introduce a temporary digital TV licence was slammed as a new Labour "poll tax" and was ultimately rejected by the government.

One source at the BBC said: "The way in which he grasped the complexity of the BBC impressed and inspired us all. He will be a real asset."

Sir Christopher Bland said: "I am delighted with the appointment of Gavyn Davies as vice-chairman. He is a strong supporter of the BBC and has a deep understanding of and belief in the value of public service broadcasting in the digital age.

"His economic, business and broadcasting expertise will make him a valuable member of the board of governors."

Mr Davies said: "I very much look forward to taking up this appointment. The BBC plays a vital role in the culture of our nation and in supporting our democracy.

"I am excited at the prospect of helping to sustain the BBC's impact and creativity in the future."

Baroness Young announced in August that she was stepping down from the post after two years to become chief executive of the Environment Agency.

Mr Davies is regarded as part of the New Labour inner circle and is one of the most successful economists in the City, recently pocketing £15m in share options.

He is married to Sue Nye, Mr Brown's personal assistant

fields.headline: Davies job 'no surprise' say Tories
fields.standfirst:
Dec 14: Davies named BBC vice-chairman
Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
1.45pm update: The Conservatives said it was "no surprise" Gavyn Davies had been named vice-chairman of the BBC but hoped he retains his zeal for reform.
Dec 14: Davies named BBC vice-chairman
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The Conservatives said political patronage meant it was "no surprise" that New Labour's favourite economist, Gavyn Davies, had been selected as vice-chairman of the BBC.

Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth said Mr Davies, a Goldman Sachs economist and author of last year's investigation into the BBC's finances, would be a tremenduous asset to the corporation as long as he retained his zeal for reform.

He said: "We always knew it was going to be a Labour appointment. The chairman was appointed by us and the fact it was somebody with links to Labour was entirely expected.

"Quite honestly, his qualifications are very good. There are very few people who know much about the BBC.

"The Davies report about the BBC was sharply critical. He looked at privatising resources and introducing private capital to the BBC. And he recommended that the national audit office have a role for the first time.

"The BBC didn't like this but it remains to be seens whether his zeal for reform will carry through."
