webTitle: Bush's tough choices over US treasury post

fields.headline: Bush's tough choices over US treasury post
fields.standfirst:
One of the most important jobs in US politics is still to be decided - that of US treasury secretary, writes Jane Martinson
Special report: US election
fields.trailText: One of the most important jobs in US politics is still to be decided - that of US treasury secretary, writes Jane Martinson
fields.body:
One of the most important jobs in US politics is still to be decided - that of US treasury secretary.

The economics job in George W Bush's cabinet will be one of the most challenging in Washington. It is also likely to prove one of the most difficult to fill.

Imagine the job advertisement: "Political bruiser needed to privatise social security and cut $1.3 trillion from American taxes. An ability to win support for such controversial policies from a deeply divided Washington would be much appreciated. The successful candidate must be well versed in the ways of business as well as finance; an extraordinary career in either and friends in both are necessary. In addition, he or she should be prepared for the challenges of a recession after a decade of unprecedented growth."

The last qualification is making Dubya's decision particularly difficult. America's economy, which has performed so spectacularly for his archenemy Bill, is slowing down. The signs are everywhere: thousands of car workers made redundant, internet companies going out of business quicker than you can say dot.com and rapacious lawyers (for whom the president has discovered a new regard) switching over to insolvency work in packs. Such evidence prompted the ever-cheerful Dick Cheney to remark that America "may well be on the front edge of a recession" last weekend.

Marshall Whittman, senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, says the appointment of a treasury secretary is a key one for a Bush. "One of the great frustrations for his father was that he never got the credit for the recovery. The son now really doesn't want to take the blame for the recession."

George W's decision has been made more difficult, however, by the lack of a true front runner for the job. Larry Lindsay, the avid supply-sider who has served as the Bush campaign's adviser on economic issues, was once the obvious choice. However, the former central bank governor and academic has recently been tipped for a job inside the White House rather than in the separate treasury department. His relatively weak links to Wall Street are seen by some Beltway observers as one of the reasons for this.

This is partly because of the success of Robert Rubin, the former co-head of the investment bank Goldman Sachs and Clinton's first treasury secretary. His handling of the Mexican peso crisis and partnership with Alan Greenspan, the revered head of the Federal Reserve Board, in managing the astonishing resurgence of the US economy made Rubin a tough act to follow. Larry Summers, the present incumbent, faced some objections to his succession even though he was Rubin's choice.

So who are the contenders for the top job? While George W has made much of his desire to increase diversity with his choice of a cabinet, there are no women or minorities on the list of those thought most likely to be the next treasury secretary. There have been a few Democrats touted, notably the incumbent Summers, but few believe that Bush will entrust such a tough job to a member of the Gore camp.

Most pundits believe a Wall Street insider will be chosen. The problem is that there are question marks over all the most likely contenders: Donald Marron, the head of PaineWebber, a US brokerage firm that was taken over by the Swiss bank UBS this summer; Walter Shipley, the retired chairman of Chase Manhattan; and John Hennessy, a former junior member of the Nixon administration who is now at Credit Suisse First Boston. While these men have been ardent fundraisers for Bush, they are not known for the sort of charm and pizzazz helpful for such a tough job. It is whispered that Dubya would not recognise them at a party.

Another choice could be Ted Forstmann, the New York billionaire financier. His liaison with Liz Hurley would provide a little glamour at least.

Yesterday, the Bush campaign team was trying to maintain a dignified silence on his cabinet "out of respect for the vice-president". But the choice of US treasury secretary, difficult though it is, is likely to be announced before Christmas. It would be fun to think that someone exciting will fall out of the cracker, but don't hold your breath.

webTitle: Cragnotti warns Eriksson ahead of Rome derby

fields.headline: Cragnotti warns Eriksson ahead of Rome derby
fields.trailText: Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti has accused his squad of "lacking belief" and warned Sven-Goran Eriksson that his team "have to win" Sunday night's Rome derby.
fields.body:
Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti has accused his squad of "lacking belief" and warned Sven-Goran Eriksson that his team "have to win" Sunday night's Rome derby.

On an impromptu visit to the Formello training ground following Lazio's humiliating 4-1 Italian Cup defeat at Udinese on Tuesday, Cragnotti left Eriksson and his players in no doubt of the importance of the match against Serie A leaders Roma.

"This is the most important derby since I became president. The match will be crucial for our season," he warned. "This is a period where things are not turning out the way they are supposed to. The players are too nervous in their belief of being a great team."

"For us, this represents a fundamental step toward the Scudetto," he continued. "It's not our last chance, although it is true that Lazio have to win while, for Roma, it doesn't really matter."

Cragnotti also pledged to spend even more of his millions to improve his squad - despite already splashing out more than £65m in the Hernan Crespo (£35m), Claudio Lopez (£17.5m), Angelo Peruzzi (£10.7m), and Emanuele Pesaresi (£4m). Reports in this morning's papers have once again linked Lazio with a £4m bid for West Ham striker Paolo di Canio.

Meanwhile, both Lazio and Roma will be able to choose from near-full strength squads for Sunday's derby.

Lazio are missing long-term absentee Claudio Lopez, but Juan Sebastian Veron (inflamed left leg) and Marcelo Salas (sore hip) are both expected to be fit.

Roma, who returned to training yesterday after being given two days off by coach Fabio Capello, have no injury worries ahead of the game.

"We are well mentally and physically," striker Vicenzo Montella told a press conference. "But the derby is always a different contest, it does not have logic and it is all living. We will face this game with the maximum attention."

webTitle: Livingstone unveils plans to fight unemployment

fields.headline: Livingstone unveils plans to fight unemployment
fields.trailText: Getting the unemployed back into work is at the heart of a new package of measures designed to kick-start the capital's economy, London mayor Ken Livingstone announced today.
fields.body:
Getting the unemployed back into work must be at the centre of a new package of measures designed to kick-start the capital's economy, London mayor Ken Livingstone said today.

A nine-point charter, dubbed a "jobs blueprint for London" and focusing on cutting unemployment, improving business competitiveness and supporting widespread regeneration, forms the backbone of the London Development Agency's (LDA) draft development strategy.

Mr Livingstone said he aimed to bridge the gap between London's central business district and the communities along its edge where high unemployment and exclusion thrive.

"Our task is as much social as it is economic. We need to ensure that our people can share in the wealth of London's centre," he added.

Priorities in the document include new local learning centres in the capital's poorest communities and targets for getting their residents back into work.

Efforts to strengthen London's capacity to deliver services by building a strong infrastructure are also suggested. This will involve establishing urban regeneration companies designed to focus regeneration efforts in parts of the capital.

Maintaining international competitiveness and improving transport, schooling and housing markets are among the key challenges the LDA sets out.

The strategy is now out for public consultation until February 28. A final version will be published next spring.

webTitle: Sir David Frost puts interviews online

fields.headline: Sir David Frost cashes in by putting interviews online
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Sir David Frost is set to make millions with a new internet venture using his famous collection of interviews, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Sir David Frost is set to make millions with a new internet venture designed to cash in on his formidable collection of interviews with stars and worlds leaders.

In a joint venture with internet firm Newsplayer, viewers will be able to dial up hundreds of Sir David's interviews, including his historic clash with President Nixon in which the disgraced premier accepted some responsibility for corruption for the first time.

But the bonus, particularly for amateur and professional historians, will be the facility to view all uncut material.

The Nixon encounter, for example, lasted almost 29 hours.

Sir David said today: "To have made it available in this way is very exciting. I remember back in the 1960s people used to see that TV is a transitory thing. But deals like this mean that the interviews will be around as long as books."

He said the service would be aimed at the "home consumer, schools and universities".

The veteran TV presenter will take 50% of all revenues generated from the online archive, underlining his long-standing business acumen.

Unlike some other presenters, Sir David has managed to retain the rights to his interviews.

"One of the reasons that I got into the business in the first place was to make things happen. You can make things happen more if you do it yourself," he told MediaGuardian.co.uk.

Footage includes interviews with six US presidents and an number of UK prime ministers. Other famous faces include Microsoft founder Bill Gates and world leaders Yasser Arafat and Mikhail Gorbachev.

Sir David selected his post-Watergate grilling of President Nixon as the highlight of the collection. It drew a record global audience for a news interview.

"That interview ranks as the most important, and we had to take so many risks to get it," said Sir David.

Ever since he began his TV career in the 1960s, the world-famous journalist has kept hold of the rights to his shows through his Paradine production company.

Sir David has made millions over the years from TV production, film-making, book writing and other investments.

Newsplayer plans to put the clips on DVD and syndicate them to other websites and internet service providers.

Sir David, 61, rose to fame with the satirical 1960s BBC programme That Was The Week That Was, which drew regular complaints from offended politicians.

The Frost Report soon followed, and is best known for starting the careers of Ronnie Barker and Ronnie Corbett, aka The Two Ronnies, and John Cleese.

He went on to become a journalistic star on both sides of the Atlantic, attracting the rich, famous and powerful to the interview sofa.

Breakfast with Frost first went on air in January 1993, although political commentators have slated the easy ride that politicians often got on the programme.

Sir David has made millions over the years from TV production, film-making, book writing and other investments. Newsplayer plans to put the clips on DVD and syndicate them to other websites and internet service providers. Sir David, 61, rose to fame with the satirical 1960s BBC programme That Was The Week That Was, which drew regular complaints from offended politicians. The Frost Report soon followed, and is best known for starting the careers of Ronnie Barker and Ronnie Corbett, aka The Two Ronnies, and John Cleese. He went on to become a journalistic star on both sides of the Atlantic, attracting the rich, famous and powerful to the interview sofa. Breakfast with Frost first went on air in January 1993, although political commentators have slated the easy ride that politicians often got on the programme.

fields.headline: What the US papers say
fields.standfirst:
After baying at the moon for more than five weeks, American newshounds now have a solid bone to chew. They make the most of it.
Special report: US election
fields.trailText: After baying at the moon for more than five weeks, American newshounds now have a solid bone to chew. They make the most of it, reports Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The Chicago Sun Times editorial headline crisply sums up: "Gore's time ran out; democracy wins". The leader-writer echoes the self-congratulation which has pervaded the election saga: "It's been said, and it's worth repeating, that we had a bitterly contested election that essentially ended in a tie, but there were no soldiers taking over the streets, no general or colonel assuming control of the country. Our differences were settled in a court of law according to the time-honored institutions, often-tested rules and governing traditions of our nation. Once again the Constitution, the collected wisdom of the Founders, has met the test of democracy."

The leader writer of the Minneapolis Star Tribune leaves little doubt about where the paper's heart lies: "Vice President Al Gore was magnificent Wednesday night. This man whom many deride for being wooden and pedantic was neither. He spoke with conviction, warmth and magnanimity. As he conceded the highest office in the land, an office he believes he won, he gave a masterful talk. Gov. George W. Bush gave an acceptable speech. He was gracious to Gore and to Democrats generally - pledging truly to reach across the chasm now separating the two parties in search of bipartisanship. But he went too far, at precisely the wrong time, in promoting his own policy agenda. In doing so, he misjudged the moment."

In its distinctive staccato style, the tabloid New York Post wishes the president-elect well in setting up his new administration: "Bush will be refining his agenda, and picking his staff, in the shortest timespan of any incoming president in decades, now that the transition period has been sliced in half. But he mustn't let that serve as an excuse for delay; from the moment he takes office on Jan. 20, the nation - and the world - will be looking for signs of stability and competence at the helm of the planet's sole superpower."

The Palm Beach Post, which has been at the heart of the Florida recount battle, is still sniffy about the intervention of the US Supreme Court: " It remains our opinion that the Supreme Court never should have taken this case. The state did not run an illegal election or set out to disenfranchise a group of voters. By intervening, the court appeared to place politics over the law.....Had the statewide recount gone ahead, either side would have reason to complain. This has been an imperfect election. But this imperfect election should have ended with an examination of ballots, not a court ruling."

The San Francisco Chronicle agrees: "The growing group of Americans who were craving finality at all costs could go to bed satisfied last night. But for the rest of us, the few days required for a more thorough recount of the Florida vote would have been justified to defend the principle that every vote counts."

The most magisterial of US papers, the Boston Globe, asks the inevitable question "What now?" Its leader writer rises to the challenge: "This election is not good news for the poor, sick, marginalized, or anyone who depends on government to be a protective force in their lives. Even in its most generous interpretation, the message of the voters was muddle-of-the-road. With a contentious Congress and no public mandate, the Bush team may be tempted to operate under the political radar, pressing an agenda less through Congress and more through appointments, regulations, and executive orders. Normally, these receive little scrutiny and will require a vigilant public."

The Houston Chronicle, which has stoutly backed Bush throughout the campaign and its aftermath, suggests that the question "who really won?" should now be laid to rest. Its leader writer offers an extraordinary analysis: "Human error and voting machinery too imprecise to cope with a close election prevent the exact number of votes cast for Bush and Gore from ever being known. Subsequent counting and analysis will not produce figures more accurate than those certified by Florida's secretary of state.

"However, Bush can make a strong argument that he won by every measure... Bush won all of the counts and recounts made in Florida and clung to a slender lead in those that were halted. Bush enjoyed decisive political support in Florida's Legislature and executive branch, and in the end he won every court case, either at the trial level or before the highest appellate bench."

So that's all right then.

Talk about it
What do you think?

fields.headline: What Scotland is saying
fields.trailText: What Scotland is saying about the Our National Health plan
fields.body:
Unison Scotland
Unison's Scottish Organiser for Health, Jim Devine said: "This document is the start of the re-nationalisation of the Scottish health service. The internal market the Tories introduced brought nothing but conflict, confusion and competition to the National Health Service in Scotland. This is now at an end. The plan sends a powerful message, that co-operation, co-ordination and comprehensive healthcare is the new priority of this administration."

Scottish Association of Health Councils
Andy Carver, research manager with the Scottish Association of Health Councils, said: "I'm pleased to say we haven't been abolished. We support the new investment in information for patients. Scotland has been lagging behind what has being going on in England and this will redress the imbalance. The commitment to national standards is both necessary and welcome - now evidence about good quality care will have to be implemented in all areas."

Scottish National Party
Shadow Health Minister Nicola Sturgeon MSP said the government's previous pledge on reducing waiting lists had been omitted from the plan:

"They have already failed to deliver on their key pledge to reduce waiting lists and even worse they have omitted any mention of this pledge in the health plan. It appears therefore the best way to deal with a pledge that they have problems achieving is to remove it from any future publications."

Scottish Conservative & Unionist Party
Scots Tory health spokesperson Mary Scanlon MSP accused health minister Susan Deacon of "rehashing the same old tired, discredited ideas".

She said: "I agree with Susan Deacon that the key is implementation. In that case I have to ask the minister why she has produced enough glossy brochures, plans, strategies, reviews consultations and focus group documents to fill an entire library.

"And we can look forward to a cancer plan and a heart disease strategy next year. We wait years for action on top clinical priorities, and the best they can think of to do is publish another document."

Scottish NHS Confederation
Scottish NHS Confederation chairman Caroline Thomson said she would adopt a "wait and see" approach to the announcement that NHS trusts and boards are to be amalgamated into unified boards.

She said: "Having several NHS organisations in each area has been confusing for many people. The introduction of unified boards could cause concern that decision making will be too far removed from patients.

"However, we recognise the potential advantage of having a single NHS body in each area with which patients can more readily identify and on which they can have a more direct impact."

Scottish Royal Colleges
Professor Jim Petrie, chairman of the Scottish Royal College, welcomed the "strong strategic direction" of the plan but warned that immediate action must be taken on workforce planning.

He said: "Ensuring quality of care across all aspects of the health service will have resource implications for the NHS in Scotland and we will have to find ways of ensuring that staffing levels are of sufficient strength to deliver these objectives whilst ensuring that staff are given time to update their skills and to continue their professional involvement."

BMA Scotland public health committee
Dr Charles Saunders, chairman of the BMA Scotland's public health committee said: "Everybody working in the NHS in Scotland will welcome the minister's commitment to reducing the burden imposed by hospital acquired infection. At any one time, one in 10 of all hospital patients suffer from an infection they picked up while in hospital. The consequences of these infections range from a few extra days in hospital to premature death. Up to a third are entirely preventable"

Royal Pharmaceutical Society In Scotland
Alison Strath , chairman of the Royal Pharmaceutical Society in Scotland, said she was "delighted" at the announcement of a pharmacy strategy in the plan.

"What I'm pleased about is the inclusive nature of the announcement and the recognition that the 'NHS family' is not just about doctors and nurses. Statistics tell us that 17% of all admissions to hospital are related to adverse drug reactions. In the Tayside region alone, there are reckoned to be 7,000 tonnes of wasted medicines each year. Through an increased involvement in repeat prescribing, medicine monitoring and reviews, pharmacists can play a key role in improving the quality of the patient journey through the NHS in Scotland."

The Royal College of Nursing
James Kennedy, RCN Scottish board secretary warned that it was important that the plan's pledges and promises "become reality," and that nurses were given a key role in implementing it.

"Nurses provide around 80% of direct patient care so it is vital that the voice of nurses is heard on these new boards.

"No one would contemplate running a school without listening to teachers How can we have a health service that puts the views of directors of finance above directors of nursing?"

He praised the plan's emphasis on family-friendly policies and said it would help with nurse retention, and even attract people back to nursing.

Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (COSLA)
Rita Miller, COSLA's health spokesperson, was underwhelmed by the lack of emphasis on local government's role in partnership working with the NHS.

"We feel the references to local government are neither strong enough nor specific enough to make us feel that we are equal partners in what must clearly be a joint agenda.

"It is disappointing that, while there are significant proposals for councils - particularly developing them as public health organisations and the inclusion of a local government voice on the new NHS boards - we do not believe that the importance of local government has, as yet, been fully recognised."

Action on Smoking and Health
Maureen Moore, Chief Executive of ASH Scotland, welcomed the plan's commitment to consult on offering nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) via GP prescription as "a great step forward".

She said: "Making NRT freely available on prescription is a positive and cost-effective public health measure. Tobacco use kills one in five Scots every year yet, historically, little has been done to help the majority of smokers who wish to quit.

"Many smokers have been deterred from using NRT because of the high cost ,so this is a great step forward. NRT is a safe and effective way of helping smokers to quit and overcome their addiction to nicotine."

BMA Scotland
The BMA warned that the "aspirational" spirit of the proposals needed to be met with "concerted effort" from all professions to implement the plan.

Dr John Garner, chairman of the Scottish Council of the BMA, said:"The health plan delivers a clear set of goals for improving healthcare in Scotland and sets out detailed aspirations that are shared by all. The task ahead is to turn the plan's rhetoric into reality and develop practical improvements in patient care."

webTitle: Maria de Medeiros outrages countrymen with farcical film

fields.headline: Carry on revolting
fields.standfirst: Maria de Medeiros has outraged her countrymen with a farcical film about Portugal's 1974 revolution. It's all true, she tells  Geoffrey Macnab  - even the bit about tanks waiting at traffic lights
fields.trailText: You'll remember Maria de Medeiros as Bruce Willis's girlfriend in Pulp Fiction. Or as Anaïs Nin, coiled around Uma Thurman in Henry and June. She has been in dozens of other films - French, British, Canadian, Spanish and Portuguese. And earlier this year, she directed her first feature, April Captains, Portugal's most expensive film ever, which chronicles the defining moment in recent Portuguese history: the April Revolution of 1974.
fields.body:
You'll remember Maria de Medeiros as Bruce Willis's girlfriend in Pulp Fiction. Or as Anaïs Nin, coiled around Uma Thurman in Henry and June. She has been in dozens of other films - French, British, Canadian, Spanish and Portuguese. And earlier this year, she directed her first feature, April Captains, Portugal's most expensive film ever, which chronicles the defining moment in recent Portuguese history: the April Revolution of 1974.

De Medeiros's crime, for certain Portuguese critics, is to have treated seismic political events in a light-hearted and even flippant way. The actress-director is dismissive of such accusations. She argues that the revolution was every bit as chaotic as she portrays it: the mutineering soldiers really didn't know whether to stop their tanks at the traffic lights; they really did manage to lock themselves out of the car that had all the weapons in it; and, en route to topple dictator Marcello Caetano, they really were harassed by gays.

All this, de Medeiros insists, is a matter of historical record. It was written about by the army leaders behind the coup. She interviewed them and they confirmed the old stories. "I would be untrue to this revolution if I didn't show the funny aspect of it," de Medeiros says.

April Captains thus features surreal scenes of tanks trundling down busy Lisbon roads, a painfully comic episode in which hapless soldiers take over a radio station ("It's a coup d'etat - can we come in?"), shots of couples sneaking off to make love in the tanks, and a sequence in which the two sides (the fascists and the mutineers) try to work out how to bargain with one another. ("Who's in charge?" an old officer asks. "We all are," the revolutionaries answer.) At times, it's as if we're watching a Carry On version of a Costa-Gavras or Pontecorvo film.

The coup was indeed a revolution with a difference. Sparked off by the broadcasting of an outlawed song, Grandola, on the radio, it was lead by young army officers, most of them barely into their 30s. They managed the unlikely feat of toppling a dictatorship that had ruled Portugal for 48 years, without killing a single person. (The only casualties were three men shot by the detested Pide secret police.)

Once the revolution was over, the "captains" faded back into obscurity. Some became entangled with the new political parties that sprang up, but most, de Medeiros insists, were "incorruptible". They stayed in the army, where they conspicuously failed to have spectacular careers.

Today the Portuguese don't like to talk about their revolution. "I think we can be proud about it," de Medeiros says. "It was an act full of respect and generosity for the people. The soldiers didn't shoot. But, for some reason, it's a kind of taboo. I think it's an oedipal complex. The civilian class was put in charge by these guys [in the army] and they prefer to forget who gave them that power."

De Medeiros was nine when the revolution happened, living in exile with her parents in Austria. Her mother was a political journalist, her father a composer. "I had very young parents. I saw them so happy - literally jumping around the living room. I understood something really important had happened." The family moved back to Portugal immediately. They no longer had a home and so took up residence in a Lisbon hotel along with hundreds of other returning exiles: "I remember that in the bar of that hotel the constitution was being written."

The immediate aftermath of the revolution was exhilarating. Citizens stuffed the barrels of the soldiers' weapons with flowers. Everybody began to discuss politics. "People of my generation in Portugal fell into the magic potion of political ideas," de Medeiros recalls. "What was very funny about this revolution was that it did not bring wealth to the Portuguese. But it brought language, ideas. You'd go to the fish market and all the women who were selling fish would call each other fascist, communist. It looked like a political meeting and it was just people talking. I remember my parents quarrelling. They would talk as if they were against each other's ideas about Trotsky, but it was just a couple arguing."

Inevitably, the excitement died down and the Portuguese forgot that there had ever been a revolution. De Medeiros was one of the few to remember. She was 14 when she was first introduced to Salgueiro Maia, the young captain who had forced Caetano (Antonio de Oliveira Salazar's replacement) to resign. "Then, when I was 21, I decided there was a movie to be made. I went to see him at the barracks. He was a very shy man. I was very shy, too. It was funny meeting him there. At that time, there were no girls allowed in the barracks. He was so generous. He immediately gave me all the information that he had, including papers that had not been published."

Maia, who died of cancer in 1992, supported the project, but was not the type to seek the limelight."I am certain of at least one thing: no one can do everything. I recognise my incompetence in politics," he commented when politicians tried to talk him into joining the government. He probably would not have enjoyed seeing himself played on screen by Italian heart-throb Steffano Accorsi.

Ironically, the Portuguese army had no objections to the film, but the intelligentsia did. April Captains has provoked fierce arguments in the Portuguese press. De Medeiros blames it on old-fashioned chauvinism. "The left-wing thinkers and intellectuals have been more misogynist with me than the army," she says, complaining about their "paternalistic, condescending" attitude toward her. "They can't accept that a young woman is able to think and they underestimate the intellectual work and study I might have done. They ask who is the man behind me."

Even without the support of the intellectuals, the film, which took 13 years to make, has been a huge hit in Portugal. Ninety-two-year- old Portuguese auteur Manoel de Oliveira, who has worked with de Medeiros in the past, gave it his seal of approval, as did many of the country's leading politicians. De Medeiros talks about screenings at which audiences stood up and joined in the revolutionary songs. Through out the 1990s, financiers and actors passed in and out of the frame. Javier Bardem, Spain's biggest star, was briefly attached to the project. At one stage, de Medeiros even tried (unsuccessfully) to co-opt British playwright Edward Bond into helping her write the screenplay. The film ended up being financed by a hodge-podge of European backers. Needless to say, no British distributor has shown much interest in acquiring it for the UK.

De Medeiros is now back in France, concentrating on her acting in various new European films. (Like Anaïs Nin, she suggests, she's a foreigner everywhere, with a bit of an accent in every language.) Yes, she gets criticised for not staying put in her homeland. "But I like to dream about Portugal and it's less easy when you are there."

She hopes, at least, that April Captains will have reminded the Portuguese that their freedom can't be taken for granted. "You have to cultivate it, and sometimes you don't realise you have lost it already. That was the message that the captains gave me. It's always easier to obey than to disobey - but we must keep in the corner of our mind a little voice saying we may have to disobey now_"

They stayed in the army, where they conspicuously failed to have spectacular careers. Today the Portuguese don't like to talk about their revolution. "I think we can be proud about it," de Medeiros says. "It was an act full of respect and generosity for the people. The soldiers didn't shoot. But, for some reason, it's a kind of taboo. I think it's an oedipal complex. The civilian class was put in charge by these guys [in the army] and they prefer to forget who gave them that power." De Medeiros was nine when the revolution happened, living in exile with her parents in Austria. Her mother was a political journalist, her father a composer. "I had very young parents. I saw them so happy - literally jumping around the living room. I understood something really important had happened." The family moved back to Portugal immediately. They no longer had a home and so took up residence in a Lisbon hotel along with hundreds of other returning exiles: "I remember that in the bar of that hotel the constitution was being written." The immediate aftermath of the revolution was exhilarating. Citizens stuffed the barrels of the soldiers' weapons with flowers. Everybody began to discuss politics. "People of my generation in Portugal fell into the magic potion of political ideas," de Medeiros recalls. "What was very funny about this revolution was that it did not bring wealth to the Portuguese. But it brought language, ideas. You'd go to the fish market and all the women who were selling fish would call each other fascist, communist. It looked like a political meeting and it was just people talking. I remember my parents quarrelling. They would talk as if they were against each other's ideas about Trotsky, but it was just a couple arguing." Inevitably, the excitement died down and the Portuguese forgot that there had ever been a revolution. De Medeiros was one of the few to remember. She was 14 when she was first introduced to Salgueiro Maia, the young captain who had forced Caetano (Antonio de Oliveira Salazar's replacement) to resign. "Then, when I was 21, I decided there was a movie to be made. I went to see him at the barracks. He was a very shy man. I was very shy, too. It was funny meeting him there. At that time, there were no girls allowed in the barracks. He was so generous. He immediately gave me all the information that he had, including papers that had not been published." Maia, who died of cancer in 1992, supported the project, but was not the type to seek the limelight."I am certain of at least one thing: no one can do everything. I recognise my incompetence in politics," he commented when politicians tried to talk him into joining the government. He probably would not have enjoyed seeing himself played on screen by Italian heart-throb Steffano Accorsi. Ironically, the Portuguese army had no objections to the film, but the intelligentsia did. April Captains has provoked fierce arguments in the Portuguese press. De Medeiros blames it on old-fashioned chauvinism. "The left-wing thinkers and intellectuals have been more misogynist with me than the army," she says, complaining about their "paternalistic, condescending" attitude toward her. "They can't accept that a young woman is able to think and they underestimate the intellectual work and study I might have done. They ask who is the man behind me." Even without the support of the intellectuals, the film, which took 13 years to make, has been a huge hit in Portugal. Ninety-two-year- old Portuguese auteur Manoel de Oliveira, who has worked with de Medeiros in the past, gave it his seal of approval, as did many of the country's leading politicians. De Medeiros talks about screenings at which audiences stood up and joined in the revolutionary songs. Through out the 1990s, financiers and actors passed in and out of the frame. Javier Bardem, Spain's biggest star, was briefly attached to the project. At one stage, de Medeiros even tried (unsuccessfully) to co-opt British playwright Edward Bond into helping her write the screenplay. The film ended up being financed by a hodge-podge of European backers. Needless to say, no British distributor has shown much interest in acquiring it for the UK. De Medeiros is now back in France, concentrating on her acting in various new European films. (Like Anaïs Nin, she suggests, she's a foreigner everywhere, with a bit of an accent in every language.) Yes, she gets criticised for not staying put in her homeland. "But I like to dream about Portugal and it's less easy when you are there." She hopes, at least, that April Captains will have reminded the Portuguese that their freedom can't be taken for granted. "You have to cultivate it, and sometimes you don't realise you have lost it already. That was the message that the captains gave me. It's always easier to obey than to disobey - but we must keep in the corner of our mind a little voice saying we may have to disobey now_"

webTitle: Millionaire backer Avesco posts huge profits

fields.headline: Avesco gets rich on Millionaire
fields.trailText: 12pm: Entertainment rights company Avesco has posted huge profits thanks to its stake in Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The runaway success of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? has helped the entertainment rights company Avesco to achieve a massive increase in profit.

Avesco has a 49% stake in Complete Communications, the company that owns the rights to the the hit quiz show, and owns Celador, the show's producer.

Avesco's net profits for the six months to September 30 totalled £2.4m, up from just £120,000 in the same period last year.

The rise is thanks largely to the success of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? abroad, with 35 countries now broadcasting their own versions of the show.

The company says the board game has also been selling strongly in the UK and the US, and a new computer game version has been introduced.

John Morton, Avesco chairman, said: "The results show our continued growth from all areas of the business and we are confident that the second half of the year will be successful."

Avesco said it expects profits to increase further in the second half of the financial year.

webTitle: Scottish NHS plan to abolish trusts

fields.headline: Scottish NHS plan to abolish trusts
fields.trailText: NHS trusts and health boards will be abolished as part of a series of measures contained in the Scottish NHS plan, published today. By Patrick Butler
fields.body:
NHS trusts and health boards will be abolished as part of a series of measures contained in the Scottish NHS plan, published today, which will effectively rebrand the health service in Scotland.

The plan will propose the merger of trusts and health authorities, putting an end to the internal market system introduced nearly a decade ago. It will also propose a number of initiatives that will, over time, make the Scottish NHS significantly different from its counterpart in England and Wales.

The initiatives are expected to include:

 Retaining local health councils as the local health services watchdog - the equivalent body in England and Wales, community health councils, were abolished in the English NHS plan.
 Cutting waiting times for heart treatment - one of Scotland's biggest public health problems - so that patients wait no longer than 12 weeks for tests or 24 weeks for surgery by 2002.
 Abolishing trusts and health boards, and creating in their place a single area body, called, for example, NHS Glasgow.
 The introduction of voluntary smart cards for patients containing details of their medical records.

The plan is the most important policy announcement to come out of the Scottish Executive this year, and is being seen as the first big test for new first minister Henry McLeish. It comes nearly five months after the publication of the NHS plan for England and Wales.

webTitle: Diagnosis good for Scottish NHS plan

fields.headline: Diagnosis good for Scottish NHS plan
fields.standfirst: The big surprise about the Scottish NHS plan is that there are to be no really big surprises - just steady progress in re-building a service that has been under-funded for years, writes Mark Irvine
fields.trailText: The big surprise about the Scottish NHS plan is that there are to be no really big surprises - just steady progress in re-building a service that has been under-funded for years, writes Mark Irvine
fields.body:
Scotland has a new health plan - and not before time, some would say. Scottish health minister Susan Deacon has taken six months to catch up with her counterpart in England and Wales, Alan Milburn. He set his stall out back in July in a joyous New Labour extravaganza, the prime minister well to the fore, with lashings of "what matters is what works" and a high-profile commitment to using the private hospitals to end the scourge of NHS waiting lists.

The Scottish launch was a more prosaic affair. Susan Deacon is a serious-minded politician; whiz-bang announcements are not her style. She did not rush into her policy announcement, emphasising Holyrood's ability to do things differently and at its own pace.

As ever, waiting list figures dominated the political backdrop. Labour has been in the stocks as they continued to rise sharply, jumping to 86,540 in September 2000 - an increase of 15% year on year. Waiting times also rose significantly. The Scottish National Party has had a field day deriding Labour's election pledges and its famous slogan that "things can only get better".

The health minister's job was to stop the rot. Labour needs to spread the good news about how Scotland will spend the extra £1.2 bn available to the NHS between 2001-2004. The big surprise is that there are to be no really big surprises, no flashy initiatives - just steady progress in re-building a service that has been under-funded and poorly managed for years.

There are new targets and pledges aplenty. Reduced waiting times will become the big priority, particularly for child, heart and cancer patients. But private hospitals will not have a special role in achieving this objective. Health councils are to remain as patient watchdogs so long as patients remain at the centre of their activities. National standards of care will apply across the country and a new 24-hour help line is to be introduced.

Less bureaucracy is a popular rallying cry and 28 NHS trusts will disappear in a small bonfire of the quangos. Their responsibilities will transfer to 15 existing health boards which will operate as strategic decision-making bodies for all services in a given area. No more internal markets, 100 fewer quango members, though arguably more remote decision making.

The central theme is a determination to develop a patient-led culture. Putting patients first has its own chapter in the Scottish plan. A greater emphasis is to be placed on patients having a real say in how treatment is delivered. A Mori poll on public attitudes towards the NHS found that 57% felt they had no or little influence over the service or its priorities, while 93% believed patients and their families should have influence. One hundred million pounds has been earmarked to emphasise customer care and develop best practice initiatives.

Ms Deacon has gone out of her way to produce a consensual plan that doesn't frighten too many horses. The strategy seems to have worked, since opposition parties are not challenging any of its key principles head on. Instead the opposition is sceptical about Labour's ability to deliver given its failure on reducing waiting lists. The proof, they say, will be in the eating.

In Scotland, the politics of the NHS have been reduced to efficient management. Everyone agrees on the diagnosis and treatment - administering the medicine is the difficult bit.

webTitle: Councils disappointed by lack of recognition

fields.headline: Councils disappointed by lack of recognition
fields.trailText: Scottish local authorities have voiced dismay that the NHS action plan has failed to recognise their key role in helping to improve public health. By David Mitchell
fields.body:
Scottish local authorities have voiced dismay that the NHS action plan has failed to recognise their key role in helping to improve public health.

Rita Miller, health spokesperson for the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (COSLA), claimed references to local government in the NHS plan were "neither strong enough, nor specific enough" to make councils feel equal partners in what was clearly a joint agenda.

"It is disappointing that, while there are significant proposals for councils - particularly developing them as public health organisations and the inclusion of a local government voice on the new NHS Boards - we do not believe that the importance of local government has, as yet, been fully recognised," she said.

Miller said the plan's aims were good ones and COSLA welcomed the focus on creating better opportunities, delivering social justice and making real improvements in the quality of people's lives.

"But a healthy Scotland cannot be delivered by the NHS alone so we welcome the emphasis on partnership and joined-up working led by local government with the NHS and other partners within the context of the community planning process," she said.

"Councils are responsible for the delivery of a wide range of services which impact directly on public health and well-being - from social care, housing, education and community safety to environmental health, transport, and leisure and recreation.

"The proposals for better health services in the community will make a real difference to people in our local areas. It is very important that we focus on improving health, not just treating illness, and that means there is a key role for local authorities and a need for the closest possible working between councils and the NHS."

Carole Wilkinson, vice president of the Association of Directors of Social Work, said she was disappointed that the NHS plan failed to highlight the key role of local authorities in providing and commissioning social care.

"The broader response is welcome. The partnership between local authorities, health boards and trusts in improving health is now recognised, and it is good to see it laid out as one of the planks of the plan, because until now we have always been on the margins," she said.

"But the plan wraps up the local authority role in community planning and public health. It would have been more helpful to have a clearer statement about the social care aspects of local authority responsibilities as well."

Meanwhile, Help the Aged welcomed the strong emphasis on improving the care of elderly people with proposals for a more joined-up approach to health and community care services, cutting waiting lists and ending the postcode lottery of care.

"While we are pleased that the executive intends to encourage more joined-up thinking in health and community care services, a great deal of work and investment will be required to make this happen effectively," said Scottish officer Liz Duncan.

"The commitment to ending the postcode lottery of care is especially welcome. Older people at the moment suffer from great discrepancies between local authorities not only in standards of care, but also in terms of how they are charged for long-term care. We would also liked to have seen in today's plan a commitment to provide free personal care."

Age Concern Scotland welcomed the plan's assertion that there would be "no place for ageism" in the NHS in Scotland but is continuing to call for a full investigation into the problem.

Scotland's chief medical officer has already been asked to lead an expert group to examine the care of elderly people in the NHS with work due to start next year.

"But it is not the same as investigating ageist attitudes or practices in the NHS," claimed assistant director Linda Dunion. "We will continue to call for that and would like to see the remit of the chief medical officer strengthened to enable him to investigate fully ageism in the NHS."

The Scottish Association for Mental Health said while acknowledging the unified health boards and trusts would help reduce bureaucracy, it was concerned about the loss of specialist trusts that delivered mental health services.

"Mental health services have suffered in the past from 'leakage' of funding to other, politically higher profile, health needs," said head of policy and information Richard Norris.

"The new unified health boards will need to be closely monitored to ensure that spending on mental health reflects its position as one of the three clinical priorities and does not lag behind general health spending as it has done in the past."

webTitle: Bush pledges to serve 'every single American'

fields.headline: Bush pledges to serve 'every single American'
fields.standfirst:
Gore forced to concede White House race as Democrats claim supreme court robbed vice-president of victory

Special report: US election
fields.trailText: Gore forced to concede White House race as Democrats claim supreme court robbed vice-president of victory
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington,  Julian Borger  in Tallahassee and  Duncan Campbell in Austin
fields.body:
George W Bush launches himself on the task of reuniting his bitterly divided nation today, naming the first official members of his new Republican administration as he scrambles to get ready to take over the White House from Bill Clinton in just over five weeks' time.

Mr Bush began the daunting job of healing the nation's political wounds when he went before Americans early today for the first time as their official president-elect with a speech laden with good intentions.

He spoke less than an hour after his Democratic opponent, Al Gore, had finally conceded defeat following 36 days of election disputes that have left the US political system bruised and bleeding.

"I was not elected to serve one party but to serve one nation," Mr Bush said in his speech from the Texas House of Representatives in Austin. "The president of the United States is the president of every single American, of every race and every background."

Calling bipartisan cooperation "the challenge of our moment", Mr Bush said he hoped that "the long wait of the last five weeks will heighten a desire to move beyond the bitterness and partisanship of the recent past". There was "remarkable consensus about the important issues before us", he said.

"Our nation must rise above a house divided," Mr Bush said. But with Republicans now in control of the White House, the Senate and the House of Representatives for the first time since the 1950s, Mr Bush also sketched out the domestic agenda which he now intends to pursue in the hardhat political atmosphere of Washington.

"These priorities are not merely Republican concerns or Democratic concerns, these are American responsibilities," Mr Bush said. "I will give it my all," he promised.

In his own no less minutely scrutinised televised concession speech last night, Mr Gore - standing with his wife, Tipper, four children and running mate, Joe Lieberman - finally said the words that Republicans had ached to hear for so long: "I offer my concession."

Mr Gore telephoned Mr Bush in Austin ahead of his speech - just as he had on November 8. "Just moments ago I spoke with George W Bush and congratulated him on becoming the 43rd president of the United States. And I promised him I would not call him back this time," he joked.

Mr Gore struck an unambiguously patriotic and conciliatory tone, touched with moments of self-deprecating humour, in a seven-minute address from his White House office in which he called on Americans to "unite behind our next president".

In what must have been a searingly disappointing moment for a man who has yearned for the presidency for much of his adult life, Mr Gore said that "partisan feeling must yield to patriotism" and that America must "heal the wounds".

Mr Gore said he strongly disagreed with the supreme court's decision to throw out his challenge to the election in Florida but said he would accept it. "I accept the finality of this outcome," he said.

In his often graceful and dignified concession, Mr Gore said he did not know what the future held for him. "I don't know the answer to that one yet. I know I'll spend some time in Tennessee and mend some fences, literally and figuratively," he said.

But as he left his office, supporters chanted "Gore for 2004".

Mr Bush, 54, was due to name the first official members of his new Republican administration today but there was little mood of celebration in the almost deserted streets of Austin, Texas.

The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said before Bush had voiced his own thoughts: "I am absolutely confident that George W Bush will reach out and bring this country together. He needs to reassure the American people."

The supreme court in effect handed the election to Mr Bush when its conservative majority, headed by the chief justice, William Rehnquist, voted by five votes to four to overturn the verdict of the Florida supreme court. They ordered an end to further counting of the disputed ballots in the state whose 25 electoral college votes will now go to Mr Bush.

The ruling prompted a fierce new debate and there were accusations that the highest court in the land had acted in a partisan way. Mr Rehnquist and fellow judge Clarence Thomas took the unusual step of denying any political motives behind the court's judgment.

One of the dissenting judges, John Paul Stevens, suggested that the real winner of the 2000 election might never be known, adding: "The identity of the loser is perfectly clear - it is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the rule of law."

Mr Bush can now look forward to a 271 to 267 electoral college victory over Mr Gore on December 18. He will be sworn in as the 43rd president of the US next month.

Mr Gore won the national popular vote by 50.2m to 49.8m. That makes Mr Bush the first US president since 1888 to fail to win a popular majority.

Mr Bush is today expected to complete plans to travel with his wife Laura to Washington, perhaps as early as tomorrow.

The supreme court in effect handed the election to Mr Bush when its conservative majority, headed by the chief justice, William Rehnquist, voted by five votes to four to overturn the verdict of the Florida supreme court. They ordered an end to further counting of the disputed ballots in the state whose 25 electoral college votes will now go to Mr Bush. The ruling prompted a fierce new debate and there were accusations that the highest court in the land had acted in a partisan way. Mr Rehnquist and fellow judge Clarence Thomas took the unusual step of denying any political motives behind the court's judgment. One of the dissenting judges, John Paul Stevens, suggested that the real winner of the 2000 election might never be known, adding: "The identity of the loser is perfectly clear - it is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the rule of law." Mr Bush can now look forward to a 271 to 267 electoral college victory over Mr Gore on December 18. He will be sworn in as the 43rd president of the US next month. Mr Gore won the national popular vote by 50.2m to 49.8m. That makes Mr Bush the first US president since 1888 to fail to win a popular majority. Mr Bush is today expected to complete plans to travel with his wife Laura to Washington, perhaps as early as tomorrow. Talk about it What do you think? fields.headline: Blair prepares for new era
fields.standfirst:
Bush is unknown quantity after years of cosy Clinton rapport
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's government last night braced itself for the unknown terrain of a second Bush administration in the White House five weeks after spin doctors in Downing Street, the Treasury and the Foreign Office first rehearsed mood music that was optimistic - possibly too optimistic.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's government last night braced itself for the unknown terrain of a second Bush administration in the White House five weeks after spin doctors in Downing Street, the Treasury and the Foreign Office first rehearsed mood music that was optimistic - possibly too optimistic.

"It will make no difference who wins. George W Bush has a lot of good people around him," one senior aide to Tony Blair insisted as the votes were being counted on November 7. That line has not changed.

At breakfast time on November 8 Robin Cook, the for eign secretary, said: "I congratulate George Bush if it is confirmed that he has won and we look forward to working with him and keeping Britain as that unique bridge between America and Europe."

He will say much the same this morning. As for the kind of ideological differences that may rend asunder the cosy relationship between London and Washington in the Clinton-Blair era, Mr Cook said at the time: "I'm not the slightest [bit] worried. George Bush is firmly within the mainstream of American foreign policy, American tradition."

Privately, officials confirmed that upbeat view last night. In international affairs, one said, the Foreign Office expects a Bush administration to be "very much part of the internationally outward-looking post-war consensus".

That may be optimistic. Mr Bush does indeed have good staff, many inherited from his father. But they are also veterans of the cold war world whose instincts have become "unilateralist" rather than "isolationist".

General Colin Powell, the son of poor immigrants from Jamaica whom Mr Cook met last winter, fits that mould. A Vietnam veteran, he does not like to put US troops in harm's way without good reason.

Ground troops in Kosovo may not meet that test, as senior Bush staffers hinted during the US campaign. Bill Clinton also played that card in 1992, leading Whitehall officials to argue: "It's just politics."

Some were quick to point out that a conservative White House which supports Labour's drive to beef up EU defence capacity (the best way to lock in the US commitment to Nato, Cook insists) will be a plus, and unhelpful to William Hague's campaign against the EU rapid reaction force.

As for the "third way" politics which made Tony Blair's relationship with the Rhodes scholar from Arkansas so "intense", they are more prob lematical. But New Labour strategists dismiss the idea that Mr Bush's narrow, disputed win amounts to much of a boost for Mr Hague.

"The manner of his victory diminishes the degree to which rightwing newspapers can claim the zeitgeist is flowing back to the centre-right," one of Gordon Brown's lieutenants said yesterday. In that regard Labour's cheerful pre-election whistling is probably warranted.

Mr Hague visited Mr Bush in Texas and enthusiastically embraced his slogan of "compassionate conservatism". But he has not moved into Governor Bush's centre-ground, preferring since mid-1999 to embrace the more rightwing stance of Mike Harris, the premier of Ontario whose "common sense revolution" on tax and social policy Mr Hague rapidly devoured.

Unlike Vice-President Al Gore, Tony Blair does not have to get out of anyone's shadow. "I am my own man," Mr Gore was still asserting as late as August. That problem prevented him proclaiming the Clinton economic record or using the Clinton campaign magic.

Mr Blair and Mr Brown will not make that mistake. Nor did they interfere in the election in the foolish way some Tory officials did to help Bush Snr against Mr Clinton (over his military draft record) in 1992.

That soured relations and impacted seriously on the Northern Ireland peace process from 1992-97, the only time London and Washington have been badly at odds since the Nixon-Heath era of 1970-74.

That is the ideological danger: that suspicion of a prime minister who chatted more often than was widely realised by phone to Mr Clinton - their lawyer wives also got on - will make the new president wary of London.

That could rub off on the traditional British role as "the bridge" between the EU and the US, weakening Britain's standing across the Atlantic and the Channel.

Belfast and Dublin will not have the same fascination for a Republican Texan, even if he does have a few debts to pro-Sinn Fein congressmen, as Peter Mandelson denies suggesting.

But, British officials admit, there may be gains, including on international free trade, where Mr Gore was quasi-protectionist.

fields.headline: Anger at supreme court verdict
fields.standfirst:
Ruling raises questions about impartiality

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The future of the supreme court, highest judicial body in the US, was thrown into the spotlight yesterday after it issued an early-morning majority ruling that caused uproar among Democrats and prompted the condemnation of some of its own judges.
fields.body:
The future of the supreme court, highest judicial body in the US, was thrown into the spotlight yesterday after it issued an early-morning majority ruling that caused uproar among Democrats and prompted the condemnation of some of its own judges.

Judge John Stevens, the main dissenter on the nine-member panel, issued a swingeing indictment of the ruling, by 5-4, that Florida had run out of time to stage proper recounts of disputed ballots from the November 7 vote. He warned that the decision had wounded the backbone of the rule of law - confidence in judges - by questioning the impartiality of Florida courts.

"Although we may never know with complete certainty the identity of the winner of this year's presidential election, the identity of the loser is perfectly clear. It is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the rule of law," he said.

The Democrat Jesse Jackson said he disagreed with the outcome "with every bone in my body and every ounce of moral strength in my soul". He accused the US supreme court of acting as a "willing tool of the Bush campaign" and of orchestrating a "velvet legal coup".

The historic verdict was handed to the waiting world early on Wednesday morning. Earlier, members of the court were spotted leaving their Capitol Hill offices looking tired and drawn. They had been called upon to resolve the nation's argument and they seemed to buckle under the weight of that responsibility.

More than 60 pages of opinion and rulings made up its judgment in the case of Bush v Gore. Some of the dissenting judgments were eloquent and pointed. But it was the 13 pages of the unsigned majority verdict that will be remembered by Mr Bush and his supporters with undying gratitude for finally paving the Republican's way to the White House.

"None are more conscious of the vital limits on judicial authority than are the members of this court," the majority wrote in a dramatic conclusion which was condemned by Gore supporters as a historic piece of judicial hypocrisy.

"When contending parties invoke the process of the courts, however, it becomes our unsought responsibility to resolve the federal and constitutional issues the judicial sys tem has been forced to confront. The judgment of the supreme court of Florida is reversed."

Only 10 days ago, in its earlier ruling on Bush v Palm Beach county, the nine member court had made more than a show of reluctance to become involved in what has traditionally been an area of state law.

"As a general rule, this court defers to a state court's interpretation of a state statute," it concluded, sending Mr Bush's complaint against the Florida supreme court back to Tallahassee.

That earlier cautious judgment was consistent with the doctrine of "judicial restraint" which has generally characterised the work of the US supreme court under the conservative chief justice, William Rehnquist.

But last Saturday, when it intervened to stop the latest recount ordered by the Florida court, the Rehnquist court began to signal a change of approach.

Tuesday night's ruling in Bush v Gore carried the abrupt change of course further. Basing itself firmly on the constitutional principle of equal protection under the law, the majority crossed the federalist frontier with scarcely a backward glance, wading deep into Florida law to unpick and rewrite the state's election rules in an exceptionally detailed way with wide implications for the conduct of all future elections.

It is not just the right to vote that must be equally protected, the majority ruled, but the manner in which the right is exercised.

That means that any recounts which examine the voter's intent where that is not immediately clear need to be subject to "specific rules designed to ensure uniform treatment", the court ruled.

The real sting of the judgment came in the tail. Having established that there was a constitutional problem of unequal protection, the five conservatives on the court then decided that there was no way of remedying it.

"It is obvious that the recount cannot be conducted in compliance with the requirements of equal protection and due process without substantial additional work," the majority concluded. Federal law was designed to meet a December 12 deadline for selecting members of the electoral college. "That date is upon us," the judges observed as they issued their ruling at 10pm on that very date.

At the heart of critics' arguments last night was one central point: that the supreme court had said the Florida election was full of unfairness, and yet they had then decreed that that unfairness must not be remedied.

That decision in effect gave the presidency to Mr Bush, the candidate for whom all of the five justices in the majority are likely to have voted, if indeed they voted at all.

Rival factions on the bench

Opinion of the supreme court (majority ruling):

It is obvious that the recount cannot be conducted in compliance with the requirements of equal protection and due process without substantial additional work. It would require not only the adoption of adequate state-wide standards for determining what is a legal vote... but also orderly judicial review of any disputed matters that might arise.

The supreme court of Florida has said that the legislature intended the state's electors to "participate fully in the federal electoral process", as provided in 3 USC Sec 5. That statute, in turn, requires that any controversy or contest that is designed to lead to a conclusive selection of electors be completed by December 12. That date is upon us. Because it is evident that any recount seeking to meet the December 12 date will be unconstitutional for the reasons we have discussed, we reverse the judgment of the supreme court of Florida ordering a recount to proceed.

Justice John Paul Stevens's dissent, joined by Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen Breyer:

What must underlie petitioners' entire federal assault on the Florida election procedures is an unstated lack of confidence in the impartiality and capacity of the state judges who would make the critical decisions if the vote count were to proceed. Otherwise, their position is wholly without merit. The endorsement of that position by the majority of this court can only lend credence to the most cynical appraisal of the work of judges throughout the land. It is confidence in the men and women who administer the judicial system that is the true backbone of the rule of law. Time will one day heal the wound to that confidence that will be inflicted by today's decision. One thing, however, is certain. Although we may never know with complete certainty the identity of the winner of this year's presidential election, the identity of the loser is perfectly clear. It is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the rule of law.

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 15.
fields.trailText: December 14: Granada and Carlton are working on plans to create a London ITV 'superfranchise'.
fields.body:
Granada and Carlton are working on plans to create a London ITV "superfranchise", with a number of areas expected to be consolidated well before the new broadcasting bill outlined in this weeks white paper comes into effect.

A group of digital TV channels is to lobby the Office of Fair Trading over the cost of launching interactive services on BSkyB's digital platform.

BBC Birmingham is quitting its premises at Pebble Mill after 29 years to relocate to the modern city centre premises of the Mailbox.

The Commercial Radio Companies Association is threatening legal action against the Radio Authority as it steps up its argument with the regulator over the issue of automated, non-live programming.

webTitle: Bertelsmann/EMI talks to continue through January

fields.headline: Bertelsmann/EMI talks to continue into January
fields.standfirst:
Nov 21: EMI/Bertlesmann merger talks 'far from concluded'
Special report: merger mania
fields.trailText:
10.45am: Bertelsmann has said merger negotiations between its music division and EMI are likely to continue at least until the end of January, writes Jason Deans.
Nov 21: EMI/Bertlesmann merger talks 'far from concluded'
Special report: merger mania
fields.body:
German media giant Bertelsmann has said that merger negotiations between its music division and EMI are likely to continue at least until the end of January.

Thomas Middelhoff, Bertelsmann chief executive, said at a press briefing today that he did not "expect a result before the end of January" from the talks with EMI over the music merger.

Mr Middelhoff added that the result of the talks was "not predictable".

He also said that within the music industry, Bertelsmann was negotiating exclusively with EMI.

The two companies are understood to be discussing a deal that would see Bertelsmann folding its BMG music arm into EMI Group and paying the latter's shareholders a special dividend in return for a controlling stake in the new venture.

EMI is the world's third-largest record company, while BMG is the fifth largest.

Mr Middelhoff also said he believed enough internet users were prepared to pay for the online music exchange service Bertelsmann is seeking to develop with Napster to make it a worthwhile venture.

"We believe that the readiness to pay is large enough to generate considerable business potential," he said.

"Music is just the beginning. I am of the opinion that, in the future, films, games, private photos, everything possible will be exchanged over the internet."

webTitle: Casting news: Hoffman gambles on true story of embezzler

fields.headline: Hoffman gambles on true story of embezzler
fields.trailText: Plus: Left-leaning Susan Sarandon sticks to her principles for drama set during the 1950s red scare
fields.body:
 Philip Seymour Hoffman (pictured) is to take the lead role in the low-budget thriller Owning Molony, a British and Canadian co-production bankrolled by Alliance-Atlantis and H20 Motion Pictures. Having made his name in Happiness, Boogie Nights and Magnolia, Hoffman will play the role of a bank manager who embezzles millions to fund his gambling habit. Directed by Richard Kwietniowski, the film is adapted from Gary Ross's fact-based book Stung: The Incredible Session of Brian Molony. Shooting starts in Canada and Atlantic City, New Jersey in March, after Hoffman has completed work on an as-yet untitled comedy directed by Paul Thomas Anderson.

 If there's a left-leaning movie with a strong female role in the pipeline, you can bet that Susan Sarandon won't be far away. The Thelma and Louise star is currently in final negotiations to star in the independent drama Rialto as the enigmatic manageress of a New England cinema who becomes a target of the McCarthy purges during the 1950s red scare. Rialto will be directed by Lizzie Borden, who also co-wrote the script with Stephen Grant and Lennie Bleecher.

webTitle: Egg is leading independent online bank

fields.headline: Egg emerges as leading independent online bank
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Prudential-owned Egg has cemented itself as the UK's largest independent online bank, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Prudential-owned Egg has cemented itself as the UK's largest independent online bank by revealing it has more than 1.33m customers.

In a trading statement published this morning, Egg said it was meeting targets and continuing to add customers.

Egg said it had signed up 141,000 customers from the beginning of October to December 11.

Launched two years ago and floated on the stock market in June, Egg has been hit by the launch of rival online banking products from traditional banks.

However, it remains well regarded by the public and has the questionable advantage of being an early entrant into this market. It also recently launched a £30m ad campaign.

Egg, which started out as an online savings bank, has now launched a credit card, a Wap service, a fund supermarket, general insurance and share dealing services.

Further plans to launch a mortgage service, Egg TV on Open, home and contents insurance and a current account in the first quarter of 2001 are being discussed.

Egg hopes to drive revenues by cross-selling products to customers. The Egg Shop pulled in revenues of £194,000 in November.

Unique visitors to Egg's website reached 754,000 in October. In the same month, the company reported a third-quarter loss of £34.4m.

Shares in Egg are currently around £1.17, below its flotation price of £1.60.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: President Bush?! All today's rumours are still in shock too.
fields.trailText: Aston Villa are ready to offer Gareth Southgate and up to £4m in cash to prise Frank Lampard away West Ham, reports the Daily Mirror.
fields.body:
Aston Villa are ready to offer Gareth Southgate and up to £4m in cash to prise Frank Lampard away West Ham, reports the Daily Mirror.

Meanwhile, West Ham have made a £6.75m bid for Marian Pahars, according to a posting on a Southampton supporters mailing list this morning.

Paris Saint Germain chairman Laurent Perpère has denied making an £18m bid for Ronaldinho - and has claimed that Leeds have been tracking the Brazilian striker. "We have approached him, but nothing has been signed. On principle, I am not optimistic for this case and am very cautious," said Perpère. "But you have to know, the Brazilian side already refused a 500m Francs [£46m] offer from Leeds!"

Internazionale are ready to accept a £12m bid for Robbie Keane, reports the Daily Mail. However, Inter have told Leeds - the most likely buyer of Keane - that they want Olivier Dacourt as part of any deal.

Sven-Goran Eriksson is ready to bid £4m for Paolo Di Canio in a desperate attempt to turn Lazio's season around, reports the Sun.

Arsenal and Chelsea "have marched straight to the top of the queue" for Matt Clarke, reports the Express. Bradford manager Jim Jefferies has agreed to let his keeper leave if he receives a £5m bid.

Arsene Wenger is also interested in signing Carlisle striker Scott Dobie, according to the Star - but the Third Division side want £1m for him.

Tottenham has denied rumours that they are prepared to cut their losses and sell Sergei Rebrov, reports the Star. "I'm delighted with him. I think he is a terrific lad, works very hard in training, great attitude, and he'll settle in, no problems with that. Just give him time," said George Graham.

New Middlesbrough manager Terry Venables has put a £4m bid for Rory Delap on hold to give the existing squad a chance to prove themselves, reports the Star. "If I think something is necessary once I've had a look at the players already here, I'll have a word with the chairman. But my job right now is to lift the players and get them performing the way we want," Venables claimed.

Slovakian international wing-back Igor Balis will sign for WBA today, claims Teamtalk.

webTitle: Price tag for Hillary's memoirs tops £5m

fields.headline: Price tag for Hillary's memoirs tops £5m
fields.trailText: Bidding for the publication rights to Hillary Clinton's memoirs about her White House years is said to have reached more than $7.5m, approaching the record for a non-fiction book.
fields.body:
Bidding for the publication rights to Hillary Clinton's memoirs about her White House years is said to have reached more than $7.5m, approaching the record for a non-fiction book.

The US president, Bill Clinton, is also expected to write his memoirs, but those by first ladies tend to sell better.

"The expectation, realistic or not, is that the wives will be more candid than their husbands," said one publisher.

The Pope got $8.5m (£5.9m) six years ago for his memoirs and former president Ronald Reagan was paid more than $8m in 1989.

"Many others have imputed thoughts and feelings to me," says Mrs Clinton, who is expected to break with convention and ask for full payment in advance. "I would like to have the chance to sort my own out and to share those."

She will address the scandals of her husband's two terms, including the Monica Lewinsky affair. "That's another issue that I'd probably like to put into my own words so that people could make their own judgments," she said.

webTitle: Ex-MI5 chief to get memoirs go-ahead

fields.headline: Ex-MI5 chief to get memoirs go-ahead
fields.trailText: Stella Rimington, former head of MI5, is to be given the go-ahead to publish her memoirs, the subject of a bitter row among senior security and intelligence officers.
fields.body:
Stella Rimington, former head of MI5, is to be given the go-ahead to publish her memoirs, the subject of a bitter row among senior security and intelligence officers.

In a series of meetings with her successor, Sir Stephen Lander, she is understood to have agreed to drop references to a number of MI5 operations, notably against the IRA. The talks were described yesterday as "amiable".

However, her decision to write her memoirs is still fiercely opposed by other agencies, including the Ministry of Defence, which is attempting to prevent more SAS soldiers from writing books about their exploits.

The MoD was dealt a blow last week when a New Zealand court dismissed its attempt to suppress an account of an ill-fated Gulf war mission by an SAS soldier.

Other agencies, notably GCHQ, the government's eavesdropping centre, and MI6, which gathers intelligence abroad from agents, are believed to have objected to the way passages refer to MI5's relations with them.

According to a draft leaked to the Sun in September, Dame Stella also referred in passing to the miners' strike - the first confirmation of MI5's role in the dispute.

The Sun said her memoirs were dotted with humorous anecdotes, including her dealings with ex-prime ministers Margaret Thatcher and John Major. It is unclear if these references will be cut.

Sir Stephen is said to have argued that her case cannot be compared to that of the MI5 renegade David Shayler, who disclosed information unilaterally. Dame Stella offered her book for vetting.

A decision will be taken by ministers on the advice of the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson.
