fields.headline: Onslow denies insolvent trading
fields.trailText: The Earl of Onslow, a former non-executive director of Continental Assurance Company of London, yesterday told the high court in London that he had done all in his power to prevent the collapse of the firm over a eight-month period in which it had experienced heavy losses.
fields.body:
The Earl of Onslow, a former non-executive director of Continental Assurance Company of London, yesterday told the high court in London that he had done all in his power to prevent the collapse of the firm over a eight-month period in which it had experienced heavy losses.

The company's liquidators allege that Lord Onslow and seven other directors breached their legal responsibilities and failed to ensure the company was solvent while trading.

The board eventually placed Continental Assurance into liquidation in March 1992 with debts of £14m and a £6m loss of shareholders' funds. Creditors hope to retrieve around £4.7m from directors.

Stephen Atherton, counsel for the liquidators, suggested that the board had not tried hard enough to anticipate a series of large losses.

Lord Onslow, who wore his trademark scarlet socks and floppy bow tie, told the court: "Insurance is a guessing game, however much people pretend it is not."

But he insisted that the "regrettable" losses experienced by the company could not have been foreseen by the board. "For my part, had there been any inkling that we were not solvent we would have stopped trading there and then," he told the judge, Mr Justice Park. The liquidators say that the directors should have known by July 1991 that Continental Assurance was unlikely to remain solvent.

When asked why he did not interrogate management over the some of company's finances, he said he was not qualified to do so.

"I am not an accountant. And I am not sufficiently intelligent or well read to dispute what they say."

The case continues today.

webTitle: Bankers beat brokers in bonus stakes

fields.headline: Bankers beat brokers in bonus stakes
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Advice on mergers and acquisitions brings hundreds of £1m City hand-outs
fields.trailText: Hundreds of million pound cheques are being handed out to City bankers - the rich rewards for the indispensable advice about mergers and and acquisition strategy they have given to top companies this year. Bankers at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter received news of their bonuses this week; rivals at Goldman Sachs will hear today.
fields.body:
Hundreds of million pound cheques are being handed out to City bankers - the rich rewards for the indispensable advice about mergers and and acquisition strategy they have given to top companies this year. Bankers at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter received news of their bonuses this week; rivals at Goldman Sachs will hear today.

The hand-outs are once again expected to top £1bn - split between 140,000 of the City's 250,000 workers. But this year a new, divisive trend has emerged. The big payouts are going to the bankers, who devise the structures of complicated takeover deals. Stockbrokers and traders will be offered relatively paltry payouts.

It is the bankers who have generated the biggest profits this year, and the big investment banks are skewing their bonus payments to those who produce the most hard cash. "Many, many bankers are going to get £1m this year," said a senior executive in the London office of a leading US bank. "Even only halfway decent ones are going to get £500,000."

Doug McWilliams, chief executive of the centre for economic and business research, said: "What we will discover is huge distinctions. Traders, by and large, have not done well. It is in investment banking, the corporate financiers, where the bonuses are going to be super-duper".

For many bankers it will be their second payment in 12 months. Many firms have already had to make golden handcuffs payments to prevent staff being lured away in the wake of mergers, including: UBS and Paine Webber; DLJ and CSFB; and Chase, Flemings and JP Morgan.

Bankers have even been given extra handouts when takeovers have failed, such as the aborted link-up between German groups Deutsche and Dresdner.

In the US some senior DLJ managers, who are now on CSFB's payroll, are said to be getting a combined $1bn (£690m) from takeover clauses in their contracts. But even mega-payouts are not enough to buy the loyalty of some big name bankers.

A spokesman for Doublecuff.com, a subsidiary of headhunters Marshall Warbur ton, said: "Competition for hiring staff with a proven track record is so great that nearly every investment house has been buying out bonuses from successful candidates and guaranteeing a minimum bonus for next year to switch jobs."

This is a trend that has been shipped in from Wall Street as US investment banks have moved into the City.

According to the New York Comptrollers Office, which collects tax revenue for the state, some $12bn was paid out in bonuses to Wall Street's 170,000 workers in 1999. But this year the bonus pot is expected to have swelled to $15bn.

One firm of US headhunters reckons that more than 4,000 senior US bankers will this year walk away with cheques for $1m - and that 100 top dealmakers are likely to bank more than $10m a head.

Headhunters say the basic salary level offered to UK bankers is now levelling out at around £100,000, but that the bonus element is becoming ever more lucrative.

These bankers are keenly aware of the exact amount of profit they generate for their employers - and vocal in their demands for a share of the spoils.

One senior banker said: "Agreeing bonus payments has become a game. Some bankers will be offered huge amounts, and then they will just look their boss in the eye as though he had just shot their grandmother."

He added that this year many of the smaller banks will be paying the biggest bonuses as they fight to keep hold of their top profit-makers. Among the first to receive their payouts will be those at Goldman Sachs, whose results are due this week. They will be closely followed by Morgan Stanley, UBS Warburg and CSFB.

As always, the recipients say the payouts are not guaranteed and that this year could well be the last good one. They point to general uncertainties, like the state of the US economy, and suggest the bubble might burst. For now though, the City's annual bonus bonanza could have knock-on effects for everyone. The huge wall of money that will be flooding into the bank accounts of investment bankers this year is once again likely to cause a one-off blip in the country's average earnings index - one of the key indicators for the MPC when it decides the cost of borrowing.

fields.headline: Health care returns to favour
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Calm returned to Wall Street as something approaching clarity returned to the US presidential race. So London was again in upbeat mood, allowing the FTSE 100 index to extend its three day rally by a further 12.6 points to 6,403.
fields.body:
Calm returned to Wall Street as something approaching clarity returned to the US presidential race. So London was again in upbeat mood, allowing the FTSE 100 index to extend its three day rally by a further 12.6 points to 6,403.

Nycomed Amersham, the health care firm which has seen its shares gradually slide from a year's high of 745.25p to yesterday's close of 580p, saw a return to favour yesterday. The price rose 40p or 7.4% to 580p following the announcement that Neospect, the company's product for the diagnosis of lung cancer, has received European marketing approval and its new gene sequencers have entered trials.

At the moment a sample has to be taken from lungs to detect cancer, but with Neospect, the company says, it shows up on screen.

Pharmaceutical firms were strong yesterday and the sector good progress. Glaxo Wellcome was up 39p to £19.60 and SmithKline Beecham rose 18.5p to 890p, partly because of the US supreme court ruling that increases the chances of Republican candidate George W Bush becoming president.

The drug sector was also popular because investors were looking for dependable companies to pile back into as the TMT sector fell. AstraZeneca rose 49p to £32.60, while Vodafone fell 8.5p to 268p - a move that equated to 22 points off the Footsie.

Tobacco companies, led by British American Tobacco, up 8.25p to 488.25p, were also looking bullish. Tobacco firms along with drug companies will benefit if Mr Bush comes to power because he does not favour price controls for drugs or litigation against tobacco companies.

Not all tobacco companies, however, were in favour. Imperial Tobacco dropped 18p to 732p after the company was downgraded from "neutral" to "underperform" by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

Bank stocks generally gained with Lloyds' share price rising 5p to 693p after Abbey National rejected its of fer of £18bn. Speculation was rife that a hostile bid was the only way for Lloyds to get Abbey National. Abbey saw its shares fall 14p to £11.66.

Peel Hunt, the stockbroker, saw its shares jump 52.5p or 14% to 425p after it said it had received a takeover approach.

Mining stocks were among the day's big losers. Alcan Aluminium, the global aluminium maker, released a profit warning on Tuesday which sent shares sliding. Alcan said fourth-quarter profit would be below expectations because its merger with Alusuisse cost more than had been forecast.

Fears were raised for others in the industry and Billiton slid 17.75p to 258p as Rio Tinto fell 29p to £11.50.

Analysts yesterday blamed the slump in the sector on the profit warning and a general feeling among investors that the slowing growth the sector had been experiencing would be more severe than previously expected.

Capital Radio shares fell 115p to £12.05 due to uncertainty raised over consolidation in the industry. ABN Amro cut its recommendation from "buy" to "hold" because of the government's communications white paper.

Not all technology stocks took a dive yesterday with shares in GEO Interactive, the Israeli technology company, jumping 45p to 730p. The move followed reports it was close to a deal to provide Ericsson with video technology for mobile phones.

Over on the food side of things,Granada Compass saw its shares rise 43p to 694p after reporting a 2% rise in annual operating profits as it entered the second round of its hotels auction.

Iceland rose 6p to 344.5p after announcing it had appointed former Wickes boss Bill Grimsey as chief executive after Stuart Rose's departure.

Tesco did not follow the positive trend - its shares slipped 0.75p to 265.24p. The company has adopted Kewill Systems' business software to manage its supply chain. Shares in the software maker rose 5p to 440p.

webTitle: Labour hopes hit as jobs boom falters

fields.headline: Labour hopes hit as jobs boom falters
fields.trailText: The boom in Britain's jobs market appears to be over, giving the government a potential headache in the run-up to the next election.
fields.body:
The boom in Britain's jobs market appears to be over, giving the government a potential headache in the run-up to the next election.

Ministers were spared the embarrassment of a second monthly rise in the number of people out of work and claiming benefit in November, but their preferred measure of unemployment - used by the International Labour Organisation - rose 36,000 to 1.62m The ILO measure includes all those seeking work and has been promoted by the government as a more reliable guide than the claimant count. The employment rate has fallen slightly to 74.6% of the work force from 74.7%.

ONS officials said: "The latest figures confirm that the downward trend in unemployment has flattened out."

Employment minister Tessa Jowell welcomed the figures, saying: "New vacancies are still at high levels, and I am pleased the claimant count - which is the most up-to-date figure we have - is falling."

City economists said that with global economic growth slowing, there was a clear danger that the labour market could begin to deteriorate.

"The balance of evidence points more to the labour market cooling off, rather than providing an upside risk to the inflation target," said Daniel Kaye, UK economist at Capital Economics in London.

The claimant count fell 5,300 last month to 1.04m, more than reversing a revised 3,900 rise in October, which was the first increase in almost two years. Mr Kaye said the bounce back in November was small enough to show that October's rise was no blip, casting doubt on the government's hoped-for fall below 1m before a spring election.

The ONS also reported that the rate of growth of average earnings - a significant measure of inflationary forces in the labour market - rose to 4.2% in the three months to October from 4.1% in the three months to September.

While that was the strongest figure for five months, it remains well within the 4.5% that the Bank of England considers to be compatible with its 2.5% target for underlying inflation.

The Bank has left interest rates steady at 6% since February and many analysts are expecting it to cut rates early next year. The rise in earnings reflected stronger private sector pay growth. Public sector earnings growth remained unchanged at 3.4%.

webTitle: MEPs act to restrict hostile takeovers

fields.headline: MEPs act to restrict takeovers
fields.standfirst:
'Poison pill' move attacked

Special report: the European Parliament
fields.trailText: Euro-MPs last night threw their weight behind proposals which threaten to throw up extra hurdles for companies planning hostile takeover bids on the continent.
fields.body:
Euro-MPs last night threw their weight behind proposals which threaten to throw up extra hurdles for companies planning hostile takeover bids on the continent.

The European parliament in Strasbourg amended the EU's nascent takeovers directive and decided to allow firms facing a hostile bid to activate so-called "poison pill" defences without consulting their own shareholders.

The move was opposed by the European commission, the CBI, the UK's takeover panel and the Association of British Insurers, who had all lobbied hard to get MEPs to think again.

The amendment, tabled by a German Christian Democrat Klaus-Heiner Lehne, gives authorities in individual member states the discretion to allow companies to resort to drastic defensive action.

The problem, however, is that member states have differing views on the subject and critics believe that protectionist minded states such as France and Germany would use the rules to fend off unwanted foreign takeovers.

Rod Armitage, the CBI's head of legal affairs, argues that the amendment would make it far more difficult for a British company to organise a hostile takeover on the continent.

"This would significantly reduce investor protection and goes very much against the principle of the single market, as defensive action permitted by member states would inevitably differ," he warned last night.

"We had seen the successful Vodafone takeover of Mannesmann as indicating that national barriers were being reduced but this goes very much in the other direction."

Frits Bolkestein, the EU's internal market commissioner, issued a gloomy statement last night warning that the takeovers directive - which has taken more than 10 years to negotiate and was designed to usher in an EU-wide capital market - may now be dead.

"It is deeply disappointing. As a result of this change management could act to defend their own potentially narrower interests rather than being obliged to act in the interests of the target company's shareholders as a whole." The entire directive in its original form was now at risk.

Although the commission will now try to arrange a compromise between EU governments and the parliament, it believes that the changes pushed through yesterday were so fundamental that it might be a lost cause.

"We would then have to throw away more than ten year's work and start all over again," Mr Bolkestein said.

fields.headline: Tide turns for hopefuls
fields.standfirst: Song deal promotes unsigned musicians
fields.trailText: Aspiring rock and pop stars could soon find their songs sold on CDs in high street stores such as Woolworth and HMV as a result of a new distribution deal agreed by Musicunsigned Holdings, writes John Cassy .
fields.body:
Aspiring rock and pop stars could soon find their songs sold on CDs in high street stores such as Woolworth and HMV as a result of a new distribution deal agreed by Musicunsigned Holdings, writes John Cassy .

The internet-based promoter of unsigned musicians said yesterday that albums branded under its Velvet Recordings dance imprint would be sold to high-street stores by 3MV, a leading record distributor.

3MV works with acts like Fatboy Slim and Oasis and the Ministry of Sound nightclubs group. "This is a great endorsement of our bands because 3MV has listened to their stuff and de cided that they are comfortable selling their records on our behalf," said chief executive Aroon Maharajh.

He hopes that Musicunsigned's two other imprints focusing on R & B and pop music will eventually be distributed by 3MV.

Musicunsigned acts as a conduit between artists and the big record labels, promoting them online before they are well known in the hope that they will be snapped up by a big record company and turned into the stars of tomorrow. The company listed on AIM at the start of October. Shares closed up 0.25p at 7p.

fields.headline: Sprint faces legal action
fields.standfirst: Shareholder accuses telecom firm's directors of fraud
fields.trailText: An angry American shareholder has filed a lawsuit against senior executives at Sprint, the telecoms company, accusing them of fraudulently earning hundreds of millions of dollars from share options they were not entitled to.
fields.body:
An angry American shareholder has filed a lawsuit against senior executives at Sprint, the telecoms company, accusing them of fraudulently earning hundreds of millions of dollars from share options they were not entitled to.

The lawsuit alleges that the Sprint management secretly altered the company's change of control clause in a way that allowed them to activate their share options whether or not a merger went ahead. The change came to light following Sprint's abortive $115bn (£79bn) merger with Worldcom.

Investors are furious that the rule change enabled 22 directors to cash in their share options, designed to reward long-term performance, even though the merger fell apart in July.

Bernard Ebbers, the head of Worldcom, has also been charged in the lawsuit, alongside his counterpart at Sprint, William Esrey, and other board members such as Ron Sommer at Deutsche Telekom.

The lawsuit, brought by a trustee on behalf of the LongView Collective Investment Fund, accuses the 22 directors of fraud, unjust enrichment, waste of corporate assets, lack of candour as well as breaching their fiduciary duty. "[They] abused their control and fiduciary positions to improperly get for themselves and other Sprint officers, managers and employees hundreds of millions of dollars of benefits in connection with the aborted merger... while greatly damaging Sprint and its shareholders," it said.

Share options, which are typically meant to be held for several years, usually activate once a company is taken over. However, at the end of 1998 Sprint changed its rules to allow executives to activate their options once shareholder approval for a deal is given.

The proposed merger between Sprint and Worldcom broke down in July after failing to win approval from the US government. Shareholders had already agreed the deal, be lieving it would go ahead. Yesterday's lawsuit, filed in Missouri, alleges that the executives changed the rules once they had received indications of interest from suitors. It also alleges that the executives sold their shares after shareholder approval had been won using inside information that the deal would not go ahead.

Bill Lerach, a partner at Milberg, Weiss, the law firm behind the suit, said that his clients wanted the money made from the vested options to be returned to the company as well as the rule change to be reversed.

Mark Bonavia, a spokesman for Sprint, said the company, intended to fight the lawsuit.

fields.bylineHtml: Jane Martinson in New York

fields.headline: Small weed, big message
fields.standfirst:
Let's hear it for Arabidopsis thaliana

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Let's hear it for Arabidopsis thaliana
fields.body:
In 1777, William Curtis, a British botanist, described a weed called Arabidopsis thaliana as having "no particular virtues or uses". More than 200 years later, he could not have been proved more wrong. The ubiquitous weed made history yesterday. For the weed has one particular virtue - of which Curtis, of course, knew nothing: it has a small genome. That made it a model organism, in line with the celebrated fruit fly and the nematode worm, ideally suitable for genome sequencing. Arabidopsis thaliana - or thale cress or mouse ear cress - had other virtues, such as a short life cycle and the ease with which it grows, which qualified it to become the first plant to be sequenced. Yesterday, all of the 116m chemical letters of the plant's genetic code were released into a public database available to researchers everywhere. It was the culmination of a six-year, $70m project involving 300 scientists in Europe, the US and Japan.

This is a landmark moment in the history of our use and manipulation of plants. For around 8,000 years, we have crossbred and experimented with plants to improve yields and durability to weather and pests; the process was hit and miss. Now we are beginning to establish the blueprint which determines those yields and those values. A new era is dawning in which the manipulation of the plants could go to lengths never before imagined. And the stakes are huge. In the next 50 years, there will be another 3bn mouths to feed - at the same time as the amount of quality farmland available declines. The role of genetic modification to feed this growing population could be crucial.

Arguably, the humble Arabidopsis thaliana is the most important genome mapped so far. Six hundred viruses, 37 bacteria, one fungus, a worm, a fruitfly and a human have all been mapped. But it is plants which soak up sunlight, convert it into tissue and produce the oxygen on which so much other life depends. It is plants which hold the key to the world's ecosystems. And it is on plants which so many human activities depend, from food to shelter, clothing, fuel and medicines. The Arabidopsis thaliana provides a key to decipering the genome of other far more complex plants, such as wheat or rice, with which it shares about 90% of its genes. What lies ahead is a huge enterprise as we determine how to make beneficial use of this wealth of emerging knowledge.

fields.headline: Arnault's internet sidekick steps down
fields.trailText: The executive in charge of French billionaire Bernard Arnault's internet investment strategy has been replaced following a change in strategy and a reshuffle.
fields.body:
The executive in charge of French billionaire Bernard Arnault's internet investment strategy has been replaced following a change in strategy and a reshuffle.

Chahram Becharat, widely regarded as one of Europe's most powerful dot.com venture capitalists, is stepping down as managing director of high-profile internet investment group Europ@web, to take up unspecified "new responsibilities" within Mr Arnault's LVMH luxury goods empire.

Europ@web, one of the early investors in the now collapsed clothing site Boo.com, is merging with a division of French utilities group Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux. The new internet arm will be run by Philippe Jaffre, a former chairman of oil group Elf.

Mr Becharat, 33, emerged as one of Europe's most influential internet investors after Mr Arnault gave Europ@web £345m to pump into new dot.com firms. A combative former merchant banker who fled his native Iran in 1980 when his family's industrial holdings were seized by Islamic revolutionaries, he aggressively took stakes in more than two dozen start-ups.

Companies he invested in included the UK's Peoplesound, I-Collector and Flutter.com, French internet service provider LibertySurf and US online music firm MP3.com.

The strategy was to build a worldwide network of internet sites and compete with technology focused investment houses such as CMGI in the US and Softbank of Japan.

However, Europ@web's heavy exposure to unfashionable business to consumer in ternet companies, negative publicity surrounding the £7m write-off it was forced to make when Boo.com collapsed and uncertain stock market conditions forced it to postpone a planned summer flotation.

The departure of highly regarded former investment chief Jean-Bernard Tellio had also unsettled some potential investors.

Mr Arnault maintained that he still planned to float Europ@web by the end of this year, but that strategy appears to have changed following the new alliance.

Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux and Spanish telecoms group Telefonica are jointly bidding for a third-generation mobile phone licence in France. Europ@web hopes that if the bid is successful it will gain preferential access to high-speed internet services through which it can distribute its content.

A spokesman for Mr Arnault said Europe@web was valued at around €2bn (£1.2bn) and the new venture had around €300m cash in the bank. A stock market flotation is a possibility.

Mr Arnault has become one of Europe's richest businessmen after building up a portfolio of luxury brands including Louis Vuitton, Givenchy and Tag Heuer. LVMH is involved in a long-running battle with rival fashion house Gucci. Relations between LVMH and Gucci have been strained since the French group built up a stake in Gucci.

The dispute has pitted Mr Arnault against another billionaire Frenchman, François Pinault. Gucci called on Mr Pinault's financial firepower after LVMH bought a stake in Gucci with a view to taking over the firm.

webTitle: Leader: The court is in contempt of the electorate

fields.headline: In, but illegitimate
fields.standfirst:
The court is in contempt of the electorate

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The court is in contempt of the electorate
fields.body:
The fix is in, Al Gore is out and it is a bad day for American democracy. In the end, the supreme court was decisive. The majority's ruling was transparently political. Questions of timeframe and standards in Florida's recounts could have been resolved with goodwill and impartiality. Both were lacking. By its action, the antithesis of jurisprudence, the court is in contempt of the electorate. It may not, in this generation's lifetime, recover its reputation. And American political discourse may never be the same again.

The fix was long in preparation. It included the pre-poll manipulation of Florida's electoral rolls by Governor Jeb Bush, George W Bush's brother; and the intimidation and exclusion of Democrat-inclined minority voters on election day. That was followed by extraordinary incompetence and possible fraud during the count. Then came the Bush lawyers, using every trick and ruse in the law books to waste time and block accurate tallies. Mr Gore won Florida and thus the national election. Jesse Jackson's vow to recount all the state's votes independently will confirm that outcome, although much too late. But Florida was a set-up from start to finish and in that disgraceful charade, the supreme court has foolishly yet definitively connived.

All this leaves a very bad taste. And looking ahead, this narrowest, meanest of results leaves Mr Bush without a clear mandate, without momentum, and with very little authority. There will be no honeymoon for him. It is hard to imagine a less auspicious start to a presidency. To say that he will be forever tainted by the manner of his success, forever denied the legitimacy essential to any head of state, would be to ignore the swift, forgetful pace of modern politics. America clearly wants to move on. The question, amid such divisions, is how? For what canyons of distrust and enmity must be bridged. Mr Bush faces a new congress as acrimoniously split as the electorate and the courts. His ambitious tax cuts are already history; so, too, may be much else in his legislative agenda. Already the Democrats eye the 2002 mid-term elections with a view to revenge. In the meantime, calls for national unity notwithstanding, they can be expected to fight him every step of the way. Lightweight Mr Bush, gabbling nervously amid the wrangling, has looked ever more like a puny frontman for the vested interests of the GOP machine, big business, big defence and big oil. He will need quality help to meet challenges that would sorely tax a more talented politician. While Dick Cheney, his number two, brings much experience, his health is suspect. The vacillating Colin Powell, on the other hand, Mr Bush's likely nominee as secretary of state, has no diplomatic or political track record. Mr Bush may yet come to find the Oval Office a very lonely place.

Mr Gore's defeat is a bitter one. It is deeply personal, and it is hard to see where the vice-president goes from here. Truth be told, he should have won this election easily. Will Democrats really risk him again in 2004? But the defeat is also national. It leaves a country scarred and angry; a country even more alienated and cynical than before about a political process that 50% of the population boycotted last month. It leaves a pressing need for reform, particularly of the electoral college system (which distorted the result as much as did the supreme court); and for a justice department inquiry into the Florida fix. And it leaves in its wake shockingly unfamiliar but very real doubts about the fundamental fairness and honesty of American democracy. In that broad sense, this election was truly a shattering event.

webTitle: Roy Hattersley on the privy council

fields.headline: Let's abolish this absurdity
fields.standfirst:
A member of the privy council calls for the ending of the odd circle which surrounds the monarch

Join the debate online
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley, Endpiece: A member of the privy council calls for the ending of the odd circle which surrounds the monarch.
fields.body:
It would be wrong to pretend that I was not pleased to join the privy council. In truth I was delighted. After "shadowing" Margaret Thatcher for three years, I had hoped to replace her at the Department of Education. But Harold Wilson, offended by a speech in which I had attacked the public schools, exiled me to the Foreign Office to do penance as minister of state. The official letter, telling me that the Queen was "minded" to make me Right Honourable, was, I thought, proof that the prime minister had forgiven me.

I was wrong. Joining the privy council did, however, improve my formal status. As soon as I promised to defend the Queen against "all foreign princes, persons, prelates, states or potentates" I became Right Honourable for life. From then on every postman knew that I was (or had been) a big noise in Whitehall and Westminster. And that is the privy council's principal purpose. Membership is a medal. Old politicians wear the distinction as if it were part campaign ribbon and part wound stripe.

Traditionalists and romantics still pretend that the privy council is more than a footnote to the "dignified" - that is to say outdated - part of our constitution. Harold Wilson once assured Richard Nixon that, because he was addressing ministers who had taken the privy council oath, he could speak freely about nuclear strategy. No doubt the secrets of the Pentagon remained secure. But I doubt if it was the promise "not (to) know or understand of any manner of thing to be attempted, done, or spoken against Her Majesty's person, honour, crown, or dignity royal" which prevented the president's audience from running out of Downing Street to phone the Soviet embassy.

Quoting those words from the privy council's oath is certainly an offence and possibly treason. Members are required to "keep secret all matters committed and revealed unto you or that shall be treated secretly in council". So I should not describe the Gilbertian meeting at which I promised to "defend all jurisdictions, pre-eminences and authorities granted to Her Majesty".

I can, however, reveal that, during the rehearsal which preceded the main event, the secretary to the council felt it necessary to explain why he was anxious about what was to follow. Wallace Rawling, prime minister of New Zealand, had been made Right Honourable in absentia. He would therefore be "sworn" separately. The Queen did not like the privy council to drag on.

Joel Barnett (chief secretary to the Treasury) then explained that he wished to swear his oath of allegiance on an Old Testament. Brian O'Malley (minister of state at the Department of Social Services) added that he must have a Douay Bible. Shamed by their bravery into confessing my own heresy, I exercised the dissenter's right to affirm. That left a judge to perform the usual ritual in the first of five separate ceremonies.

The Queen remained calm. But, as we left the audience chamber, Jim Callaghan, one of the old hands who had been on duty that day, led me towards an archbishop (I think he was York) who was about to do what is required of archbishops before they assume their archdioceses. Putting an avuncular arm round my shoulder, Jim enquired "Have you met Roy Hattersley? Her Majesty had to keep you waiting because he wouldn't swear on the Bible".

In the 25 years since that fateful day, I have attended only one privy council meeting. Like most cabinet ministers I was reluctant to waste my time - though at least (unlike some of my colleagues) I was never required to travel to Balmoral for a pointless ceremony which is, at best, a convenient legal fiction built round the senior ministers, judges and archbishops who become Right Honourable as a matter of course.

At worst the privy council is neither an instrument of baronial tyranny nor the last bastion of monarchist power. It is simply pointless. The usual complaint against it (normally made by Tony Benn) is that it is the institution through which orders in council are made and the royal prerogative exercised - both potential abuses of our parliamentary system. But the blame lies with ministers. The privy council only provides the flummery which camouflages their autocracy.

Orders in council are often no more than the mechanism which activates secondary legislation - clauses of an act of parliament which come into force when the orders are made. The real danger to democracy is the royal prerogative. It began life as the instrument by which the monarch overruled Lords and Commons. But after the sovereignty of parliament was established, ministers, acting in the monarch's name, used the prerogative to legitimise decisions which they took without parliamentary approval.

Ten years ago, a progressive chief constable - who did not wish to change the character of his police force by equipping it with CS gas - was warned that, unless he "voluntarily" accepted the Home Office's instruction, the policy would be imposed on him "under the royal prerogative". There was even some talk of John Major using the device to ratify the Maastricht Treaty if the House of Commons would not pass the necessary resolution.

No government could have survived so gigantic an affront to parliamentary government. But the royal prerogative is still used to legitimise smaller acts of autocracy. In other democracies, appointments to the cabinet are ratified (or not) by the legislature and dates of elections are decided by statute. In Britain, ministers take office and parliament is dissolved under the royal prerogative. Do not blame "the Queen in council". Power lies with politicians. So does the opportunity for power's abuse.

That does not mean that its judicial committee - which meets from time to time to consider cases of especial constitutional significance - is either powerless or pointless. But, like the House of Lords "acting in its judicial capacity", it is just a fancy name for a collection of senior judges. The aura of the privy council is attached to both institutions because of two peculiarly English diseases - the belief that association with the sovereign reinforces authority and the conviction that antiquity increases respect.

So the privy council is not just an anachronism. It is one of those elements in our constitution which, because they have arcane rules and archaic associations, exist to prove that real power lies in places remote from everyday life. The mystery and magic of the monarchy and everything which flows from it are meant to be living proof of the distinction between them and us. The privy council is part of the deferential society. A genuinely radical government - anxious to promote the idea either of equality or meritocracy - would politely suggest to the Queen that she confirmed her desire to modernise the monarchy by announcing that she no longer needed "privy" advisers.

Yet most meetings of the privy council, although shrouded in secrecy, are concerned only with trivia. The one item of business which I recall was "to appoint the chaplain of Wadham College, Oxford", a duty to which the Queen reasonably reacted by asking "Why do I do this?" Michael Foot, lord president of the privy council, was ready with an explanation. "Wadham," he began, "was my college".

There followed a fascinating account of Oxford history from medieval times. We had just arrived at the Reformation when the Queen - with brilliant timing and perfect courtesy - thanked him and declared the privy council over. That is exactly the right attitude towards the whole unnecessary business.

Those Right Honourables

There are currently just over 500 members of the privy council, including all senior members of past and present governments. This "magic circle", with regency offices in Carlton Gardens near Buckingham Palace, has a staff of two dozen officials, mostly dealing with miscellaneous appeals and university matters. The Labour government's leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, has the job of organising regular meetings of privy councillors with the Queen. fields.headline: Allied Domecq swallows Mumm
fields.trailText: Allied Domecq yesterday stepped up its campaign to sabotage the $8bn (£5.5bn) auction of Seagram's drinks business by buying two leading champagne brands distributed by the Canadian firm.
fields.body:
Allied Domecq yesterday stepped up its campaign to sabotage the $8bn (£5.5bn) auction of Seagram's drinks business by buying two leading champagne brands distributed by the Canadian firm.

As it announced a €575m (£350m) deal to buy Perrier-Jouet and Mumm, Allied took a swipe at the way Seagram was conducting the sale of its portfolio.

Allied said it had withdrawn from the international auction because Seagram had insisted on an "unusually onerous" confidentiality letter. One adviser described the document as "utterly unique", adding: "In all my years in the City, I've never seen anything like this."

The letter prevented bidders from making any contact with Seagram's customers, suppliers, distributors and partners for a period of 18 months. Signing such a document could, in theory, have prevented Allied from talking to many of its own customers.

Allied intends to sever Sea gram's rights to distribute Perrier-Jouet and Mumm as soon as it has completed purchase of the brands from the owners, venture capital firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst. Both are top-of-the-range champagnes, and Perrier-Jouet is the third biggest seller in the world.

The move will be a disappointment to the remaining contenders - an alliance between Diageo and Pernod Ricard, and a consortium of Bacardi, Brown-Forman and Vin & Spirit. Allied has already cherry-picked the jewel in Seagram's crown, Captain Morgan rum, although this is subject to a legal challenge.

Diageo and Pernod are the favourites to win the auction, although some sources believe such an outcome could run into regulatory trouble. One said: "The view from the Federal Trade Commission is that they should have blocked the merger of Guinness and Grand Metropolitan to form Diageo. How are they going to react to the company buying 250 more brands?" Allied Domecq's shares fell 2p to 414p.

fields.headline: Börse demands £6m from stock exchange
fields.trailText: An important group of private client stockbrokers yesterday urged the London Stock Exchange to reveal details of takeover bids it had received following a report in the Guardian that it had refused a proposal from Nasdaq, the US hi-tech market.
fields.body:
An important group of private client stockbrokers yesterday urged the London Stock Exchange to reveal details of takeover bids it had received following a report in the Guardian that it had refused a proposal from Nasdaq, the US hi-tech market.

The call by the lobby group Apcims came as relations between the LSE and its one-time merger partner Deutsche Börse deteriorated further when it emerged the German exchange was demanding €10m (£6m) in compensation for their collapsed merger.

Their plans were aborted when Swedish company OM Gruppen launched a hostile bid for the LSE after sensing the level of dissatisfaction among LSE shareholders about the Frankfurt deal.

OM failed to win enough support for LSE shareholders for its bid, but the LSE is regarded as a potential target for a number of other exchanges.

One is said to be Nasdaq, which was rebuffed by Don Cruickshank, the LSE chairman, two weeks ago.

Angela Knight, the chief executive of Apcim, yesterday called on the LSE to make details of the bid known. "If there is a proposition on the table it is one the shareholders have the option to look and decide upon," she said.

webTitle: Railtrack tries to head off criticism

fields.headline: Railtrack tries to head off criticism
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack was last night casting around for new non-executive directors to protect the board from criticism that people at the top have no experience of the industry.
fields.body:
Railtrack was last night casting around for new non-executive directors to protect the board from criticism that people at the top have no experience of the industry.

Approaches have been made to Alan Williams, a senior executive with the Post Office, in charge of corporate affairs, who writes regularly about railways and has a wide knowledge of the sector.

Mr Williams is understood to be interested in the job although he would not want to give up his position at the Post Office, where he has been a leading adviser to the board on how to handle its relationship with the railways, where the Post Office is the biggest customer.

Railtrack's move was seen in the industry as an attempt by the company to buy off its strongest critic. The PO has voiced concerns over Railtrack's decision to commandeer part of the west coast main line over Christmas and its severe restrictions on speed limits.

These have imposed heavy delays on PO rail deliveries. The possible appointment of Mr Williams was also seen as a way for Railtrack to head off legal action by the Post Office for loss of business, now running to millions of pounds.

The hiatus over the strengthening of the board is partly seen as a move by Railtrack to protect itself from charges of incompetence or even corporate manslaughter by outside groups. The arrival of Mr Williams, it is argued, woulld make it difficult for the Post Office to seek compensation against Railtrack.

Changes at senior level at Railtrack have not been achieved smoothly. Richard Middleton, the company's most senior executive, threatened to resign if his position was usurped by a new man from Yorkshire Water, appointed to head Railtrack's operations.

Sir Philip Beck, Railtrack's chairman, is looking for an energetic replacement from next July. Several captains of industry and a number of leading politicians, including Kenneth Clarke, Michael Heseltine and Steven Norris, have all been mentioned for the job.

The company is desperately looking for a well known businessman or politician who can take the heat off Railtrack's chief executive during a crisis to allow him to get on with the job of running the company.

webTitle: Netanyahu takes first steps back to power

fields.headline: Netanyahu takes first steps back to power
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The prospect of the former Israeli leader Binyamin Netanyahu returning to power was strengthened yesterday when a nod of parliamentary approval was given to a new law that would allow him to seek re-election to the office of prime minister in next February's polls even though he is not an MP.
fields.body:
The prospect of the former Israeli leader Binyamin Netanyahu returning to power was strengthened yesterday when a nod of parliamentary approval was given to a new law that would allow him to seek re-election to the office of prime minister in next February's polls even though he is not an MP.

The bill passed 67-35 on first reading, but must go through three more votes before it becomes law and opens the way for the former Likud party boss to challenge Ehud Barak, the current Labour party prime minister.

The knesset vote followed one of the heaviest gunbattles of the past 11 weeks in Gaza, which left four Palestinian policemen dead and dealt another blow to Mr Barak's aspirations of concluding a peace deal before the elections.

The policemen were killed by Israeli forces near the Khan Younis refugee camp in an exchange of gunfire that raged for hours.

Yesterday's hostilities began when Palestinians opened fire on Israeli troops at around 1am. The soldiers returned fire, according to the Israeli army. Palestinians, however, alleged that the fighting began when an Israeli bulldozer tried to remove a sand embankment erected by Palestinians to protect civilians from what they said had been regular Israeli shooting.

Major Yarden Vitikay, the Israeli army spokesman, said the Palestinians had built the embankment to provide cover as they shot at Israelis. The army decided to destroy it after gunmen fired into a classroom at the nearby Neve Dekalim Jewish settlement on Tuesday.

As machine-gun fire and explosions awoke the refugees at Khan Younis, loudspeakers called on residents to confront the Israelis. "We appeal to every man with a weapon to come to defend his land and honour to drive out the Israeli invasion," the loudspeakers urged. Witnesses said up to 1,000 Palestinian gunmen heeded the call.

The Palestinian security chief, General Abdel-Razek al-Majaydeh, warned Israel that any of its soldiers trying to raid Palestinian areas again would not get out alive.

Visiting the camp's hospital, the Palestinian minister of health, Dr Riad Za'anoun, said 33 people, including three children, had been wounded. He said the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, had "been informed of the ugly attack on the people in Khan Younis".

In the West Bank city of Hebron, a Palestinian was shot dead in front of his shop by Israeli soldiers. The militant group Hamas said the man was a member of its military wing and called his killing an assassination.

Mr Netanyahu's return to political office, after resigning his seat last year, has been impeded by a law which says that only members of parliament can stand in February's election. A beleaguered Mr Barak, who was elected last year on a agenda of peace, resigned last Sunday.

The newly proposed law would allow any citizen to run for the prime minister's position in a special election.

Mr Netanyahu, however, is still several steps away from running against Mr Barak, as he has not yet secured his party's nomination. The Likud party primaries are scheduled for next week and the Likud's leader, Ariel Sharon, affirmed that he would be seeking the nomination.

During a speech in Tel Aviv Tuesday, Mr Netanyahu told Likud stalwarts that he would bring a sense of security back to Israel and further accused Mr Barak of trying to block his candidacy. Mr Barak dismissed Mr Netanyahu's promises as "empty talk".

The latest deaths brought to 318 the number of people killed since Palestinians demanding an independent state began an Intifada, or uprising, against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza.

webTitle: Police wives fight flaws and orders

fields.headline: Police wives fight flaws and orders
fields.trailText: It has always been a joke in the barracks: "Dogs welcome; wives tolerated." But the spouses of France's gendarmes no longer see the funny side - and after years of suffering in silence, they are fighting back.
fields.body:
It has always been a joke in the barracks: "Dogs welcome; wives tolerated." But the spouses of France's gendarmes no longer see the funny side - and after years of suffering in silence, they are fighting back.

"We want to be more than just tolerated," said Nathalie Douet, 36, one of 200 wives who have formed a militant group to fight for better conditions. "Alright, we knew more or less what to expect when we married our husbands. But why should these inhumane practices from a bygone age be allowed to continue?"

The Gendarmes' Wives Movement, whose members include lawyers, doctors and teachers, aims to change some of the more absurdly chauvinist traditions acquired during the force's 200 years as a paramilitary police service run by the defence ministry.

"We would like family mail delivered to our letter box, and not to our husbands' desks," said another founding member, Corinne Michaud, 32. "We would like to be able to call a plumber without our husband first having to draw up a report and hand it to his superior. When our friends drop round for lunch, we would like them not to have to leave their identity cards at the entrance to the barracks."

The wives also want new postings in the 100,000-strong force to start at the beginning, not in the middle of, the school year. But most of all, they want to be rid of the over-riding impression that their every move is being watched, all the time.

The women say their initiative has been greeted with sullen suspicion by other gendarmes' wives, and by direct threats to their husbands from the hierarchy. But they remain unbowed.

fields.headline: Russian authorities drop 'Kremlingate' inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The "Kremlingate" corruption investigation - concerning the payment of kickbacks to the family and entourage of the former president, Boris Yeltsin - was closed yesterday by Russian prosecutors who claimed there was not enough information to proceed with the case.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow and  Peter Capella  in Geneva
fields.body:
The "Kremlingate" corruption investigation - concerning the payment of kickbacks to the family and entourage of the former president, Boris Yeltsin - was closed yesterday by Russian prosecutors who claimed there was not enough information to proceed with the case.

Russian and Swiss authorities had been investigating allegations that Russian officials, including the former presidential property manager, Pavel Borodin, were paid millions of dollars in bribes by the Swiss-based construction firms Mabetex and Mercata Trading to secure lucrative Kremlin refurbishment contracts.

Mr Yeltsin's wife, Naina, and his daughters, Tatyana Dyachenko and Elena Okulova, were originally implicated in the case, suspected of having received credit cards guaranteed by the director of Mabetex.

Announcing the closure of the inquiry, Ruslan Tamayev, the new head of the investigating group in the chief prosecutor's office, said a decision had been made not to open a criminal case against members of the ex-president's family on the grounds that there was no evidence of a crime.

Earlier this year, Swiss magistrates issued an international arrest warrant for money laundering against Mr Borodin, who was suspected of funnelling bribe money through Swiss bank accounts. Beghjet Pacolli, the Mabetex head, also faces money-laundering charges. Both men have denied the accusations.

Throughout the investigation, Swiss prosecutors have repeatedly complained that their Russian colleagues did not appear to be vigorously pursuing the case. But Mr Tamayev claimed yesterday that, in fact, it was the Swiss who had failed to provide sufficient evidence to support the case.

"Since 1998 we have been waiting for a response to our inquiries from them," he said. "But until now they have been unable to answer all our questions."

The former prosecutor who initiated the case, Yury Skuratov, expressed weary resignation when he heard it had been closed. He said he had long been convinced that the case had no future because "numerous government officials" were caught up in it.

The government "does not want to admit that corruption has penetrated to the highest reaches of the Russian leadership", he added.

Mr Skuratov pointed out that Mr Tamasov had been promoted just a few days before making yesterday's announcement.

Mr Skuratov's own career took a rather unfortunate turn after he launched the anti-corruption case; when several attempts by Mr Yeltsin to fire him failed, a security service video showing the former prosecutor having sex with two young prostitutes was aired on state television. He was suspended from his duties.

Several other senior officials in the prosecutor's office have also been sacked during the investigation.

Swiss magistrates said they would press on with an independent investigation into Russian money-laundering in Switzerland, which they launched in frustration at the reluctance of their Russian counterparts to pursue the affair.

Their inquiries are likely to focus on more than £40m in commission payments made by Mercata Trading, a company linked to Mabetex.

Swiss prosecutors have alleged that Mr Borodin's office paid Mercata $492m (£340m) to renovate official buildings, including the Kremlin. Their investigations into the use of credit cards by the Yeltsin family are also to be dropped.

webTitle: Why the need for a 'Grandparents' section

fields.headline: The new Grandparents section
fields.standfirst: Matt Seaton, our parents editor, explains why the Guardian is today launching a monthly grandparents page
fields.trailText: Matt Seaton, our parents editor, explains why the Guardian is today launching a monthly grandparents page
fields.body:
'We are a grandmother," Margaret Thatcher once famously said. In fact, one in three adults is - or are, if you prefer - a grandparent. Despite the fact that many women now postpone having their first child until they are 30, the average age to become a grandparent is still just 50. Most of these maintain regular contact with their grandchildren: as today's Guardian poll shows, well over a third of Britain's grandparents put in the equivalent of a three-day week looking after grandchildren. It seems only proper, then, that 40% of parents admit that their working lives would be impossible without the childcare provided by their parents.

Demographic change is fuelling the rise of grandparents as a social force: people are living longer, they are more affluent in middle age and retirement, and they lead more active lives. While much has been said about children getting old younger, there is a counterphenomenon of pensioners getting young older. My parents' generation - children of the 30s and 40s - were lucky if they had both parents, let alone one or two grandparents. Half a century of medical advances - and no major wars - mean that for my children's generation, children of the 90s, it is common to have three or even four grandparents.

Because nearly half of marriages end in divorce and single parents now represent a quarter of families with children, grandparents are being dragooned into helping with the grandkids as never before - as mother's helpers, cost-free childminders, even surrogate parents. As Shirley Lowe's article attests, nearly half of the childcare in this country is provided by grandparents - a vast iceberg of domestic labour that is unpaid, unseen and largely unrecognised. Grandparenting is required to be its own reward. Freely given, in every sense, this time may be, but it also brings its pressures and resentments: a recent poll found that four out of 10 grandparents wished for a life with fewer family responsibilities.

The sociologist Michael Young, who with Peter Willmott wrote a seminal study of family and kinship in London's east end in the 1950s, has observed the emergence of a new type of extended family. The 21st-century family is not extended laterally - as those 50s working-class families were, with many members of the same generation living in close proximity - but vertically. The ties that bind now leapfrog generations, from grandparent to grandchild.

And those ties are very real. For grandparents, the experience is one to savour: now there is time to enjoy the children of their children. For many, it may even seem like a second chance at parenting. For parents, too, presenting their mother and father with grandchildren is a deeply felt rite of passage, a sign that they have assumed the mantle of adult responsibility. Grandchildren provide a new focus for family relationships, rekindling a kind of intimacy that is exciting and gratifying to all. Grandparenting offers the chance to reunite generations separated by a gulf of cultural experience.

The cultural affiliations of different generations are as significant a factor behind the new grandparents as demographic shifts: grandparenting has become important because the baby boomers are doing it. That peculiarly self-conscious and contentious generation that came of age in the 1960s, which grew up with pop, protest and the pill, put off having children longer than their parents had while they enjoyed an extended adolescence. But history and human evolution have caught up with them willy-nilly. Think about it: Mick Jagger is a grandad, for God's sake! No wonder we're getting interested in this inter-generational business. Grandparenting is groovy, man.

This year saw Britain's first grandparenting conference, yet its organiser, the Family Policy Studies Centre, acknowledges that the study of grandparenting is still (improbable phrase) in its infancy. Policy-makers, certainly, are behind the curve. Last week the government published a green paper which should eventually bring the UK more or less in line with other European countries on the provision of leave for working parents. But the Asda supermarket chain is a step ahead, recently introducing a seven-day "grandparents' leave" allowance and enabling staff to opt for further unpaid leave of up to three months after the birth of a grandchild.

The Guardian has always tried to recognise when the emerging forms of social and cultural change have reached critical mass - and to give them a voice. In the 1960s, on its women's pages, it became the first national newspaper to seriously engage with feminism. In 1992, it launched its parents pages to tackle growing concerns with the balance between work and children. Now it is time for grandparents to have a space of their own.

This is why every month the Guardian will now be publishing a grandparents page in G2. Parents constantly wax lyrical about the pleasures and pains of parenthood. fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Highlands
fields.trailText: Highlands
fields.body:
There's no wilderness left in the north of Scotland, but there's plenty of wildness, and it's easy to experience it, depending on your point of view. Some find it on the high tops where the ptarmigan seeks refuge, others by visiting remote islands with rookeries of grey seals. Others find it in the remnants of old Caledonian pine forest with crested tits and capercaillie.

This wildness may be easy to experience, but to define it is another matter. So I was interested to read a recent angling book, Scotland's Classic Wild Trout Waters, because I've experienced plenty of wildness when I've been casting the fly. The author, Lesley Crawford, is no stranger to wildness, as she lives in Caithness. She lays great emphasis on "untamed trout havens", differentiating between native trout that may have been there unadulterated for thousands of years, and wild trout, which can be second or third generation stocked trout.

These havens, which could be classed as wildness, have no influence from fish farms or from introduced fish like minnows and pike, and no pollution. When writing about the special lochs, she uses the word "ambience" to describe trout waters. In winter the waters can look cold and dark. In summer it seems a completely different world.

This book transported me back to the wild places where I've fished. The limestone lochs of Assynt watched over by hills like Suilven and Cul Mor, Loch Sionascaig where the magical ferox trout lie, and lochs near Durness that hold arctic char. There was, and is, a wildness in these places. As Henry Thoreau said, "In wildness is the preservation of the world."

fields.headline: A leaf from life's book
fields.standfirst:
Genetic scientists have deciphered the text of a nondescript little weed. With it, they can read all nature's growing secrets, reports Tim Radford
Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Genetic scientists have deciphered the text of a nondescript little weed. With it, they can read all nature's growing secrets, reports Tim Radford
fields.body:
A rabidopsis thaliana is a little member of the mustard and cabbage family sometimes called thalecress. It grows fast, and it grows almost everywhere. It takes six weeks to go from seed to seed, and it has been found from the Arctic to the Cape Verde Islands in the tropics. It has no commercial value whatsoever - but it is about to turn the world of agriculture upside down.

Yesterday, in a triumph celebrated in London, Brussels, Washington and Tokyo, scientists around the world celebrated the completion of the entire DNA sequence of arabidopsis. This sequence is relatively small - it is about 100th the size of the genome of maize, for example - but the challenge was still on an epic scale. The answers set to emerge from systematic study of this genome, too, are epic.

Caroline Dean, of the John Innes Centre at Norwich, studied the DNA of arabidopsis and found a gene called Frigida. This is the tiny piece of genetic machinery that stops the plant from flowering until after the winter.

"So many plants have a strategy to overwinter vegetatively - they keep from flowering while it is cold," she says. "That effectively means you flower in the spring. That process is called vernalisation. That is a process breeders have used extensively in all sorts of crops, for example to generate winter wheat and spring wheat."

Winter wheat needs two or three months of cold temperature before flowering. It can be sown in September or October and a nice warm week in November isn't suddenly going to generate flowering at the wrong time. Breeders have developed this trait both in cereals and vegetables. Parsley is valuable only until it flowers; sugar beet becomes a problem once it has bolted. "What the genes do to keep the flowering off and how on earth the plant figures out it has had two months of cold temperature was really a complete mystery," she says. "We decided to choose that as a topic and unpick that in arabidopsis."

There are sets of genes that prevent flowering, and Frigida is just one of them. It is, however, the only one that delays flowering until after a cold spell. But this raised other interesting questions for the John Innes researchers. "We then started to look at the natural variation in arabidopsis. There is a wide range of habitats and there is a wide range of flowering time. This is an adaptive trait of great significance, if you flower at the wrong time, you are scuppered."

All this variation turned out to be due to changes in just one gene - Frigida. "So we have now unpicked the basis between, effectively, winter and spring arabidopsis, so if we go into wheat and sugar beet and some of these other things where the same thing has evolved, are we seeing the same changes?"

The guess is yes. Flowering time is a very complicated piece of machinery. Yet Dr Dean thinks the same sets of genes will be interacting, perhaps in a subtly different way, for the same function. You could account, she believes, for all the flowering time variation in all plants by subtle changes in the genetic model build up for arabidopsis. "For me the genome sequence is a beginning. I have had this debate, people say, OK, arabidopsis is done, let's move on to something else. I think, whoa, this is just the beginning of being able to unpick the whole workings of arabidopsis."

The plant has very specific recognition systems: it can see a particular disease, react and nip an infection in (for once the perfect phrase) the bud. Resistance genes have been identified and cloned: these can recognise bits of the invading fungus or bacterium, elicit a response, turn off genes, kill the infected cell and stop the infection spreading outwards. Arabidopsis will start to answer questions about plant breeding, it will lead to a new understanding of plant breeding, it will be a testbed for genetic engineering, and it will throw light on the process of evolution itself.

But for the Horticulture Research International at Wellesbourne in Warwick it will also answer questions about brassicas. It is a family member, close to kale, cabbages, calabrese, broccoli, kohlrabi, Brussels sprout and cauliflower, which in turn are all one species. These are all descended from some cliff-dwelling, kale-like progenitors from the Mediterranean region, and then honed into astonishingly different varieties by centuries of selection and cross-breeding. Together, these plants were worth probably £200m to the UK; one other brassica, oilseed rape, is worth more than £400m to the UK economy. They will all soon be indebted to the knowledge won from their tiny cousin.

"Things which affect growth of crops, their post-harvest ability to survive on the shelves or be resistant to disease, can be studied in detail in arabidopsis and we are now applying that in brassicas," says Graham King of the HRI. "Brassicas have larger chromosomes, more DNA and longer life cycles, so that's why they haven't been used as a model system. But it is now very easy for us to transfer information. So basically, when we read down and look at the DNA sequence or order of genes in a brassica chromosome, we get a lot of information and guidance, signposts if you like, from the arabidopsis genome sequence."

Brassica crops are sprayed with insecticides three or four times a year, and once with a fungicide. If people don't spray, losses are high. There are natural resistance genes out there in the brassicas, waiting to be identified and transferred into the most high-yielding strains. The trick is to identify the genes in the thalecress. With that knowledge, breeders will know what to look for in the brassicas.

"We have collections, which we have been putting together over 20 years, of a wide range of vegetable crops," says Dr King. "Now we can go in and analyse in a detailed way. We can go out now with that knowledge of the key genes which affect where things grown, how they perform afterwards, and say, where is the diversity? Can we harness that diversity before we lose it? Crop systems are becoming more and more homogenised. There is a thing called genetic erosion: we are losing a lot of the diversity. Now we can help breeders harness that diversity."

webTitle: UN blames west for lack of troops

fields.headline: UN blames west for lack of troops
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The ability of the United Nations to mount future peace-keeping operations is at risk because of a lukewarm international response to pleas for troops for Sierra Leone.
fields.body:
The ability of the United Nations to mount future peace-keeping operations is at risk because of a lukewarm international response to pleas for troops for Sierra Leone.

A source at the UN in New York said yesterday that a resolution proposed in the summer by the secretary-general, Kofi Annan, to raise the number of UN peace-keepers in Sierra Leone from 13,000 to 20,000 has had to be "put on a backburner".

Western diplomats are sceptical that the current ceasefire in Sierra Leone will hold in the next few weeks as UN forces attempt to move into areas controlled by the rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF) to monitor the ceasefire.

Mr Annan is said to be disappointed at the lack of countries, especially western nations, willing to commit troops.

A UN official said: "It is reminiscent of other African peace-keeping operations, not least Rwanda, when we were begging countries for troops and no one was forthcoming."

He added that many developing countries were unhappy at contributing troops because the US and Europeans were holding back: "Western countries [in the UN security council] are making decisions about sending in troops and expecting developing countries to provide troops."

He exempted Britain, whose contribution in Sierra Leone he described as faultless. Britain moved in to buttress the UN forces in the spring and has become increasingly entangled in the conflict.

Indian and Jordanian forces, who between them account for more than 4,000 troops, are pulling out. Kenyan, Ghanaian and Bangladeshis are due to replace them, but this has yet to be finalised.

The UN asked the Indians, who had been involved in a row with Nigerian troops, to stay but they agreed to only one concession, to phase their withdrawal.

Ukraine has promised to send a specialist unit and talks are also taking place with Pakistan and Nepal.

The transition represents a vulnerable time for peace-keepers but the UN says it has no intelligence that the RUF might want to exploit this by mounting an offensive.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, who also asked the Indians to stay, phoned European Union partners asking them to contribute troops but to no avail. Approaches have also been made to Turkey.

A Foreign Office spokesman played down the issue, saying that some other European countries who might have contributed had already promised troops to a peace-keeping force for the Eritrean-Ethiopian border.

The spokesman said force numbers were not the issue: "Focusing on a finite number of troops is pointless unless they have been properly trained and have a proper command structure. That is much more important than actual numbers." He added that Nigerian troops, currently being trained by US forces, were also due to go to Sierra Leone and would take the numbers beyond 13,000.

Although a ceasefire is holding, the RUF is unlikely to give up the key diamond-producing areas. Most of the diamonds end up in neighbouring Liberia, whose president, Charles Taylor, has been accused of supporting the rebels.

A UN panel set up to look at diamonds in Sierra Leone is due to publish its findings tomorrow and is set to criticise the part played by Mr Taylor.

The UN is then likely to apply "smart" sanctions, such as refusing visa applications by Mr Taylor and his inner-circle and putting a ban on diamonds from Liberia.

The UN needs a success in Sierra Leone. Without one, the UN will find it even harder to gather forces for the more complex conflict in the Congo.

fields.standfirst: Chatham
fields.trailText: Chatham
fields.body:
Ah, Chatham in Kent. One of the three Medway towns I believe, the others being Rochester and Gillingham. Yair.

And once famous for the Royal Naval dockyard (pictured) which was closed down in 1984. Yair. Wotevva.

Would I be right in thinking that the young Charles Dickens lived there at one time? U wot? Gail Porter more like.

Ah, ha. I think I know that way of speaking. You must be one of these new Chatham girls I've been hearing so much about recently. Dirty ol'horey annas, u mean.

Often to be seen wandering Chatham high street, window-shopping because you've spent all your dole money on jewellery. Nice earrings by the way. Do they need to be quite so big? Ahrrrr in ney luvlee. Jingall jangall, innit. Dare gorwljus.

In fact, some of the tabloids are saying Chatham girls are the new Essex girls. The ultimate in bad taste and foul language, you wear threequarter length fake leather coats and trainers. Yor doin my nut in.

And while you're out stalking the high street in pairs with pink mobiles permanently clamped to your heads, your boyfriends are to be found racing their souped-up cars around the Toys 'R' Us carpark. Me luvvaz got un x r free, an itz a wun a dem conver'eebal wunz unnit lite

Actually, I understand that because I've been to a website which takes the mick out of you lot: Chatham Girl. It gives a fairly extensive glossary of Chatham expressions. Yair?

Not everyone is amused though. Town councillor Paul Godwin has called the website "offensive and sexist". Saaink like that.

Perhaps we should be concentrating on Chatham's seafaring heritage. Rite. Oy maaeet, gotta spayr fag?

Sorry, don't smoke. Ass all rite den, innit.

Not to be confused with: Eh? Yor confusing me. Wot evva ar u on?

fields.headline: Phone mast protest grows
fields.standfirst: Special report: mobile phone fears
fields.trailText: A national campaign was launched yesterday to bring together 100 local groups seeking planning controls over mobile telephone masts so that health effects can be taken into account.
fields.body:
A national campaign was launched yesterday to bring together 100 local groups seeking planning controls over mobile telephone masts so that health effects can be taken into account.

British planning law over mobile phone masts is the most lax in Europe, with nothing to prevent 20,000 planned new masts being built in residential areas and on schools.

A meeting at the Commons yesterday was told the priority was a change in the law so that local people could object to masts on health grounds, since there was increasing evidence that radiation from them was a hazard. Masts under 15 metres do not require planning permission and objections to those over that height can only be made on amenity grounds.

Mast Action UK wants the masts a safe distance from the vulnerable, such as children. In Europe and the US there are 500 metre exclusion zones.

The meeting heard that new organisations to oppose the masts were appearing all over the country.

Debbie Collins, of Bexley, south London, has kept her daughter Rhiannon, seven, off school for 18 months because of a mast next to her classroom and was handing out leaflets encouraging other parents to educate their children to protect their health.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: It's a brake with the future | Who has the first word?
fields.body:
It's a brake with the future
Britain has just announced £250m for three new key science areas . But the Californians have just announced £620m for three new California institutes for science and innovation. The idea is that these institutes at Los Angeles, San Diego, and San Francisco will be a magnet for the best and brightest.Larry Smarr of University of California San Diego foresees sensors in bridges, cars and even people, transmitting information about stress, or earthquakes. "Wouldn't it be nice if you got a call on your cell phone that said 'Hello, we thought you'd like to know that your right front brake will fail in about 100 miles'?" he says.

Who has the first word?
The Oxford English Dictionary may not have the last word on the first use of a term. Yale Law School word historian Fred Shapiro says that the phrase "personal computer" first appeared in a Hewlett Packard advert in Science in October 1968. This is eight years before the OED's first identified use. The US journal, Science ( sciencenow.sciencemag.org ), also claims verbal priority for genotype (1897), cryogenics (1902), chain reaction (1910), geneticist (1912), positron (1933), molecular biology (1941), H-bomb (1950) and test ban (1956). The country that gave the world microchip (1969) also claims precedence for Agent Orange (1969) and global warming (1971).

Rock and a hard place
Applied Marine Technologies, an American firm based in Dominica, is growing 25,000 coral pieces in 128 shallow tanks, each containing 250 gallons of seawater. Balls of coral are to be flown to Mustique to be bolted into specially prepared bases on a reef damaged by Hurricane Lenny last year. Harold Hudson, of Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary, says: "My concern is we might be raising pretty little bouquets of coral in the hothouse, but putting them into an environment that is not conducive to coral health can be problematic."
