webTitle: Conservative judges faced possible conflicts of interest

fields.headline: Conservative judges faced possible conflicts of interest
fields.standfirst:
Judiciary Rightwinger feared for career under Gore
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: More than that of any other case before the supreme court, the outcome of Bush v Gore has had a direct impact on the future of the judiciary.
fields.body:
More than that of any other case before the supreme court, the outcome of Bush v Gore has had a direct impact on the future of the judiciary.

No one predicted that the conservative profile of the court would have a direct influence on the election's outcome, and the experience has exposed the intensely political culture in which the nine judges live and work.

Here are some of the question marks about conflict of interest that now hang over the court.

Antonin Scalia

The leading conservative ideologue on the court, he had hung his reputation on the defence of state rights and a strict reading of the constitution limiting the "judicial activism" of the court. On this occasion, those principles seem to have taken a back seat, and the 64-year-old Reagan appointee led the charge to reverse the Florida court's decision and to get involved in the outcome of the election. Mr Bush's election could have a direct bearing on Mr Scalia's career. Earlier this year he told the Washingtonian magazine that if Al Gore won the election he would retire as he would have no chance of winning the coveted position of chief justice.

One of his sons, Eugene, is a partner in the Washington office of Ted Olson, who acted for Mr Bush in the two cases he brought to the court in the past two weeks.

Clarence Thomas

Justice Thomas is also a Reagan appointee and another rightwing ideologue. As is his custom he stayed silent during oral hearings but as usual he supported Mr Scalia's position.

There were calls for him to withdraw after revelations that his wife was leading a recruitment effort for the future Bush administration on behalf of a rightwing pressure group, the Heritage Foundation.

Sandra Day O'Connor

Another Reagan appointee and a potential swing vote on the court who did not swing. In the past she has differed from other conservatives on abortion rights. But in the oral hearings on Monday she appeared to put the blame for the proliferation of questionable ballots on the voter rather than the voting system.

In the New York Times liberal columnist Maureen Dowd noted that Ms O'Connor's husband, John, was a member of the Bohemian Grove club, whose rich and powerful men go into the woods for "male bonding" sessions which reportedly include nudity and communal urination. Members include George Bush Sr, Mr Thomas and Mr Scalia.

fields.headline: Quantum leap in the dark
fields.standfirst: A century ago today, Max Planck looked into an abstruse subject and sparked a physics revolution.  Graham Farmelo reports
fields.trailText: A century ago today, Max Planck looked into an abstruse subject and sparked a physics revolution. Graham Farmelo reports
fields.body:
Basic science more than pays for itself through its technological spin-offs, right? Most politicians seem to take a lot of convincing. So let us switch off our PCs and let the politicians see what life is like without the information revolution, which is based on a fundamental idea revealed exactly 100 years ago today - quantum theory. The first quantum theory emerged from the brain of a leading German theorist, Max Planck.

He was working with a group of government-funded experimenters investigating a subject so laughably abstruse that most people would be amazed it could be of any interest to anyone outside academia. On December 14, 1900, the 42-year-old Max Planck stood before his colleagues at the German Physical Society in Berlin to report on a new piece of work. He was laying the foundation stone in quantum theory, which eventually taught us that nature at the sub-microscopic level is granular, not smooth. As every physics student learns today, the energy of an atom jiggling around in a solid is quantised - its values are discrete, they don't vary smoothly as we might expect from looking at energy on the everyday scale. But all that would have been news to Planck a century ago.

His first quantum theory was a brilliantly cobbled together lash-up, designed to make theory fit data taken by his experimenter colleagues. He wanted to derive, from first principles, a formula for the comparative brightness of each colour in the electromagnetic spectrum from a tiny hole in a special oven at a range of steady temperatures.

Planck found that the only way he could explain the data was to savage some orthodox theoretical ideas. He had to assume that the total energy of all the atoms in the wall of the atoms, at each frequency of vibration, came in discrete lumps, or "quanta".

Planck was a deeply conservative thinker. He introduced the quantum idea unwillingly and against his instinct to stick with proven theoretical ideas. He later said: "I did not give it much thought except for this: that I had to obtain a positive result, under any circumstances and at whatever cost."

True to this indifference, he scarcely published anything else on the quantum for the next four-and-a-half years. But during that time he tried hard to use pre-quantum ideas to understand a new quantity (now called Planck's constant h ) that he had introduced as part of his new theory. He failed because h was a truly fundamental constant, not derivable from another theory - the only such constant to be introduced in the entire 20th century. It now features in almost every equation of quantum theory.

Planck loathed the very idea of an uprising against the classical scientific ideas about energy that he cherished. The true beginner of the quantum revolution was Albert Einstein, who read of Planck's quantum idea and studied it while he was working in the Swiss Patent Office. In 1905, Einstein wrote a paper that gave the great Planck a physics lesson, correcting a serious error in his early quantum derivation, and putting forward the idea that the energy of light, and all other radiation, comes in quanta. Planck was a huge admirer of Einstein, whom he dubbed "the new Copernicus", but he abominated Einstein's idea of radiation quanta and went to his grave in 1947 unconvinced.

By the late 1920s, other physicists had come up with a fully fledged quantum theory of the atom. Quantum theory has since formed the basis of our understanding of the micro-world, enabling technologists to develop increasingly effective transistors, microprocessors, lasers and fibre-optic cables. The highlight of the theory's technological applications occurred in 1947, when a group of physicists (including the quantum theorist John Bardeen) invented the transistor, one of the components of microprocessors, which power every PC.

But the theorists could never have begun the revolution without experimenters. They, in turn, would not have been able to take their results without state-of-the-art facilities in their institution, the Imperial Institute of Physics and Technology. Founded by the German government and the wealthy industrialist, Werner von Siemens, the institution later became the model for the UK's National Physical Laboratory.

The institute was set up to preserve German's industrial pre-eminence. The experiments that Planck's friends were doing were designed to help the German heating and gas-lighting industries understand how lights radiate heat, and so how to make these devices more efficient. It turned out to be the perfect technology foresight project. But, as usual, the relationship between the foreseen benefits and the pay-off was tenuous.

So would you consider switching off your PC to con template the impact of fundamental research? I thought not. But next time your machine goes down and you are cursing, spare a thought for today's underfunded quark and string theorists, Planck's successors. What might be the spin-offs of their research in the year 2100?

 Graham Farmelo is head of science communication at the Science Museum. He is editor of a collection of essays, It Must Be Beautiful, published next year by Granta.

webTitle: Interventionist approach will be the first casualty of new US regime

fields.headline: Interventionist approach will be the first casualty of new regime
fields.standfirst:
Foreign policy Advisers move to quell alarm in Europe

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: When George W Bush was given his first CIA briefing last week, the event prompted a cartoon of him being shown a map and patiently taught the names of major countries. For America's allies, the humour is worryingly close to the truth.
fields.body:
When George W Bush was given his first CIA briefing last week, the event prompted a cartoon of him being shown a map and patiently taught the names of major countries.

For America's allies, the humour is worryingly close to the truth. Mr Bush has been abroad only half a dozen times. Any references to foreign policy on the campaign stump betrayed traces of contempt for Nato allies - accused of not pulling their weight - and distrust of Russia and China.

Foreign policy is likely to be made by a team of advisers inherited from his father. It is striking in its military complexion: Dick Cheney is a former defence secretary and Colin Powell headed the joint chiefs of staff.

The humanitarian interventionist approach of the Clinton years is likely to be the first victim. The military dislikes peacekeeping, as another likely Bush adviser, Condoleezza Rice, made clear when she suggested that the US should withdraw from the Balkans and arrange a geographical "division of labour" with Nato allies.

That triggered alarm in Europe, which already shoulders three-quarters of Balkan deployments. There was also concern that such a division of labour would split and fatally weaken Nato. Ms Rice and the rest of the foreign policy team quickly moved to reassure European leaders that a Bush White House would make no hasty moves but the incident has left uncertainty and apprehension in its wake.

The change in administration is also likely to have a sharp impact on relations with Russia. One of the first foreign policy decisions facing the new White House will be how to respond to Moscow's unilateral decision earlier this year to expand arms sales to Iran. Mr Bush's advisers have promised to take a less indulgent line than Bill Clinton.

Relations with China are also likely to cool. The Bush team has been far less ambiguous than its predecessors about Taiwan, which claims independence from the mainland. Mr Bush has offered the island solid security guarantees.

There is much less debate over the effect of another key plank in the Bush platform - the implementation and expansion of the national missile defence (NMD) network, an anti-ballistic system which, like Ronald Reagan's Star Wars plan, is supposed to provide an umbrella against the threat of sudden attack.

After a string of test failures Mr Clinton put off a final decision on NMD, which Moscow, Beijing and most US allies see as destabilising and a clear violation of the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty. The Bush strategy is to pursue an expanded NMD network even if it means abandoning the ABM accord.

webTitle: Can a system which allows the winner to lose go unreformed?

fields.headline: Can a system which allows the winner to lose go unreformed?
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: These are the questions that will keep Al Gore up at night - tonight and maybe for the rest of his life. What if he had fought his campaign just a tad differently, sending Bill Clinton to fight for his home state of Arkansas, whose 11 electoral college votes alone would have been enough to make Gore president?
fields.body:
These are the questions that will keep Al Gore up at night - tonight and maybe for the rest of his life. What if he had fought his campaign just a tad differently, sending Bill Clinton to fight for his home state of Arkansas, whose 11 electoral college votes alone would have been enough to make Gore president?

What if he had sunk just a little more energy into his own home turf of Tennessee, whose 11 electoral votes he also lost to George W Bush?

What if he had found a way to reach the supporters of the Green candidate, Ralph Nader, just 1,000 of whom switching sides in Florida would have made all the difference?

Or what of all those events beyond his control? What if Theresa LePore, the well-intentioned election official in Florida's Palm Beach County, had not tried to help the elderly in her region with a large-print voting form that metamorphosed into the now notoriously confusing "butterfly" ballot paper? What if she had left well alone; wouldn't that have bagged more than 20,000 votes for Al Gore?

Even with all that damage done before election day, what else might have been done differently afterwards? What if the good people of Palm Beach had not taken a day off for Thanksgiving, thereby making their recount come in too late to be included in the final, certified figure? What if officials in Miami-Dade county had not been so rattled by a Republican near-riot, protesters pounding on the doors of the counting room, that they suspended their effort when only a fifth of the votes had been recounted?

And, in the last days, what if Gore's lawyer, David Boies, had done more to convince the supreme court's waverers that December 12 was not an iron deadline - that there was plenty of time to conclude a recount by the real deadline of December 18?

What if, what if, what if? These questions may well plague Al Gore, forcing him to sweat through the nights of the next four years, weighing on his heart as he sees Bush - a man he regards as his political and intellectual inferior - swearing the oath of office next month, delivering the state of the union address or generally enjoying a job Gore be lieves rightfully belongs to him. Perhaps these nagging questions will act as a spur, forcing an astonishingly determined man to fight on to the next round: a grudge match against President Bush in 2004. But maybe they will drag him down, torturing him still when the rest of America has moved on.

Unless the rest of America does not move on so easily. For these 36 long days have taken their toll on the United States, exposing to the light failings and divisions within the country which the prosperity of the past eight years had done much to conceal. The presidential contest of 2000 became the election that wouldn't die - and the pain it has caused may not fade quickly.

First, there will be the bitterness, felt keenest among Democratic partisans but shared, too, by many of the 50m-plus Americans who cast their ballots for Al Gore. A clean knock-out blow on November 7 would have been hard, but they would have lived with it. But what happened in the early hours of yesterday morning does not feel like a fair defeat. "It was a raw seizure of power," said one Clinton administration official, insisting that five Republican-appointed judges had in effect anointed George W Bush to the presidency - by refusing a count of legal votes "because they feared the result".

Now Republicans will control all three branches of government - White House and both chambers of Congress - for the first time in nearly 50 years. And yet the arguments of the court majority were so weak, so full of holes, that nothing in the final ruling can reassure Democrats that in the end fairness, however harsh, prevailed. They will for ever doubt the legitimacy of the government that rules them.

For Gore and his supporters will look back on these five long weeks as a series of Republican attempts - in one court or other - to stop citizens' votes being counted for fear of what they might reveal. Whether it was the constant delays that kept volunteers stewing in the heat of Palm Beach county, stopping them counting when time was already precious, or the endless procedures in assorted courts - county, circuit or supreme, state and federal - it all boiled down to one theme. The Republicans did not want all Florida's votes to be counted, and that has offended American democrats - with both a large and a small D. The talk of a virtual coup d'état will grow.

Others less committed will also hold long memories of these 36 days of postelection madness. It was in these weeks, for example, that they got their first glimpse of how their new president reacts in a crisis. It was not a pretty sight.

For Bush seemed to crack under pressure. The symbolic image was - and will remain - the boil that bubbled up on his cheek a day or two after polling. The image stuck because it seemed to fit a man barely able to handle stress.

Instead he headed almost instantly for his Texas ranch. Even his friends admit that Bush did not follow the postelection campaign: while Gore watched the supreme court on CNN, Bush was in the gym. Indeed, the clearest impression to have emerged of Bush these past weeks is of an exercise fanatic - a man who has replaced his much-documented earlier addiction to alcohol with a fitness compulsion.

There was more revealing imagery. The lead was taken throughout by James Baker, the veteran hardman and loyal retainer of the Bush dynasty, and Dick Cheney, the vice president-to-be and former defence secretary to Bush's father. Baker did the groundwork in Florida, while Cheney sorted out the transition. The impression formed of a Bush administration run by Daddy's friends, with George W as the callow youth allowed to serve as frontman - a dauphin in a restoration monarchy. As one acerbic New York columnist put it, Baker, Cheney, and the former Gulf war general Colin Powell are the "grown-ups who keep sending poor George W off to play".

That's how it was during this strange period of election extra-time - and that's how it may well be for four more years. Bush will get to play with the toys - Air Force One, the White House situation room - while Daddy's country club friends do what the hell they like.

Gore, by contrast, appeared like a new man in the post-election twilight. Americans had known that he was stubborn - that "he would do anything to get elected". But they also saw an Al Gore who remained apparently calm and smiling, even under the most intense pressure.

Among Democrats who had previously had their doubts about the vice president, his stock began to rise. His doggedness was an asset: if that's how hard he would fight for his job, they wondered, imagine how he would battle for America.

That perception, coupled with the belief that he was robbed, might act as the rocket fuel for a second Gore attempt on the White House in 2004. It is rare in the television era for a failed nominee to get a second chance, but everything about this contest was rare, if not unprecedented. Besides, Americans love a good story, and the sheer narrative appeal of a Bush-Gore rematch may prove irresistible.

But the real legacy of the surreal days of autumn 2000 may well outlive both of these flawed men. Americans may finally look back on this episode as the moment when they realised they had to start taking their own medicine.

For some Americans are already arguing that the US can no longer travel the world, telling smaller, weaker nations to embrace democracy, when their own leader has been installed in a courtroom fix. Instead, they might have to make some changes.

There could be a flood of claims from voters saying that the systems of their particular state were also patchy and therefore unconstitutional, under the new standard set by the supreme court. The result may well be a drumbeat for a modern, standardised voting system - using new technology - across the country.

More fundamentally, Americans are coming to see their own constitution more clearly. For the second time in two years, that 224-year-old document has been strained to breaking point as it was forced to apply to the 21st century. As with the impeachment affair, a text written for an age of horse carriages and quill pens had to cope with the demands of satellite TV and 24-hour news cycles.

It was revealed to be creaking at the edges. Now, at last, Americans may see that a system which can allow the loser to win and the winner to lose cannot remain unchanged. Perhaps they will realise at last that the beauty of their constitution is that it contains within it the possibility of its own reform. Americans have that power.

After the long, Alice-in-Wonderland autumn of 2000, they may finally decide to use it.


What happens next

December 18 Electoral college members meet in each state capital and send votes to Washington.

December 27 Deadline for arrival of electoral college votes.

January 3 New Congress convenes in Washington.

January 5 Senate and House of Representatives count electoral college votes in joint session, and hear any objections.

Gore will preside in twin roles as US vice president and president of the Senate.

January 20 Inauguration day. George W Bush and vice president-elect Dick Cheney are sworn in.

They take office.

What if he had fought his campaign just a tad differently, sending Bill Clinton to fight for his home state of Arkansas, whose 11 electoral college votes alone would have been enough to make Gore president? What if he had found a way to reach the supporters of the Green candidate, Ralph Nader, just 1,000 of whom switching sides in Florida would have made all the difference? What if she had left well alone; wouldn't that have bagged more than 20,000 votes for Al Gore? Even with all that damage done before election day, what else might have been done differently afterwards? What if the good people of Palm Beach had not taken a day off for Thanksgiving, thereby making their recount come in too late to be included in the final, certified figure? What if officials in Miami-Dade county had not been so rattled by a Republican near-riot, protesters pounding on the doors of the counting room, that they suspended their effort when only a fifth of the votes had been recounted? What if, what if, what if? webTitle: Uniting a divided nation: the first task for President Bush

fields.headline: Uniting a divided nation - the first task for the new man in the White House
fields.standfirst: Celebrations at last, but the work is just starting for President Bush
fields.trailText: George W Bush had already heard that Al Gore was withdrawing his recount team from Florida when he arrived at the Capitol building in Austin, Texas, yesterday and was indicating that the theme of his response would be to "unite a divided nation".
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in Austin and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
George W Bush had already heard that Al Gore was withdrawing his recount team from Florida when he arrived at the Capitol building in Austin, Texas, yesterday and was indicating that the theme of his response would be to "unite a divided nation".

After greeting members of the media he spent yesterday working on his conciliatory address to the nation and contacting potential members of his cabinet. "This has been a long and arduous process for everyone involved on both sides," said James Baker, who has been acting as Mr Bush's legal adviser for the past five weeks.

Art Aubry, who runs the Shooting Star photography studio just down the road from the governor's mansion, ran out on to the street to celebrate when he heard that Al Gore was ending the recount yesterday. "I couldn't be happier," said Mr Aubry, whose business card shows him and Mr Bush together.

Mr Aubry had been ready for a big celebration on the night of November 7. Then Al Gore withdrew his concession and 500 disposable cameras he had been hoping to sell to revellers had to be stored. But he felt that the wait had been worth it. "I think the country is aghast at the way the vote was carried out. Who knew that there were 67 different standards in one state?" he said.

A hardy band of four supporters had braved the icy winds to wave their placards at George Bush as he arrived in Austin. Barbara Goldin, who works at a nearby military base, said: "I wanted to be here to show the president-elect my support because I can't go inside the governor's mansion and give him a hug."

She said that Bush supporters would probably not get round to celebrating the victory properly until the weekend. "It would be wrong for us to celebrate now - the whole nation has been torn apart."

The Bush camp was still reluctant to put the bunting out. But plans for a muted unofficial party at the nearby Four Seasons hotel were under way, although there was no triumphalism on display as Mr Bush arrived, flanked by his secret service bodyguards, at the Capitol building to carry out some of his last acts as governor.

There has been much discussion within the Bush camp as victory seemed increasingly likely about an appropriate response. From early yesterday, Karen Hughes, Mr Bush's spokeswoman, was engaged in producing a suitably restrained reaction, not least because of the bridge-building that Mr Bush will have to do with the Democrats for any meaningful legislation to proceed next year.

Gradually, since the early, angry days after November 7, Mr Bush has sought to present a more conciliatory manner as it became clear that Al Gore had won the popular vote by 300,000, that less than a quarter of the electorate had voted for Mr Bush and that around half of the population were not really convinced that he had won. Many believe he has been shoe-horned into power by a partisan judiciary and a flawed, if not corrupt, electoral system in a state run by his brother.

No American president has come to the White House in such difficult circumstances and with as little practical political experience for dealing with them. He faces two great challenges of political legitimacy. The first is to secure his authority as the winner of the most intensely disputed election in modern US politics. The second is to restore the authority of the presidency in a nation split down the middle on party lines.

In these tasks he has a major credibility gap to cross. He is regarded by his opponents as a placeman for the religious right, gun lobby and big business. It was noted that, when a Bush victory finally looked almost certain, shares in tobacco, pharmaceuticals and Microsoft rose. Mr Bush is perceived as someone likely to put a halt to the big tobacco company civil actions and the government's action against Microsoft, and unlikely to cap the price of pharmaceuticals.

Those lobbies that backed Mr Bush are expecting legislative help, tax breaks and a lighter regulatory framework.

Mr Bush has also been throwing out hints of how he hopes to "heal the divide". One of the biggest divides will be with the black voters, 92 % of whom supported Mr Gore. His team has dropped hints that not only will Colin Powell become his secretary of state and Condoleezza Rice his national security adviser, but that there will be other high-profile appointments to address the perceived distrust. William Gray, a Democratic former congressman and current head of the United Negro College Fund, has been suggested as a possible secretary of education.

Mr Bush's background and manner suggest the Oval Office is about to see a dramatic change. Instead of Bill Clinton's energy and engagement in detailed policy and campaigning issues, he seems likely to be more of a figurehead and delegator in the Ronald Reagan mould, though without the latter's instinctive sense of style. Much of the burden of governing is likely to fall on Dick Cheney, who sometimes appears to be the real head of the new team.

A year ago George W Bush was famous in for just two things - being the son of a president and being the Republican presidential candidate who had raised more money on the campaign trail than any candidate for the White House before him. Those who invested will now be looking for their return. For some it will be one of the 8,000 patronage jobs that change hands in Washington with the arrival of a new administration. For the most influential there will be posts at the White House; for the richest, ambassadorships and invitations to White House banquets.

The right wing of Mr Bush's party, led by Trent Lott in the Senate and Tom DeLay in the House of Representatives, intends to secure some of the policy goals that a Democratic president prevented. The most controversial of these would be steps towards outlawing abortion, an almost sacred cause to many conservatives.

In Shrub, the unauthorised and sceptical biography of the man who will be the 43rd president, Molly Ivins quotes one of Mr Bush's less statesmanlike remarks when he described himself as "the pitbull on the pantleg of opportunity". He will need a pitbull's tenacity if he is not to be seen as another, more pampered, member of the canine species acting on behalf of the corporations who spent so heavily to ensure his success.

George W Bush - a life

1946 Born George Walker Bush in New Haven Connecticut, the son of George Herbert Walker and Barbara Bush

1948 The Bush family moved to Midland, Texas, where George Bush Senior started an oil exploration business

1959 The family moved to Houston and George W Bush was sent to Phillips Academy boarding school in Andover, Massachusetts, where he was an indifferent student

1965 Went to Yale University in New Haven, where he earned a BA in history in 1968

1968 Won a coveted slot as a trainee pilot in the Texas Air National Guard, which ruled out being sent to fight in the Vietnam war.

1969-73 Bush wandered from job to job, at one point working with young people in Houston

1973 Enrolled in Harvard business school

1975 Returned to Midland, Texas, to try his luck in the oil business, with the help of former business friends of his father

1977 Married Laura Welch, a Midland librarian and teacher

1978 Ran unsuccessfully for Congress in Texas

1986 A Dallas firm bought out Bush's ailing oil company. After his 40th birthday party, he gave up drinking and resolved to take life more seriously

1988 Helped run his father's presidential campaign

1989 Helped put together a consortium to buy the Texas Rangers baseball team

1994 Defeated the Democratic governor of Texas, Ann Richards

1998 Won re-election as Texas governor

1999 Declared his intention to run for the presidency

webTitle: Planning law falls foul of rights act

fields.headline: Planning law falls foul of rights act
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The government will have to make radical changes to the law and remove the environment secretary's right to rule on planning, after the high court yesterday declared UK planning law to be incompatible with European legislation.
fields.body:
The government will have to make radical changes to the law and remove the environment secretary's right to rule on planning, after the high court yesterday declared UK planning law to be incompatible with European legislation.

The ruling, the first "declaration of incompatibility" made under the Human Rights Act, which incorporates the European convention on human rights, strikes at the heart of the system under which decisions in many of the most controversial cases have been taken by the government.

Lord Justice Tuckey, sitting with Mr Justice Harrison, held that the system - with decisions being taken by the environment secretary - did not guarantee people "a fair and public hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal", as required by the act.

In each of four test cases, the secretary of state had not been impartial because his policy had been at issue, the judges said. "He cannot be both policy maker and decision taker."

A spokesman for the environment secretary, John Prescott, said: "The potential implications of the judgment go beyond the planning system. We are seeking leave to appeal to the House of Lords."

The judgment is a foretaste of how pervasive the Human Rights Act is likely to be.

In two of the four test cases, the environment secretary had "called in" planning applications to determine them himself after local authorities indicated they intended to grant planning permission for a car salvage operation and a leisure centre, both in Essex.

The third case involved proposals to build warehouses on Alconbury airfield, Cambridgeshire, which is Ministry of Defence land.

The MoD had entered into a profit-sharing deal with the developers, and the government, therefore, had a financial interest in the outcome of a planning appeal.

The fourth case raised the question of whether compulsory purchase proceedings, stemming from an improvement scheme on the M4, were compatible with the Human Rights Act.

The wording of the declaration of incompatibility will be decided next week.

webTitle: Gore's thoughts turn to the campaign of 2004

fields.headline: Gore's thoughts turn to the campaign of 2004
fields.standfirst:
The losers: Democrats lick wounds and look to future
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Democrats reacted with anger to Al Gore's defeat last night, with some senior officials barely able to conceal their bitterness at an election they claimed had been fixed.
fields.body:
Democrats reacted with anger to Al Gore's defeat last night, with some senior officials barely able to conceal their bitterness at an election they claimed had been fixed.

"There was a campaign of voter suppression in Florida which has left very bitter feelings," a senior aide to President Bill Clinton said. "Gore won but he was robbed."

For the first time in half a century the Democrats now control neither the White House, the Senate, nor the House of Representatives. In exceptionally promising economic circumstances, the party has failed to place itself at the centre of American politics. The political prospects of Mr Gore himself are also now in question. For an incumbent vice-president to be ousted from the White House at a time of sustained economic prosperity, domestic tranquillity and international peace - and when the outgoing administration enjoyed record approval ratings - ought to be politically unforgiveable.

If this were November 8, the political obituary writers would say that Mr Gore threw it away and that his career as a major national politician must be over. But his prospects have changed. Last night's expected concession speech might even have been the opening shot of the 2004 Gore-Bush rematch.

Senator Kent Conrad, a Democrat, said last night that it was "very hard to know" whether Mr Gore could try again in four years.

"That is several lifetimes in politics and that makes it hard to predict. There are lots of other capable people who, no doubt, will step forward."

But Mr Gore's achievements in defeat in the 2000 election cannot be lightly dismissed. He won more votes on November 7 than any Democratic presidential candidate in history - more than Bill Clinton, Jimmy Carter, John Kennedy or Lyndon Johnson. Only Ronald Reagan has ever won more support from Americans than Mr Gore did last month. And no candidate since 1888 has won more votes than his opponent and not moved into the White House.

For all the talk about bipartisanship under a Bush administration there will be no magnanimous job offer to Mr Gore - and he would not accept it anyway.

A Los Angeles radio station has offered Mr Gore a $200,000 a year contract to host a show but that seems even less likely.

Mr Gore may briefly think about relaunching his political career in the 2002 midterm elections. The governorship of his home state of Tennessee will be up for grabs in two years, as will Republican ex-film star Fred Thompson's Senate seat, which Mr Gore once held. But Mr Gore's loss in Tennessee on November 7 was a serious blow.

Unless he improbably drops out of politics altogether, a much likelier scenario is a period on the lucrative lecture circuit while he takes stock and maybe writes another book while fundraising for a presidential bid in 2004. He has the family farm in Tennessee to retreat to, but Mr Gore has not spent much of his life away from Washington.

The Democratic nomination for 2004 is not his for the taking. Dick Gephardt and Joe Lieberman must fancy their own chances, and it will not be long before the Democratic feminist machine begins to push a Hillary Clinton candidacy that could be irresistible. But Mr Gore controls the party for the moment and he can say with much conviction and some truth that he deserves a rematch. He remains a plausible candidate to take on and defeat Mr Bush next time.

Whether Mr Gore's closest advisers have the same determination is unclear. And there will be no shortage of Democratic critics who will argue - after a decent interval to let the dust settle and the wounds heal - that Mr Gore ran such a bad campaign in 2000 that it would be fatal for the party to tie itself to him a second time.

From the left, some critics will argue that the centrist legacy of eight years of Clinton-Gore drove vital supporters into the arms of the Green candidate, Ralph Nader. Mr Nader is the villain in many Democrats' eyes - his votes undoubtedly cost Mr Gore the election - and party pragmatists will want to get as many of those votes back as possible. They may reason that Mr Gore is hardly the candidate to achieve that goal.

From the right, critics will say that Mr Gore squandered the political legacy of 1992 and 1996 by pitching his appeal too low down the national salary scale. The Democratic leadership council, the organisation which has successfully promoted "third way" politics as the solution for the party since 1988, believes that Mr Gore identified himself too closely with the trade unions and voters dependent on benefits.
fields.bodyText: Democrats reacted with anger to Al Gore's defeat last night, with some senior officials barely able to conceal their bitterness at an election they claimed had been fixed. "There was a campaign of voter suppression in Florida which has left very bitter feelings," a senior aide to President Bill Clinton said. "Gore won but he was robbed." For the first time in half a century the Democrats now control neither the White House, the Senate, nor the House of Representatives. In exceptionally promising economic circumstances, the party has failed to place itself at the centre of American politics. The political prospects of Mr Gore himself are also now in question. For an incumbent vice-president to be ousted from the White House at a time of sustained economic prosperity, domestic tranquillity and international peace - and when the outgoing administration enjoyed record approval ratings - ought to be politically unforgiveable. If this were November 8, the political obituary writers would say that Mr Gore threw it away and that his career as a major national politician must be over. But his prospects have changed. Last night's expected concession speech might even have been the opening shot of the 2004 Gore-Bush rematch. Senator Kent Conrad, a Democrat, said last night that it was "very hard to know" whether Mr Gore could try again in four years. "That is several lifetimes in politics and that makes it hard to predict. There are lots of other capable people who, no doubt, will step forward." But Mr Gore's achievements in defeat in the 2000 election cannot be lightly dismissed. He won more votes on November 7 than any Democratic presidential candidate in history - more than Bill Clinton, Jimmy Carter, John Kennedy or Lyndon Johnson. Only Ronald Reagan has ever won more support from Americans than Mr Gore did last month. And no candidate since 1888 has won more votes than his opponent and not moved into the White House. For all the talk about bipartisanship under a Bush administration there will be no magnanimous job offer to Mr Gore - and he would not accept it anyway. A Los Angeles radio station has offered Mr Gore a $200,000 a year contract to host a show but that seems even less likely. Mr Gore may briefly think about relaunching his political career in the 2002 midterm elections. The governorship of his home state of Tennessee will be up for grabs in two years, as will Republican ex-film star Fred Thompson's Senate seat, which Mr Gore once held. But Mr Gore's loss in Tennessee on November 7 was a serious blow. Unless he improbably drops out of politics altogether, a much likelier scenario is a period on the lucrative lecture circuit while he takes stock and maybe writes another book while fundraising for a presidential bid in 2004. He has the family farm in Tennessee to retreat to, but Mr Gore has not spent much of his life away from Washington. The Democratic nomination for 2004 is not his for the taking. Dick Gephardt and Joe Lieberman must fancy their own chances, and it will not be long before the Democratic feminist machine begins to push a Hillary Clinton candidacy that could be irresistible. But Mr Gore controls the party for the moment and he can say with much conviction and some truth that he deserves a rematch. He remains a plausible candidate to take on and defeat Mr Bush next time. Whether Mr Gore's closest advisers have the same determination is unclear. And there will be no shortage of Democratic critics who will argue - after a decent interval to let the dust settle and the wounds heal - that Mr Gore ran such a bad campaign in 2000 that it would be fatal for the party to tie itself to him a second time. webTitle: US election: Seven key players who have waited for this moment

fields.headline: Seven key players who have waited for this moment
fields.standfirst:
Cold war caution and conservatism look likely to underpin the incoming cabinet

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Cold war caution and conservatism look likely to underpin the incoming cabinet
fields.body:
Dick Cheney

The vice-president elect was the first President Bush's defence secretary. He is another Texan oilman who sees the world through an oilman's eyes, with an inherent tendency to equate US interests with those of American big business. He was put on the ticket to compensate Bush Jr's inexperience in foreign affairs. This is, after all, a president elect who has been overseas fewer than half a dozen times in his life. It is reasonable to assume Mr Cheney will be taking the lead White House role in foreign policy-making in at least the first months of the new administration. Like Al Gore, he is likely to wield more power than has traditionally been the case for running mates. But unlike the outgoing veep, he is unlikely to be spending much of his power or time at global warming conferences.

Colin Powell

Another face from the old Bush court who as national security adviser helped run the Gulf war campaign alongside Mr Cheney. He is almost certain to become the new secretary of state, replacing Madeleine Albright's enthusiasm for humanitarian intervention (Kosovo is still thought of as "Madeleine's war") with the caution and pragmatism of a soldier who rose to the top by taking few risks and making few mistakes.

Condoleezza Rice

Ms Rice, who is expected to become President elect Bush's national security adviser, is cut from similar cloth. The Stanford academic is a generation younger than her two colleagues but she shares their mindset. As the Russian affairs adviser in the first Bush White House, she is a child of the cold war, with a much more hawkish view on Russia and China - as rivals rather than partners. She has also led the withdrawal from humanitarian intervention, promising Americans that their armed forces "are not the world's 911", an emergency service on 24-hour call.

Paul Wolfowitz

Mr Wolfowitz is likely to become the fourth corner of the new foreign policy. Mr Cheney's undersecretary in the old Bush regime is another cold war veteran who has been biding his time since as dean of the Johns Hopkins University's school of advanced international studies in Washington. A cold war hawk, he has been highly critical of the outgoing administration's handling of relations with Russia and China.

Larry Lindsey

One of the godfathers of supply-side economics, under which economic growth is fostered by tax cuts for the rich. Mr Lindsey is a former governor of the federal reserve and served the president elect's father as a White House economic policy guru. He is tipped to replace Larry Summers at the treasury, although it is possible that job will be given to a financier to build a bridge to Wall Street. In that case, Walter Shipley, the retired Chase Manhattan chairman, or Donald Marron, the head of investment house PaineWebber, could get the job, in which case Mr Lindsey might be compensated with the top job at the White House national economic council thinktank set up by President Clinton.

Andrew Card

Andy Card was deputy chief of staff under the governor's father, and has already been selected as a White House chief of staff. As a former lobbyist for General Motors, he is likely to be a friendly gatekeeper, opening the gates on Pennsylvania Avenue wide for big business, which donated a record amount to the Bush campaign and will be looking for a return on its investment.

Katherine Harris

The Florida secretary of state's future will be closely watched, since she played such a significant role in the events of the past month. She is a citrus heiress, who before becoming forever associated with dimpled ballots and hanging chads was Florida's cultural tsar. Before the election she had expected an ambassadorial posting for her efforts as co-chairwoman of the Bush campaign in Florida. She may now be considered radioactive when it comes to distributing largesse.

webTitle: Deaths prompt fears of new CJD cluster

fields.headline: Deaths prompt fears of new CJD cluster
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Health officials are investigating a possible link between the deaths of two men from the human form of BSE.
fields.body:
Health officials are investigating a possible link between the deaths of two men from the human form of BSE.

Steven Lunt, 34, and Paul Dickens, 28, one of the latest victims believed to have died from variant CJD, both lived in Adswood, Stockport, Greater Manchester. Their proximity is bound to raise fears of a new "cluster" such as those already being examined in Leicestershire. There have been five victims in the county, four with links to the village of Queniborough, and three victims from Armthorpe, near Doncaster, south Yorkshire.

The Leicestershire investigation is concentrating on the preparation and sale of meat products locally in the 1980s. But although infected beef is prime suspect for the entire vCJD epidemic, there is still no proof.

A total of 82 Britons died from the condition, five more victims face death, and numbers are still rising.

Mr Lunt, from Melrose Crescent, died in April, but experts from the CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh still have to confirm whether Mr Dickens, from nearby Bexhill Road, was another victim. His widow, Melanie, said her football-loving husband had a burger every Sunday before playing for Hillgate Spartans.

"My son and I no longer eat meat now. It is not worth it. Paul lived for playing football and watching our nine-year-old, Jordan, play himself. He was an athletic man and a brilliant husband."

David Baxter, the local health authority's consultant in communicable disease control, said: "I understand there is fear but there is not much evidence at the moment these fears are justified. There is bound to be local concern because they lived so close together."

Meanwhile consumers were warned yesterday by the food standards agency that beef products such as corned beef, salami and pate from France and other BSE-infected countries were more risky to eat than carcass meat.

But the agency said there was no justification for a ban as they revealed the results of early spot checks indicating that 20% of all beef entering Britain lacked the necessary paperwork on age of cattle or country of origin. Such beef or beef products should not be offered for sale, although it would only press local authorities to prosecute where there seemed evidence of fraud.

Sir John Krebs, chairman of the agency, said consumers could make up their own minds as to whether they chose to eat imported products or eat beef while in France, despite new figures suggesting that the risk of humans being infected across the Channel is now greater than in this country.

A ban on risky offals, introduced in Britain in 1989, and the exclusion of nearly all cattle over 30 months old from food, introduced here since 1996, have reduced the danger from homegrown cattle.

Imported carcass meat has to follow the same 30-month rule, but meat in processed products does not yet. Around 2,400 tonnes of the 5, 570 tonnes of beef and beef products imported from France was in corned beef form.

Sir John insisted that "on current evidence the risk posed by French and British steaks sold in the UK are comparable". When it came to meat products, "I would simply say we cannot be as confident about risk levels as we are with carcass meat".

The agency does not want another political rumpus similar to the beef-on-the-bone ban. It argued that France too has banned risky offals since 1996 and the introduction soon of the 30-month rule across the rest of Europe, unless carcasses are tested BSE-free, will further reduce risk.

webTitle: Farmer killed as Mugabe speaks of war

fields.headline: Farmer killed as Mugabe speaks of war
fields.standfirst:
Elderly father dies and son shot in sixth fatal attack on white landowners by Zimbabwe war veterans
Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: "War veterans" in Zimbabwe murdered an elderly white farmer hours before President Robert Mugabe told the leadership of his ruling party that the people are at war with white landowners.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  and  Chris McGreal  in Harare
fields.body:
"War veterans" in Zimbabwe murdered an elderly white farmer hours before President Robert Mugabe told the leadership of his ruling party that the people are at war with white landowners.

Henry Elsworth, 70, a former MP, is the sixth farmer to have been murdered since the government sent armed veterans to seize white-owned land earlier this year. About 30 opposition activists and supporters have also been killed in state-sponsored political violence.

Within hours of the killing on Tuesday night, Mr Mugabe told members of Zanu-PF's central committee that legal action by the mostly white Commercial Farmers Union (CFU) to stop the redistribution of farm land is an act of war.

"Let us bring it home to the commercial farmers of the CFU that they have declared war on the people of Zimbabwe who have every determination to win," he said.

Mr Elsworth - a member of parliament under Ian Smith's rule, then an ally of Mr Mugabe before finally joining the opposition - was killed and his son seriously injured in an ambush on their farm in Kwekwe, central Zimbabwe.

Three men opened fire with semi-automatic guns as Ian Elsworth, 20, climbed out of a vehicle to open a gate. Ian described from his hospital bed how his father, who was on crutches after a recent hip operation, attempted to intervene and was fatally wounded.

"He said: 'Please stop, we will leave Zimbabwe tomorrow. We will leave'," Mr Elsworth said. "He was a defenceless old man on crutches and they shot him down."

Ian Elsworth, who was hit by nine bullets in his legs and side, dragged his father to a ditch where he died about 10 minutes later. It was two more hours before assistance came.

Shortly before undergoing an operation to remove several bullets, Mr Elsworth alleged that his father's murder was politically motivated because both men were active supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

Mr Elsworth described it as a "hit job" by war veterans who had occupied part of their farm, because no attempt was made to rob them.

"I only saw one of them but I think they were war veterans who are on our farm. I believe they wanted to kill us because of our affiliation with the MDC. These people are evil. They do not even care about the suffering of their own people.

"Next year we will have food shortages. They don't care. They just want to fill their sticky pockets while they can," he said.

The killing came hours before the opening of a special congress of the ruling Zanu-PF party at which the land issue is top of the agenda. Mr Mugabe's speech to the central committee yesterday was behind closed doors but he is expected to be equally bellicose in a televised address to the entire congress today.

It was not the president's first warning to the CFU. Last week he said that if white farmers did not drop their legal action over the land seizures, they would be expelled from the country.

"I urge farmers to drop the nonsense of fighting the land issue in the courts, as that will make us even more angry. If the farmers cannot be harmonious... then we will ask them to leave our country harmoniously," he said.

The CFU initially shied away from direct confrontation with the government but last month it won a supreme court ruling that the land redistribution and invasions are illegal, and that the government is obliged to remove the war veterans and other squatters.

Many farmers are surprised that more of their number have not been killed. For two months the CFU has warned that Mr Mugabe's armed supporters have assaulted farmers and their workers, and that death threats have been issued.

Mr Elsworth was well known to Zimbabwe's president. He was an MP for Ian Smith's Rhodesian Front until two years after independence in 1980, but then allied himself with the new order and was appointed to parliament by Mr Mugabe as a non-elected MP.

He broke with the ruling party in 1994 after being accused of abusing several black women whom he "arrested" for stealing firewood from his farm. The courts acquitted him but Mr Mugabe publicly denounced him as a racist and pledged to seize his farm.

The MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, yesterday said that Zimbabwe is descending deeper into anarchy. "In Zimbabwe no one is safe now, no one can feel confidently safe. The law enforcers are now involved themselves in lawlessness with the tacit approval of the president himself. Everybody must be very careful," he said.

But Zimbabwe's foreign minister, Stan Mudenge, dismissed claims the murder was politically motivated.

"There are criminal elements all over the world, even in the United Kingdom. This says nothing about a breakdown of law and order in Zimbabwe," he said.

From hospital, Ian Elsworth vowed to return to his farm. "I'm not leaving. That's what they want. I'm going back to our farm and if they kill me, they kill me," he said.

The government says it intends to acquire about 3,000 farms, approximately three-quarters of all white-owned land. War veterans and other squatters have already occupied about half of those farms.

Among the latest victims of the land seizures is a controversial British multi-millionaire who says he has made substantial donations to Mr Mugabe's party and described farmers as "white trash".

Nicholas van Hoogstraten is one of the biggest landowners in Zimbabwe, with more than 2m hectares (4.9m acres) of property. A few months ago he said his land was protected from occupation because of his relationship with Mr Mugabe.

"I'm in bed with his Zanu-PF party. My land will not be affected," he said at the time. But all of his farms, with nearly 30,000 head of cattle, have now been invaded.

Murdered for the land

David Stevens Shot dead on April 15 by supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party who were retaliating after being chased off his farm. He was tied up, beaten and shot in the face in the presence of two neighbours

Martin Olds Died while trying to defend his farm from war veterans on April 18. After a three-hour gun battle, the veterans set fire to Olds's house to force him out. They then shot him

John Weeks Killed on his farm in May by six or seven intruders who also robbed the premises

Alan Dunn A local MDC official, Dunn was beaten to death on May 8. He had left his farm two weeks earlier after receiving death threats, but then returned to pay his workers

Tony Oates Killed by two intruders who broke into his farm on May 31. Oates shot dead one of the attackers before being killed. The men were thought to be criminals taking advantage of the lawless situation

fields.headline: 'Spy spray' reveals secrets of mail
fields.trailText: The secrets contained in our private mail may not be secret for much longer, thanks to an invention by a team of American scientists.
fields.body:
The secrets contained in our private mail may not be secret for much longer, thanks to an invention by a team of American scientists.

Researchers have developed a spray that makes envelopes transparent and the letters inside as easy to read as postcards. The spray leaves no trace that the correspondence has been tampered with, apart from a slight odour lasting 15 minutes.

Called See-Through, the spray is intended for use by police forces investigating suspect packages, according to a report in New Scientist magazine.

But private detectives or snoopers keen to pry on their neighbours' private correspondence are likely to be disappointed: the company which developed the environmentally safe spray, Mistral Security, based in Maryland, has said it will only sell to law enforcement agencies.

A spokesman, Bob Schlagel, said: "With a business card in a brown envelope you can read the card, the email address, the telephone number, everything. It leaves an odour for about 15 minutes but apart from that there is no smudging of ink on the envelope or letter, no watermark, or any evidence at all."

webTitle: Prescott's tightrope act disappoints the ghouls

fields.headline: Prescott's tightrope act disappoints the ghouls
fields.trailText: The prime minister was in Belfast, so we had John Prescott instead. The house was packed. The last time he stood in it was a magnificent castastrophe. Passengers had to leap clear in case the whole edifice exploded. Now we were back in hopes of a repeat. If this had been a motorway crash, a police spokesman would have condemned us as "ghouls" interfering with the rescue work.
fields.body:
The prime minister was in Belfast, so we had John Prescott instead. The house was packed. The last time he stood in it was a magnificent castastrophe. Passengers had to leap clear in case the whole edifice exploded. Now we were back in hopes of a repeat. If this had been a motorway crash, a police spokesman would have condemned us as "ghouls" interfering with the rescue work.

Or it was like watching a tightrope walker returning to work after a terrible fall. We could hardly bear to look as he began to inch over the shark infested water. Damien Green asked about fiddled NHS figures ("how many of the new nurses are full time?"). Mr Prescott blustered out his old catchphrase, "I don't think we need any lectures," to the merry jeers of Tories. You could see his pole wobble, his toes curled round the wire.

But, we learned, the circling shark was made of rubber, its teeth were perished, and its name was Angela. Most Commons traditions date back for centuries, or at least weeks, and one of the most rigid holds that the leader of the opposition can never face the deputy PM. It would be demeaning, like turning up at a Buck House banquet on a bike.

So Angela Browning, recently demoted to shadow leader of the house, had the job. She had written out her first question, stood up, took a deep breath, and gabbled as fast as she could. "The government has set out five economic tests for joining the euro. What are they?"

Now this was silly. It was a quiz question, not a request for enlightenment. It was designed to prove that Mr Prescott did not know what the five tests are, any more than he could name the moons of Neptune. Of course he does not know. We know he does not know, and more to the point, he also knows he does not know. He played for time. "I couldn't exactly hear what she said, she said it very quickly," he began. "But it was the test for joining the euro, that indeed it is the one we have made absolutely clear..."

Tories know that in Prescott-speak "absolutely clear" means "incomprehensible". They jeered again.

"And that there will be an economic test, it is the convertability of the European currencies, the effect it will have on our investment and the effect on our economy."

Phew! His feet were jiggling on the rope, yet he was still aloft. Mrs Browning returned. It was like a feeding frenzy in a Soviet supermarket. She was hungry, but there was nothing to bite.

"I will speak more slowly," she said, so began to talk faster. She changed the question. How were the five tests going? Mr Prescott suddenly remembered two of them. They had to be hurled into his answer, like Pooh sticks in a flooded river.

"We have always made clear to the house and my Rt Hon friend made it absolutely clear that he gave some assessments some months ago and didn't feel we could not meet these conditions and that he would report to the house after the next general election giving the assessment of those tests, which of course include the financial services and employment!" The shark closed its gummy, impotent jaws and Mr Prescott tottered on.

Now he could see the opposite bank. At moments we thought he was about to break into a run: "We've got to do a great deal more about investment in the flooding," he shouted at one point.

The rubber shark tried a final time, on train chaos. But in front of her were only loud ironic cheers, and behind her an equally deafening silence. Her prey, meanwhile, had somehow scrambled to the safety of dry land.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Head denies pupil assaults
Light plane disappears
£2.3m for drug error teenager
Goodbye sailor
Patsy, Liam and lust
Lottery rollover
Doctor denies killing baby
Policeman shot himself
Move for BBC's Archers studio
Ice cream tubs trap hedgehogs
Court pulls plug on festive lights
fields.body:
Head denies pupil assaults

Northumberland police said yesterday that the head of a junior school in the village of Wooler had been charged with assaults on eight pupils. Elizabeth Carey, 51, of Ashington, who was suspended in October, denies the charges.

Light plane disappears

A search was under way last night for a light plane carrying two passengers which disappeared off the west coast of Scotland. The pilot last made radio contact at 9.15am, shortly after taking off from Inverness.

£2.3m for drug error teenager

The family of Laura Stevens, 16, of Reigate, Surrey, who suffered brain damage after hospital doctors gave her an overdose of Valium when she was a baby, were awarded £2.3m compensation from East Surrey health authority at the high court yesterday.

Goodbye sailor

The Duke of York, 40, will leave the Royal Navy in July, after 22 years, to take over the Duke of Kent's role of representing British Trade International, the government organisation that promotes overseas trade and investment.

Patsy, Liam and lust

The actress Patsy Kensit has told Hello! magazine that there was "a lot of lust" in her three-year marriage to the Oasis singer Liam Gallagher, but no "meeting of minds". In an interview she said: "All the mess I used to have to deal with is not my mess anymore."

Lottery rollover

The £3.4m lottery jackpot will roll over to the next draw after no tickets matched the numbers 3, 12, 23, 34, 38 and 39 last night. The bonus number was 11.

Doctor denies killing baby

Hospital doctor Kosalakumar Karunaratne, 36, yesterday denied at Liver pool crown court the manslaughter of a baby in his care. Three-day-old Adam Teare, one of triplets, died at Liverpool women's hospital in February. The doctor, of Shotton, Cheshire, was charged in July after a coroner ordered an investigation.

Policeman shot himself

A policeman who felt victimised by his superior officers killed himself because he could not live with an accusation of sexual harassment against him, an inquest heard yesterday.

PC Paul Wilkinson, 37, a father of two from New Longton, Lancashire, shot himself in June, shortly after he learned he could be liable to pay damages to a colleague if she succeeded in her harassment claim. He left a suicide note on his computer. Preston coroner Howard McCann recorded a verdict that Wilkinson killed himself.

Move for BBC's Archers studio

The BBC is to move out of its Pebble Mill studios in Birmingham - the home of the Archers - after 30 years. The move to a new complex in the heart of the city will take place over the next few years.

Ice cream tubs trap hedgehogs

The fast food chain McDonald's is in talks with suppliers over a change in the design of its ice cream cartons because of the danger they present to hedgehogs. The creatures are enticed into discarded McFlurry containers by the smell of the ice cream but the design of the container's lid means they can become trapped.

Court pulls plug on festive lights

Residents were celebrating yesterday after a judge banned their neighbour from turning his home into a Christmas attraction.

David Rowlands, 49, has decorated his house in Irvine with 8,000 lights at Christmas for the last three years. Kilmarnock sheriff court ruled he could no longer do so after neighbours complained they had been besieged by visitors.

webTitle: Parents charged over girls' deaths on rail line

fields.headline: Parents charged over girls' deaths on rail line
fields.trailText: The parents of a child killed alongside her friend as they played on a railway line have been charged with manslaughter through gross negligence.
fields.body:
The parents of a child killed alongside her friend as they played on a railway line have been charged with manslaughter through gross negligence.

The charges were brought by British Transport police after an investigation into the death of Sophie George, seven, on July 29 at Ynyslas, near Borth, Mid Wales. Sophie's friend, Kymberley Allock, eight, was also killed in the accident last July.

British Transport police last night charged Sophie's stepfather, Gareth Edwards, 33, and her mother, Amanda Edwards, 34, over both deaths. They were bailed to appear before Aberystwyth magistrates on December 20.

The tragedy shocked the village community of Tre'rddol where the families of both girls lived. The girls and Kymberley's brother Mathew, 11, were being looked after by Sophie's parents when the accident happened.

Sophie and Kymberley were struck by a two-coach Shrewsbury-Aberystwyth train as they played on the bridge after a Saturday afternoon picnic. The driver of the train was treated for shock after the accident.

It is thought that the girls had been throwing stones into the water from the bridge and had not seen the train approach.

The spot, two miles from the village and accessible only on foot, is midway between Ynyshir nature reserve and the holiday village of Ynyslas.

It is a popular haunt for local young people, with many visiting it to catch flatfish or collect cockles.

A public footpath and stile ends near the bridge, which crosses the River Clettwr, and when the tide is in it has been the custom for people to walk over the railway line to reach the other side.

After the incident, Kymberley's father Tony Allcock, 39, said: "They were not dare devils in any shape or form. They were innocent young children who were taken away for no reason at all.

"At the moment, my family and I do not blame anyone for this tragedy, but answers have to be found."

He demanded safety measures on the railway bridge. A memorial fund was being set up to provide safety barriers at the spot.

fields.headline: Master stroke
fields.standfirst: Rembrandt portrait fetches record £19.8m
fields.trailText: A Rembrandt painting showing the "great beauty" of a woman of 62 fetched £19.8m at auction in London yesterday, setting a record for his art.
fields.body:
A Rembrandt painting showing the "great beauty" of a woman of 62 fetched £19.8m at auction in London yesterday, setting a record for his art.

The price is the second highest paid for an Old Master. It was reached after manic bidding at Christie's as Portrait of a Lady, aged 62 (right), came briefly into public view after 368 years in private collections.

Bidding rose by £2m at a time until - within three minutes - it reached more than three times the highest catalogue forecast.

It portrays a woman on the borders of old age with such tender exactitude that she was assumed to be the artist's mother when it was first offered for sale in the early 19th century.

It shows age pinching an unassuming face which still has character and a touch of the beauty of youth, but also vulnerability and a sense of death. "It is a truly magnificent portrait, painted with love and sympathy", said David Llewellyn, Old Master specialist at Christie's. "It shows that there can be great beauty in a portrait of a woman of 62."

The buyer was Robert Noortman, an art trader from Maastricht, the Netherlands. It was not immediately clear whether he bought the work for stock or intends to sell it.

The work, dating from 1632 during the Dutch artist's Amsterdam period, was sold by the estate of Baroness Batsheva de Rothschild, who died last year. It had been in her banking family since the 1830s. Research indicates the woman in the portrait was probably Aeltje Uylenburgh, wife of Calvinist clergymen Johannes Sylvius, who was a witness at the painter's marriage. The previous Rembrandt record was £6.27m in 1998 for his Portrait of a Bearded Man in a Red Coat. The Old Master record is £24m paid in 1989 for Jacopo da Pontormo's Portrait of Cosimo Medici.

fields.headline: Winter wonderland
fields.standfirst: Somerset House welcomes young blades to its rink
fields.trailText: The magnificent courtyard of Somerset House, in central London, which served as a civil service car park for most of the past century, opened as an outdoor skating rink last night, complete with cafe, Christmas tree and bandstand.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The magnificent courtyard of Somerset House, in central London, which served as a civil service car park for most of the past century, opened as an outdoor skating rink last night, complete with cafe, Christmas tree and bandstand. Costing £300,000 to build, the rink can take up to 200 skaters at a time, and will be recreated each winter.

Duncan Wilson, director of the Somerset House Trust, said he hoped it would become as much part of the character of Christmas in London as the ice rink at the Rockefeller Center is in New York.

Somerset House, Sir William Chamber's palatial 18th century building, which has been reclaimed from miles of filing racks and hundreds of civil service offices with the help of lottery grants and private donations, has already reached its visitor target for the year, attracting more than 500,000 people since May. The ice rink opens daily until January 7. A day of special events and entertainments at the "fairytale ice palace" is planned for New Year's Eve.

webTitle: Philippine leader faces his accuser in bribery trial

fields.headline: Philippine leader faces his accuser in bribery trial
fields.standfirst: President Estrada remains defiant as key prosecution witness fails to deliver the explosive new evidence he had promised
fields.trailText: President Estrada remains defiant as key prosecution witness fails to deliver the explosive new evidence he had promised
fields.body:
The impeachment trial of the Philippines' president, Joseph Estrada, entered its most critical phase yesterday when the main prosecution witness, the provincial governor who made the initial corruption allegations, began giving evidence.

However, Governor Luis Singson, a former drinking and gambling buddy of the president, failed to offer the extraordinary new revelations he had promised in a morning radio interview.

He spent hours going through an extremely detailed ledger explaining how he had collected £5.5m in protection money from illegal lottery gangs and passed it on to Mr Estrada, his relations and cronies in fortnightly instalments.

The president is facing four indictments: bribery, corruption, betrayal of public trust and violating the constitution. If two-thirds of the country's 22 senators, who are acting as judges, convict him of any of the charges he will be removed from office.

"I was the one who actually handed the money to President Estrada," Mr Singson told the hushed court in proceedings broadcast live across the country.

The president's name was not on the ledger, but Mr Singson said the initials AS referred to Asiong Salonga, the name of a character played by Mr Estrada, a former movie star.

The evidence varied little from the initial claims he made in October when he first blew the whistle on alleged presidential complicity in the numbers-game scam.

Mr Singson said yesterday that operators of the game, called jueteng, were asked to send 3% of their earnings to the president.

During testimony that included him brandishing a $100,000 (£69,000) cheque made payable to cash that allegedly ended up in Mr Estrada's account, Mr Singson also claimed that he collected £1.8m in taxes that were meant to be spent on improving tobacco farmers' welfare.

Hours before beginning his testimony in the five-day hearing Mr Singson told a radio station that he would give explosive new details of the president's corruption.

"I promise to drop a new bomb," he said. "I'm not going to tell you now because it won't be a new bomb any more."

Mr Singson was initially scheduled to begin testifying on Tuesday but prosecutors held him back for a day, until December 13, in the hope that it would prove unlucky for the extremely superstitious Mr Estrada.

However, Mr Estrada was as ebullient as ever yesterday, reiterating his innocence.

"I have not received a single cent from any form of illegal gambling," he said. "My conscience is clear. I am not hiding anything from our people and I believe that in the end the truth will prevail."

The court has already heard from six other witnesses how they had passed money on to members of Mr Estrada's inner circle.

None of their evidence, however, is considered strong enough to convict Mr Estrada by itself.

It is still unclear whether prosecutors have enough votes to secure a conviction.

Prosecutors on Tuesday tried to demonstrate that Mr Estrada accepted bribes from Mr Singson.

They played excerpts of a press conference which took place on November 10 when Mr Estrada admitted being offered £2.8m, but insisted he rejected it.

The money ended up in the account of a foundation Mr Estrada controlled, a fact he never declared, claiming he was "too busy".

If convicted of this, he faces a six-year prison term for the oversight.

webTitle: Search for 160 asylum seekers feared drowned off Australia

fields.headline: Search for 160 asylum seekers feared drowned off Australia
fields.trailText: More than 160 people, mostly asylum seekers, are feared drowned in violent storms off Australia's north-western coast yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 160 people, mostly asylum seekers, are feared drowned in violent storms off Australia's north-western coast yesterday.

A Japanese tanker reportedly picked up four people but hopes of finding other survivors from the two small vessels which were carrying a total of 167 people appear slim.

The asylum seekers, thought to be from the Middle East, had paid smugglers to be taken from Indonesia, across the Timor Sea to the remote Australian island of Ashmore Reef, 200 miles north-west of the mainland Australia.

Australia's hard-line immigration minister, Philip Ruddock, described the deaths as "tragic" but said it should act as a deterrent to others seeking refuge in Australia.

"I think it's appropriate that people are aware of the very significant risks involved," he said. "If people are intent on getting into vulnerable vessels on very dangerous seas then there are risks associated with it.

"We're dealing here with a group of people whose intention was to arrive without no tice, clandestinely, on vessels that really don't have the sort of navigational devices and identification equipment that would enable a search-and-rescue operation to be mounted," said Mr Ruddock.

Conditions in the Timor Sea were "atrocious", Mr Ruddock said, following the 175mph winds of Cyclone Sam which battered the north-west coast over the weekend. A search of Australian waters by the navy, customs service and federal police will resume tomorrow.

The route from Indonesia to Ashmore Reef is well-travelled by refugees, usually taking two to three days. Australia has a permanent customs patrol stationed in the area, and more than 1,000 "boat people" have been intercepted since July, most en route to the reef.

"Recently we've seen people from Afghanistan, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Syria and a small number of Palestinians," Mr Ruddock said.

Indonesian authorities said that the smuggling ringleader who chartered the boats which sank yesterday had fled Indonesia, fearing reprisals.

More than 250 suspected illegal immigrants were feared drowned in April after three boats went missing between Indonesia and Australia. Mr Ruddock estimated that a third of all boats trying to smuggle people into Australia never arrive.

Canberra has met increasing international criticism over its treatment of asylum seekers. Three United Nations reports have condemned Canberra's human rights record this year, criticising the detention of asylum seekers aged under 16 and attacking the two-year wait immigrants endure to receive social security benefits.

Guidelines from the UN High Commissioner for Refugees say that asylum seekers should only be detained during the initial assessment and that children should be spared detention. The Australian government places all asylum seekers, including women and children, in privately run detention camps while their claims are assessed.

A government-led internal investigation is currently under way at the Woomera detention centre, in South Australia, after widespread claims of ill-treatment and child abuse. The former conservative prime minister Malcolm Fraser called Woomera a "hell hole", while Amnesty International has requested access to the centre to investigate reports that children were restrained with plastic handcuffs.

Mr Ruddock claims that the detention camps, which provide basic facilities inside barbed-wire compounds, act as an important deterrent to asylum seekers considering Australia as a possible refuge.

Underlining the government's "zero tolerance" of asylum seekers, nine illegal immigrants were arrested at Sydney fish markets in a dawn raid yesterday.
