fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: American held over bombings | Turkish police stage protests | Six killed in Ecuador blast
fields.body:
American held over bombings

Police in Saudi Arabia have arrested an American suspected of involvement in two car bombings which killed a Briton and wounded four others last month.

A Saudi newspaper identified the suspect as Michael Sedlak, believed to have worked in Riyadh.

Christopher Rodway, 47, was killed and his wife hurt by a car bomb on November 17. An attack six days later injured three more Britons. Saudi officials have been hinting at a non-political motive.
Brian Whitaker

Turkish police stage protests

Thousands of Turkish police officers outraged by the killings of two colleagues yesterday held a second day of nationwide protests at low pay and an amnesty that would release criminals but exclude police convicted of torture.

Prosecutor Seyfettin Erdem is considering whether the officers had broken a law banning unauthorised protests.
AP
Ankara

Six killed in Ecuador blast

Six people were killed yesterday in the second attack in a week on Ecuador's only crude pipeline, state oil company Petroecuador said yesterday.

The dead had been in a bus passing the pipeline when it was ruptured by a series of explosions, which a Petroecuador official said were triggered by a bomb.
Reuters
Quito

Nigeria given debt boost

The Paris Club of creditor nations agreed yesterday to reschedule £16.2bn of Nigeria's external debt.

The deal will cut payment on Nigeria's debt to £700m next year. The group accounts for 75% of Nigeria's external debt.
AP
Paris

fields.headline: Terrorists glorify death of Briton
fields.standfirst: Greek group tries to justify its murder of defence attache
fields.trailText: Greek group tries to justify its murder of defence attache
fields.body:
The Greek terrorist group responsible for killing the British defence attache Stephen Saunders in Athens last June, yesterday boasted that he was their most important victim in 25 years of violent operations.

In a chilling six-page proclamation published in the Greek daily Eleftherotypia, "November 17", Europe's most elusive terrorist outfit, said that Saunders played a major role in last year's Nato bombing of Yugoslavia - which outraged many Greeks - and taunted security agencies for their inability to protect "sensitive" targets in Greece. Eleftherotypia said it found the declaration in a bin in central Athens after a tip-off.

Saunders was killed as he drove to work in Athens on June 8. The group said that his assassins were able to zigzag through Athens' notorious traffic on a motorcycle carrying a large G-3 assault rifle. They pulled up beside the car and shot him twice.

Saunders "was not a simple routine defence attache", the group said. It charged that he "had an active participation in all the imperialist interventions and war carried out in recent years by the British military forces in different countries, committing a crime against their peoples."

In London, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, dismissed the allegations. "I strongly condemn November 17's attempt to justify their brutal murder of Stephen Saunders." Mr Cook said Saunders played no role in the Nato campaign and was on a posting in Kuwait at the time the bombing began.

In the wake of the assassination, Greek police invited anti-terrorism experts from Scotland Yard to help search for his killers. FBI investigators have been in the Greek capital helping the hunt for several years but no one as yet from the group has ever been caught.

During a visit to Athens at the end of October, Mr Cook made an appeal on television for anyone with information about the group to come forward. Saunders's widow, Heather, also urged Greeks to help catch the killers.

British diplomatic sources said in Athens last night: "We are satisfied with cooperation between the two forces and that the commitment of the Greek police to bring the murderers of Stephen Saunders to justice is clear."

But Greek police sources say that despite the publicity no new leads have emerged.

November 17 is a small, tightly knit group that has its roots in the resistance to the colonels' regime which ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974. It is named after the date of a 1973 student uprising at the Athens polytechnic which was brutally crushed by the junta's tanks. The group espouses a virulent mixture of Marxism and extreme nationalism.

Since murdering Richard Welch, the CIA chief in Athens, in December 1975, it has openly defied security services by striking, seemingly at will, against carefully selected and mostly heavily protected targets. It has killed 23 people during more than 100 attacks.

Many of its operations are aimed at western European military, diplomatic, and business links with Greece. But it has also targeted many Greeks - shipowners, bankers, and politicians, people the group claim have been enriching themselves at "the people's expense" and who have sold out Greece to western interests.

Some commentators believe that the failure to even arrest a suspect - which, with the 2004 Olympic Games on the horizon has put the government of Costas Simitis under intense international pressure - is because there may be influential figures in Greece who also came from the "polytechnic generation" and who do not want to see their former comrades punished.

But George Kassimeris, author of Europe's Last Red Terrorists, the first book on N17, believes that the group's campaign of violence has exposed many deficiencies within the country's political system and state structure, "irresolute administrations, unreliable intelligence services, inadequate police forces, and a cumbersome judicial system."

"After two-and-a-half decades of bombings, rocket attacks, assassinations, kneecappings, and shootings in broad daylight, Greece's counter-terrorism effort is ramshackle," he said. "Governments in other countries afflicted by terrorism have their shortcomings but the ineptitude of the Greek state has been unparalleled."

Kassimeris said the statement was, in part, a response to the Greek public reaction since the Saunders killing, and part "a declaration of defiance of a quarter of a century of violence with impunity".

"November 17 are very publicity conscious. The dignified response by Heather Saunders following her husband's murder in which she did not blame all Greeks for the killing, struck a chord in Greece," he said.

He also said that the government is approaching the problem "with a new seriousness."

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Edward Brooks writes: At least one of the obituaries of Malcolm Bradbury mentioned the celebration of his elusiveness suggested in the University of East Anglia graffito: "What is the difference between God and Malcolm Bradbury? God is everywhere, Malcolm Bradbury is everywhere but here."
fields.body:
Edward Brooks writes: At least one of the obituaries of Malcolm Bradbury mentioned the celebration of his elusiveness suggested in the University of East Anglia graffito: "What is the difference between God and Malcolm Bradbury? God is everywhere, Malcolm Bradbury is everywhere but here." So when I saw Graham Swift's letter (Obituaries, December 5) about his pipe smoking, I was reminded of my wife's first impression of Malcolm. She is much affected by film and, seeing him standing in the doorway of his office wreathed in vapour, felt she had seen something similar before. She briefly looked away, but when she returned her gaze he had gone, leaving just the swirling smoke: Leslie Howard on the railway station in Pimpernel Smith.

James Ross Moore writes: In addition to his prolific songwriting and an innovative television career, Steve Allen (Obituary, November 6) authored a shelf full of books. While a number applied a light historian/scientist touch to the art of humour, Allen's moral and politically liberal concerns often came to the fore. These were particularly evident in Ripoff: A Look At Corruption In America (1979), whose chapters teemed with information and indignation about underhanded dealings in the police, show business, politics, labour unions, the military, etc. Occasionally salted with personal experience, the largely derivative material acquired power when thus assembled. Often thought naive, always proof against cynicism, Allen really believed that words could "change things".

fields.headline: Julian Dixon
fields.standfirst: Influential black US politician who courted the middle-class vote
fields.trailText: Influential black US politician who courted the middle-class vote
fields.body:
Julian Dixon, one of the most influential and well-regarded black members of the US House of Representatives, has died suddenly aged 66. In November, the Los Angeles suburban district he had represented for the past 22 years returned him to Washington with 84% of its vote. The area bears no resemblance to the common stereotype of a Los Angeles black-majority neighbourhood. The largest portion of Baldwin Hills' 500,000 inhabitants are blacks with a household income well above average, many of them working in government and other public sector jobs.

That allows them to observe the evident benefits of public spending, and few have been tempted into the Republican party, which might otherwise be thought their natural political home. Dixon's moderate and judicious approach to politics, despite sniping from some of his fiercer Democratic colleagues, always found a strong response from a middle-class electorate with little time for barnstorming. His support came from as many whites as blacks.

Dixon was born in Washington DC, the son of a post-office worker. His family moved to California when he was 11, and he finished his education there. After military service he embarked on a legal career, but decided to move into politics and won a seat in the California assembly in 1972. Six years later, he moved on to the national scene when the Baldwin Hills incumbent vacated her congressional seat.

Though Dixon kept a generally low profile when he got to Capitol Hill, he soon established a reputation as a reliable member, ready to take on any of the dozens of mildly disagreeable chores that accrue around public office. Eventually he rose to the leadership of the Congressional Black Caucus, a ginger group which can exercise considerable muscle.

In the early 1980s, one of its chosen targets was the South African apartheid regime, and Dixon was a leader in the campaign to bring Pretoria's racial policies much higher up the American national agenda. At one point he was arrested for staging a vociferous protest outside the South African embassy. A little later, however, he was able to reassure his party's moderates by using his position as chairman of the Democratic convention's rules committee to swat away some of the Rev Jesse Jackson's wilder proposals.

This sort of balancing act was very much the Dixon style and he needed all his skills when he found himself running a formal inquiry into the conduct of his own party boss. Dixon was chairman of the House Ethics Committee when the Republican opposition accused the Speaker, Jim Wright, of failing to declare a considerable income from non-congressional sources. The issue was, of course, deeply partisan, and Dixon was faced with a committee that seemed certain to divide along party lines. However, his even-tempered handling of the inquiry, and the fairness with which he accumulated the evidence, gradually cooled the atmosphere. In the end, even his own party colleagues found the speaker guilty of unethical conduct and forced his resignation from the House.

However, the lifeblood of American politics - particularly for those facing election every second year - is a dedication to local interests, and Dixon made sure he always attended to them. One of the major issues in Los Angeles, particularly among its poorer citizens, is the battle to enhance its abysmal public transport system with a new subway. In an area prone to earthquakes it is also not the easiest project to fund.

In the face of considerable opposition from President Reagan, a former governor of California, Dixon used his membership of the House appropriations committee quite ruthlessly to divert federal money into the project. As these huge amounts of cash poured in for the scheme they brought the inevitable allegations of financial misconduct. But even his critics accepted that Dixon was in no way involved in the scandals.

No local problem seemed too small for his attention. When the city's natural history museum lacked funds for an exhibition of dinosaur eggs, Dixon rifled through the federal budget to scoop out a useful $1m. He also bullied the US treasury into stumping up more than $500m to meet California's bills for keeping illegal immigrants in jail. His argument, in the best legal tradition, was that the immigrants may have come over the border into California, but the constitution laid down unequivocally that they were Washington's problem.

Dixon is survived by his wife Bettye and a son from an earlier marriage.

 Julian Dixon, politician, born August 8 1934; died December 8 2000

fields.headline: An ode to Atherton
fields.trailText: Mike Atherton's decisive innings at Karachi was more than "a vigil" . Some years ago a writer flying into the interior of Guyana was drawn to a young man immersed in a Wilson Harris novel. It takes strength of character to negotiate the prose of Harris, a Guyanese novelist who writes in the magical realist mould of Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Intrigued by this intrepid reader, the writer sought his identity: Atherton, the cricketer, she was told.
fields.body:
Mike Atherton's decisive innings at Karachi was more than "a vigil" (Mike Selvey, December 13). Some years ago a writer flying into the interior of Guyana was drawn to a young man immersed in a Wilson Harris novel. It takes strength of character to negotiate the prose of Harris, a Guyanese novelist who writes in the magical realist mould of Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Intrigued by this intrepid reader, the writer sought his identity: Atherton, the cricketer, she was told.

Last week, in Karachi, he self-effacingly characterised his marathon innings as "turgid stuff". In fact, there is something pure, cleansing, elevating in these epics, chiselled out of adversity. Harris, Marquez, Waqar, Saqlain: they are all of a piece; the greater the challenge the more concentrated, worthwhile, the effort. Atherton's "vigils" speak to something inviolable at the heart of cricket.
Clem Seecharan
Head of Caribbean studies, University of North London
hxezseechac@unl.ac.uk

 Rob Steen says the A-Lot's record salary of $252m over the next 10 years "... might strike some as a tad unhealthy" (Sport, December 13). I know who pays. Me! Alex Rodriguez, Tiger Wood, David Beckham's multi-million salaries are funded by money added onto the price of sporting goods that I buy.
Ken Brock
Cleveland
kjha.brock@ntlworld.com

webTitle: Letter: Potted-history of the V sign

fields.headline: Off target
fields.trailText: The V sign is not an "Anglicised version of the definitive US middle finger" (Big up da Windsor massive, December 12). The English were giving two fingers to the French as long ago as the 14th century.
fields.body:
The V sign is not an "Anglicised version of the definitive US middle finger" (Big up da Windsor massive, December 12). The English were giving two fingers to the French as long ago as the 14th century. The English longbow proved lethally decisive at battles such as Crecy, where, outnumbered two to one, the English sustained negligible losses annihilating the forces of King Philip VI.

Captured English archers were returned butchered, minus the index and middle fingers of the right hand, rendering them incapable of drawing a bow. The V sign, indicating fitness to fight, has signalled cool, definitively British defiance ever since.
Martin Palmer
Manchester
fields.bodyText: The V sign is not an "Anglicised version of the definitive US middle finger" (Big up da Windsor massive, December 12). The English were giving two fingers to the French as long ago as the 14th century. The English longbow proved lethally decisive at battles such as Crecy, where, outnumbered two to one, the English sustained negligible losses annihilating the forces of King Philip VI. Captured English archers were returned butchered, minus the index and middle fingers of the right hand, rendering them incapable of drawing a bow. The V sign, indicating fitness to fight, has signalled cool, definitively British defiance ever since. Martin Palmer Manchester

fields.headline: Götz Friedrich
fields.standfirst: Part of an influential wave of East German operatic imports to Britain, his Ring production sealed a historic partnership at Covent Garden
fields.trailText: Part of an influential wave of East German operatic imports to Britain, his Ring production sealed a historic partnership at Covent Garden
fields.body:
The German opera director Götz Friedrich, who has died of cancer in Berlin aged 70, leapt into the spotlight in 1972 with a Bayreuth staging of Tannhäuser that presented the Pilgrims' Chorus as modern socialist workers shaking clenched fists at the well-heeled, dinner-jacketed audience. Frederic Spotts's 1994 history of the Wagner festival called it "the most blatantly ideological production ever" at Bayreuth.

The policy of Wieland and Wolfgang Wagner, after the festival was allowed to restart in 1951, had been to avoid politics. At Bayreuth, Hitler's ghost still walked. Frau Winifred, their English-born mother, continued to entertain old Nazis and loathed the new Bayreuth style. But Friedrich was from East Germany, and a leading disciple of Walter Felsenstein at the Berlin Komische Oper.

Ironically, despite the clenched fists, he defected to the west within a few months - heading for posts in Hamburg, and a historic Covent Garden partnership with Colin Davis and the new Ring production which sealed it. But, unlike his fellow East German Ruth Berghaus, who was to prove a more potent and substantial operatic innovator, he was never really an ideologue (though he was always proud of the role his father played, as an ordinary soldier, in the generals' plot to assassinate Hitler).

There should not have been any opening for Friedrich at the Royal Opera. But in 1971 Peter Hall had parachuted out of his planned Covent Garden partnership with Davis, intended as replacement for Georg Solti's regime, and the general administrator John Tooley was desperate to find a substitute. Friedrich's succès de scandale at Bayreuth happened at just the right time, and Tooley - no doubt with trepidation - persuaded Friedrich to come and direct Covent Garden's new Ring cycle to mark the work's centenary. Friedrich initially hoped for his Tannhäuser designer, Jurgen Rose. But Tooley needed the security of a more renowned name and slotted in the brilliant Czech Josef Svoboda.

What Friedrich brought to the Royal Opera, both while building his Ring and in other work like Freischutz, Idomeneo and Lulu that he undertook as principal producer, was an operatic professionalism in depth that had never actually been part of the establishment there before. The German training for a career in the theatre was something that simply had (and has, alas, still) no equivalent in Britain.

Friedrich studied theatre history for four years in Weimar, and then went straight to the Komische Oper as an assistant to Felsenstein, with whom he remained for two decades, teaching dramaturgy. Like Felsenstein's other leading disciples, Joachim Herz and Harry Kupfer, who were part of the same influential wave of East German imports in London and Cardiff in the 1970s, he was totally committed to the concept of "realistic music theatre".

Opera was basically not to be seen as something culinary for browsing bourgeoisie - just a matter of taste. Rather, it was like the work of Brecht's Berliner Ensemble - in earnest. Which was the only justification, as Friedrich told me, for spending all that taxpayers' money. "If opera had no social function," he once said, "there would be no reason to keep this sound museum going."

The Komische Oper in East Berlin was where the artistic policy of English National Opera originated. After the war, Felsenstein (with certainly no sentiment for communism) was determined that his audience should fully understand their opera, and have a thrillingly theatrical experience. Singing was to be less important, which suited the then financial realities. The quality of the Komische product depended on the fact that directors were working with a company and within a house style.

Friedrich, according to Eleanor Fazan, who was often his movement director at Covent Garden, was extraordinarily passionate about his artistic objectives. "He would shout and scream, and of course the stage management hated him for it. But he was tremendous to work with. If you were responsive to his ideas he loved it, and would take great pains to involve you in his vision."

His assistant on the Royal Opera's Ring, completed in 1976, was Elijah Moshinsky, for whom the director's exercise of power was a forceful example.

After the opening night of his Götterdämmerung at the Royal Opera in 1976, Friedrich told me, "I know in some ways I'm a foolish producer giving hostages to the critics by talking very theoretically in advance about what I'm trying to do. But yesterday I felt that, for all those long six hours, the audience was not shifting in their seats. It was like an audience watching a thriller."

He also felt that, though Covent Garden then was technologically terrible, "I, as a foreigner, know that this Ring could not have been done in any other house in Europe. People here were working 14 or 16 hours a day."

Friedrich was not a teamwork man, but a dictator. "He was difficult because he doesn't give you any freedom", Elisabeth Soderstrom, his Jenufa in Stockholm in 1975, said. "I had perhaps other ideas about the reactions of Jenufa. It took me a very long time to bring them out through his pattern. But when I saw the rest of the jigsaw puzzle around me I understood him better."

Josef Svoboda's Ring design for Friedrich used a powerful piston to raise, swivel and incline a platform, sometimes like the lid of a box, sometimes like a stage floor. This was very suggestive of a world below what you could see (Niebelhem) or just offstage, enormously enhancing the sense of epic fantasy. Jurgen Rose's Bayreuth Tannhäuser presented the Wartburg like a wedding cake iced with wooden flooring: Friedrich got Gwynneth Jones as Elisabeth to throw herself exuberantly into the role, racing along the top of this platform before launching into "Dich teure halle".

Svoboda's ideas for Friedrich's first Covent Garden Ring were much more compelling, in a middle European expressionist style, than Peter Sykora's ideas for Friedrich's later, 1991, Berlin and Washington Ring which Covent Garden picked up as a poor substitute for the failed Yuri Lyubimov Ring in 1988. This was a sign of desperation, and really done just to help Bernard Haitink have his own Ring staging.

The limitation of Friedrich's work in the opera tended to be his fairly conventional visual taste - in terms of prevailing German expressionism. Leather greatcoats, what looked like swimming caps covering women's hair, heavy rather ungainly clothes, a kind of theatrical costuming that belonged nowhere except in the theatre - these became the tired norms of his work. In fact his aesthetic insensitivity made it difficult for him to move beyond the standard visual references of German operatic theatre. A director like Patrice Chereau, whose Bayreuth Ring was even more of a resonating scandal and success than Friedrich's Tannhäuser, was always more aesthetically sophisticated - more romantic perhaps, and no less interpretative. Friedrich's Ring suffered by comparison with Chereau's.

His interpretative style and vision were never as original or challenging as Chereau's and Berghaus's best work - though many early productions, such as his Meistersinger in Stockholm, were deservedly admired. Like many who get fame as enfants terribles for a brief time, Friedrich was overtaken by younger, more lively talents as the 1980s wore on. What he liked about his Ring designer Svoboda, he told me, was that Svoboda was neither picturesque nor pictorial, but understood the true expressive nature of the theatre space. "Aesthetic in the theatre is for me - this sounds awful - function. It must function. I don't mean only the technical function, but narrative, epic, dramaturgical, poetic."

In 1981 Friedrich became one of the most powerful figures on the German operatic scene, as Intendant of the Deutsche Oper in Berlin, the Western sector of the city's answer to the East's old Staatsoper. Berlin's problem, that since reunification it has too much operatic plant for one city, still awaits successful rationalisation.

Friedrich's work at its best was true both to the music and to the meaning. He didn't believe it would be appropriate to mess around with the overt narrative of a Puccini opera, for example. But his Aida at the circus theatre, the Carre in Amsterdam, was a superb ritual - set in the round, which, while it made the final incarceration of the pair of doomed lovers problematical, made the public scenes in the first half very thrilling.

He was not a director for The Marriage of Figaro. He didn't have much interest in comedy. At Bayreuth, that initial Tannhäuser and the later Parsifal in a sort of time-travel science fiction tower were startling and intensely effective. At the Royal Opera House his Lulu, his Caspar David Friedrich-inspired Freischutz, and his 1970s (first) Ring cycle were among the most accomplished opera productions Covent Garden has enjoyed.

When he decamped to the west Friedrich left behind his first wife, actress Ruth Maria Kubitschek, and his son Alexander. His second wife, with whom he also had a son, Johannes, was the American opera-singer Karan Armstrong - Lulu in his 1981 Covent Garden staging of the Berg. His final staging - Menotti's Amahl and the Night Visitors - was premiered only last week in Berlin.

webTitle: Letters: Hastings bypass hits a dead end

fields.headline: Hastings bypass hits a dead end
fields.trailText: The excellent report on the Hastings bypasses (Road rage, Society, December 13) misses an essential point - as does the consultant's final report. If a political decision is made to allow the bypasses to be built and, in particular, the eastern section "which wrecks an area of outstanding natural beauty", where does it go from there?
fields.body:
The excellent report on the Hastings bypasses (Road rage, Society, December 13) misses an essential point - as does the consultant's final report. If a political decision is made to allow the bypasses to be built and, in particular, the eastern section "which wrecks an area of outstanding natural beauty", where does it go from there?

As proposed, it stops dead at its eastern end on an unimprovable A259 - no more than a country lane in traffic terms. This winds its way through the High Weald area of outstanding natural beauty and the medieval streets of Winchelsea and Rye. These are unique in their rural setting, surrounded by sites of special scientific interest, National Trust land, and the flood plains of the Brede and Rother rivers. Finally, it mean ders across the Walland and Romney marshes and levels on its ancient way to Ashford and Folkestone. This is not joined-up thinking. The omission of this essential point from an otherwise in depth study is hard to understand.
Dr Mike Theis
University of Westminster
fmaxlockc@wmin.ac.uk

 John Vidal (Battle over bypasses may hinge on Hastings, December 12) infers some reports have been hastily rushed through. The report on the Access to Hastings study has in fact appeared nearly six months later than planned. Objectors say they hope to draw a line in the sand over a Hastings bypass. It seemed for many years that a line had already been drawn in the sand, as Hastings remains the only coastal town in the country not to have been given a bypass. The results of the recent consultation confirm that Hastings residents overwhelmingly want to see that line in the sand moved to permit Hastings what other towns take for granted.

Hastings & Rye is indeed a key three way marginal. All three main political parties locally have supported the bypass. John Prescott stated earlier this year that he was minded to permit the bypass. If the government is now considering backing down, the issue will certainly feature largely in Hastings voters minds when they next do their public duty.
Graem Peters
Lib Dem prospective parliamentary candidate
Hastings & Rye

fields.headline: Some hairy questions
fields.trailText: If Libby Brooks is so keen on the Opium poster ad, perhaps she can suggest what I should say to my two-year-old when we pass it on the way home from nursery and he asks, "What's the lady doing?"
fields.body:
If Libby Brooks is so keen on the Opium poster ad (Anatomy of desire, December 12; Letters, December 13), perhaps she can suggest what I should say to my two-year-old when we pass it on the way home from nursery and he asks, "What's the lady doing?" ("Pretending to be gagging for it in order to make a lot of money for herself and the perfume company"?). If this is an image of "what sex could actually look like", how come the woman has no pubic hair?
Helen Tookey
Liverpool

 So, many people think Zadie Smith is "bitchy, supercilious, smug, cold, a fake" (White Knuckle Ride, December 11). I have known her for 10 years. She is warm and genuine, a hugely supportive and, yes, very funny woman. I know success attracts resentment, but that does not mean you have to slag her off in inverted commas.
Daisy Houghton
London

 Karen Gold suggests both Wittgenstein and Einstein might have had Asperger's syndrome, a form of autism (Health, December 12). I made the same suggestion about the philosopher AJ Ayer in my biography of him. Some reviewers were sceptical, so I take comfort from Gold's fascinating article.
Ben Rogers
London

 We must hope that Roy Hattersley (Comment, December 11) will not suffer the fate of George Bernard Shaw in his old age and find himself being injected with beef extract.
Ted Short
Thornbury, Glos

 The older person may well find it easy to solve crosswords because they are set by older people (Letters, December 11) ... my uncle will be 80 in February and makes up most of the ones you are all solving.
Patrick Graham
(nephew of John Graham)
Cardiff

fields.headline: After the Vauxhall crash
fields.trailText: Vauxhall's decision to withdraw from Luton will not come as a surprise to anyone who analyses what the UK is best at in the 21st century (Vauxhall to axe 2,000 jobs, December 13). What it isn't best at is industrial mass production.
fields.body:
Vauxhall's decision to withdraw from Luton will not come as a surprise to anyone who analyses what the UK is best at in the 21st century (Vauxhall to axe 2,000 jobs, December 13). What it isn't best at is industrial mass production. Ford and BMW's decision earlier in the year to scale back in the UK underlines this point. Longbridge in the Midlands is making a bold attempt to reinvent itself as a heartland for nano-technological development. This isn't brave, it's realistic.

In Europe, the UK has a reputation for excellence in financial services, the media, telecommunications, IT, biotechnology, travel and tourism. None of them blue-collar, metal-bashing industries. The centre of gravity for those industries has shifted eastwards to the emerging nations of eastern Europe.

The UK should welcome the loss of its mass car production. It's a wake up call to get fit for the next decade. While there's still time.
Patrick Koller
Zurich
patrick.koller@adcore.com

 Why, people will be right to ask, is it that a modern British plant is axed and German and other European countries factories untouched? The answer is simple. They are in the euro and we are not. All of us who have worked for major car company's suppliers know the truth. We can't compete against companies in the eurozone and when investment decisions are made the volatility of the pound sounds the death knell for any hope of the UK benefiting from multinationals' actions.
Robert Coppinger
St Neots, Cambs
rob_coppinger@hotmail.com

 One is reminded again of this Labour government's policy concerning employees' rights. These were decimated by Margaret Thatcher and Labour has since done little to remedy that. Many workers now also have to contend with unpaid overtime. Why is this such a sadly neglected area of Labour's long-term plan?
Mark Walker
London
mwalker2@dircon.co.uk

 It is difficult to reconcile Vauxhall's treatment of its employees and the townspeople of Luton with Claire Short's conversion to the benefits of capitalism in third world countries. If we cannot control the destructive decisions of large companies to devastate the economies of our major conurbations, what chance is there for those countries with negligible political power to protect their citizens from exploitation?
Charles Tyrie
Nottingham

 Larry Elliott says we need "a route to people-friendly globalisation" (A setback for Global Megabucks plc, December 11). Yes, but the primary way of finding that route would be through achieving respect for core labour standards worldwide.

This would not result in lower exports for developing countries, since trade unions do not wish to negotiate such high wages that they price their members out of a job. Unions should have the legal rights to negotiate the highest attainable level of wages that their employers, and the local economy, can afford.

Wages in developing countries would rise to match increases in productivity, rather than lagging far behind the accumulation of riches in the hands of elites. But such governments are under pressure to violate workers' rights in order to succeed in the global marketplace when, countries like China systematically violate core labour standards.

Enforcing workers' rights throughout the international system would outlaw illegitimate competition from authoritarian governments to exploit their workers to boost exports.
Bill Jordan
International Confederation of Free Trade Unions
Brussels

fields.headline: All over bar the shouting
fields.trailText: So if you delay, obstruct, intimidate and challenge the counting of votes for long enough you will indeed triumph as time runs out for democracy (Florida moves to hand Bush victory, December 13).
fields.body:
So if you delay, obstruct, intimidate and challenge the counting of votes for long enough you will indeed triumph as time runs out for democracy (Florida moves to hand Bush victory, December 13). Explicit in the supreme court decision seems to be the acceptance that there are a number of legitimate votes in Florida that have not been counted, but that there is no time to do so.

The supreme court itself has helped to ensure that time would run out by initially halting the recount and then, amazingly, waiting until the final few minutes of December 12 before issuing its decision. It (almost) makes our 100% hand-count electoral system seem sophisticated and fair.
Steve Norman
Edinburgh
Norm1962@hotmail.com

 It is worth reflecting once again that the winner is the candidate with the fewer votes, largely because of an arcane system which was specifically designed to temper the expression of the will of the people. The chance to rectify this situation was disallowed because votes could not be counted properly. As Jim Royle might say: "World's greatest democracy? My arse!"
Rod Lipscombe
Faversham, Kent
rodlipscombe@yahoo.com

 I seem to remember the law lords' decision on Pinochet being rescinded because one of them was perceived to have a conflict of interest due to his connections with Amnesty International. Isn't the lesson of the US election that it is folly to have a judiciary which is politically appointed and partisan?
Martin Fey
Bristol
martin.fey@capitafhe.co.uk

 Al Gore wins 300,000 more votes yet Dubya, aided by his father (former director of the CIA), his brother (governor of Florida) and his cousin (Fox TV anchorman who fed sensitive information to the Bush camp on election night) is declared the winner. Hail to the thief.
Brian Glancey
Airdrie, Lanarks

 Talk of the similarity of the current American electoral chaos to that of 1876 prompts me to a second comparison, one that offers hope to the beleaguered Gore camp. In 1828 another leading Tennessee Democrat stormed to victory in the presidential contest. The basis of Andrew Jackson's campaign was that, having received the highest popular vote four years earlier, he had been deprived of the presidency after a "corrupt bargain" between his opponents.
Martin Crawford
Keele University
m.s.crawford@ams.keele.ac.uk

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Bravely seeking to salvage a fly-on-the-wall docusoap about the rival euro camps from the wreckage of a referendum that never was, BBC2 shows the Battle for the Euro on Sunday. Impartiality won't be at issue - presenter Jane Corbin's marriage to leading Tory Eurosceptic John Maples is irrelevant, as are publicity flyers reading "Keep the pound".
fields.body:
 Bravely seeking to salvage a fly-on-the-wall docusoap about the rival euro camps from the wreckage of a referendum that never was, BBC2 shows the Battle for the Euro on Sunday. Impartiality won't be at issue - presenter Jane Corbin's marriage to leading Tory Eurosceptic John Maples is irrelevant, as are publicity flyers reading "Keep the pound".

But what excites are interviews with Mark Littlewood, a Tory who worked for a precursor of pro-euro umbrella body Britain in Europe until last year. Despite receiving a letter from Giles Radice banning him from the premises, Mr Littlewood turned up the Saturday before last, according to the security guard's report, and tried to enter with a companion and a laptop at 11.45pm.

First he claimed to be an employee, then said he was investigating "corruption", and finally threatened to get the guard sacked. Touchwood the show is half as exciting as the night-time adventures of Mr Littlewood, who declines to return calls.

 Contestants on the Weakest Link are ruder than Anne Robinson. Asked the name of Cherie Blair's new chambers, also the name of a 1999 movie, a contender said: "the Blair Witch Project". Need they be so personal? (The Matrix is the answer.)

 When we left Express chief Richard Desmond's Best of Forum, 80-year-old DB, Address Withheld - one of the Gloucestershire Address Withhelds, we suspect - was recalling how in Germany once he was in bed with Lilla when her mother Gerda walked in. "Now I'm in trouble," thought DB, but far from it. "She (Gerda) ... leaned forward and her hands grasped my prick before she..." but enough.

DB ends by saying he often wonders what became of them. "The thoughts of that night are still with me," he says, "and, as I gently rub my old cock, I wish I could turn the clock back." Or is that "rub my old clock, I wish I could turn the cock back"? Can't quite make it out. Must be going blind.

 Still, at least Rizla Rosie Boycott is adapting to her new boss. She and Mr Desmond were overheard last night, apparently, discussing the contents of today's Express. "Well, naturally we've got several pages of Bush," said Rizla. "Well done," he replied. "I knew you'd come round in the end."

 Previously with the chicken soup:

1) clean and quarter a boiler, bring saucepan to boil, turn down to simmer and skim thrice;

2) leave for two hours on low flame, add giblets (neck, heart and gizzard) and vegetables (large onion, carrots, celery and petrushka, salt and pepper);

3) bring back to boil, skim again, back to simmer for two hours with lid half on;

4) when cool, put in fridge overnight;

5) cut off fat layer, remove chicken and veg, strain soup till clear.

And now to the concluding episode:

6) put small bits of chicken and chopped veg back into reheated soup;

7) boil egg vermicelli (must be egg);

8) add tiny, yellow, chicken yolk eggs to soup (if you can, get them off butcher; if not, don't worry);

9) put egg vermicelli in colander over soup to warm;

10) serve, putting bit of chicken, vermicelli, veg and a couple of eggs in each bowl;

11) enjoy;

12) have seconds;

13) engage in rancorous dispute over refusal to have thirds.

That is all.

 Kevin Richardson emails. "Could you tell me what a petrushka is? You described it as a "white root", but of what?" Of parsley, Kevin. It has a green top and resembles a parsnip.

"Presumably they can be found in Jewish shops, but would they be available elsewhere?" Have you considered a greengrocer, Kevin? A crazy idea, but it may just be worth a shot.

 My mother calls. "The veal bone," she shouts. "I forgot to mention the veal bone that goes in at the start." A fierce debate ensues, and eventually we agree that the veal bone probably isn't crucial after all. Let's hope not.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • In our report of the legal hearings concerning Neil Hamilton and Mohamed Al Fayed, page 2, yesterday, we quoted Mr Hamilton's lawyer, Anthony Boswood QC, saying it was "inconceivable" that Mr Fayed had not known what was happening (over payment for allegedly stolen documents). The report then continued, without quotation marks, to say, "though it was apparently kept secret from his [Mr Fayed's] legal team". We want to make it clear that Mr Fayed's legal team knew nothing about the allegedly stolen documents in question - nor did Mr Boswood, in fact, suggest that Mr Fayed's legal team might have known. Apologies if that passage in our report appeared to suggest otherwise.
fields.body:
 In our report of the legal hearings concerning Neil Hamilton and Mohamed Al Fayed, page 2, yesterday, we quoted Mr Hamilton's lawyer, Anthony Boswood QC, saying it was "inconceivable" that Mr Fayed had not known what was happening (over payment for allegedly stolen documents). The report then continued, without quotation marks, to say, "though it was apparently kept secret from his [Mr Fayed's] legal team". We want to make it clear that Mr Fayed's legal team knew nothing about the allegedly stolen documents in question - nor did Mr Boswood, in fact, suggest that Mr Fayed's legal team might have known. Apologies if that passage in our report appeared to suggest otherwise.

 In an article headed, Do we need 24-hour gossip? page 42, Media, December 11, we stated that the 16 portals planned by Trinity Mirror had now dwindled to just four. This is factually incorrect. Trinity Mirror Digital continues to work towards the launch of all its planned sites. These include 13 regional sites, icSport and icChoice - in addition to icShowbiz, which was launched on December 8 and icScotland, which was launched in March this year, and not last month as stated in our article.

 Joan Ruddock, MP for Lewisham, Deptford, has asked us to point out that contrary to any suggestion in an article about a citizenship exercise among schoolchildren in her constituency, page 8, Education, December 12, she has lived in the constituency since she was elected 14 years ago. She says she is a frequent visitor to the Pepys Estate and well aware of the concerns of her constituents there.

webTitle: Gore concedes presidential race after the fight of his life

fields.headline: Gore concedes presidential race after the fight of his life
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Democrat Al Gore surrendered his battle for the White House, accepting Republican George W Bush as the 43rd president of the United States. "I accept the finality of this outcome," the vice president said.
fields.body:
Democrat Al Gore surrendered his battle for the White House, accepting Republican George W Bush as the 43rd president of the United States. "I accept the finality of this outcome," the vice president said.

In a valedictory Wednesday night from the ceremonial office at the White House he will vacate, Gore signalled some of the reluctance to concede defeat that propelled his 36-day legal battle for Florida ballot recounts.

"Now the US Supreme Court has spoken. Let there be no doubt," Gore said. "While I strongly disagree with the court's position, I accept it."

He called for his supporters to unite behind his Republican rival Bush. "We close ranks when the contest is done," Gore said.

"While we yet hold - and do not yield - our opposing beliefs, there is a higher duty than the one we owe to political party. This is America and we put country before party," Gore said. "We will stand together behind our new president."

Addressing people abroad, Gore said: "Let no one see this contest as a sign of American weakness. The strength of American democracy is seen most clearly through the difficulties it can overcome."

Standing behind Gore in the ornate White House office were his wife, Tipper, their four children, running mate Senator Joseph Lieberman and his family.

Gore recognized that the 50m voters who cast their ballots for Gore-Lieberman on November 7 were disappointed. "I am too. Our disappointment must be overcome by our love of country," he said from an armoured presidential lectern missing its presidential seal.

Gore spoke minutes after telephoning his congratulations to Bush in the Texas governor's mansion and made a weak joke about the election night drama in which Gore called Bush twice - once to concede, once to retract. "I promised him that I wouldn't call him back this time," Gore said in the nationally televised address.

The rivals are to meet next Tuesday in Washington - a man-to-man summit meant to pull the deeply divided nation together after an unprecedented court battle over the White House.

Gore, a senator's son and 16-year veteran of Congress, says he doesn't know what comes next for him after 24 years in public office.

Clinton telephoned from Northern Ireland minutes after news broke Wednesday morning that Gore was giving up. The two political partners had grown apart during the campaign, in which the vice-president laboured to distance himself from Clinton's personal scandals.

More than 103m Americans who went to the polls on Nov 7 gave Gore a lead of about 330,000 over Bush.

The US supreme court pushed Gore from his overtime struggle for an electoral majority when it ruled late Tuesday that further recounts in Florida could not meet constitutional muster in time for the December 18 Electoral College vote.

Gore privately conceded to Bush once before, in the wee hours of November 8. But as the Florida vote appeared less certain, Gore called the Texas governor back to retract the concession, touching off the unthinkable election contest.

Aides who worked nearly two years on Gore's presidential campaign betrayed on Wednesday - in not-for-attribution remarks and casual asides - their bitterness about a split Supreme Court ruling they viewed as partisan and about Republican advantages they saw as stacked against them.

Gore had mounted his recount in a state where Bush's brother, Jeb, is governor and the Republican secretary of state who certified Bush's victory was also co-chairwoman of his Florida campaign.

Outside the residence, where Gore was with wife and their four children, two of whom hastened from homes out of town, a lone supporter held a "Gore 2004" sign.

Gore must leave the house before Republican Dick Cheney is sworn in as his replacement on January 20. For the eight years they lived there, the Gores loaned brother-in-law Frank Hunger the Arlington, Virginia, home where Tipper Gore grew up and they raised their own family.

Associates said Gore, 52, had been so focused on the five weeks of legal wrangling that he never spoke - out loud, at least - about where his life might turn in defeat. Aboard Air Force Two one September night, the one-time newspaper reporter mused about maybe being "a writer of some kind."

Some who know him well speculated he might turn to academia. Both Princeton and Harvard, his alma mater, will have vacancies at the helm next year.

fields.headline: Homes subsidy for key workers
fields.standfirst: Plan to provide interest-free loans to nurses, teachers and police priced out of property hotspots in London and the south-east
fields.trailText: Nurses, teachers and other essential workers on average salaries priced out of property hotspots such as London and the south-east could soon be offered government subsidies of up to £25,000 to help buy their first home, under plans unveiled yesterday.
fields.body:
Nurses, teachers and other essential workers on average salaries priced out of property hotspots such as London and the south-east could soon be offered government subsidies of up to £25,000 to help buy their first home, under plans unveiled yesterday.

Designed for middle England in the run-up to a general election, the proposed starter homes initiative will involve interest-free top-up loans, cash for deposits and help with shared ownership schemes where a housing association might own half the equity.

But with the scheme due to begin operating next summer, the Department of the Environment, which oversees housing, says it is banking on other Whitehall departments and employers chipping in to boost a central fund from which the cash will be distributed.

Although the department has promised £250m, John Prescott, the environment secretary, is hoping that the Home Office and the Department for Education and Employment - responsible for police and teachers respectively - will provide extra funding. Talks are being held with the Council of Mortgage Lenders to see how the scheme will work in practice.

Nick Raynsford, the housing minister, who announced yesterday that the scheme would be designed to help 10,000 workers, has said the initiative might depend on private companies providing subsidies to match government cash in areas of high housing demand, such as the south-east, where property prices rose by 23% last year.

In operational guidance published yesterday, the Department of the Environment said the scheme would be aimed at groups of essential workers - nurses, teachers and the police - in areas where there were "demonstrable recruitment and retention difficulties".

The initiative would be concentrated on homes in the bottom quarter of house prices.

When the scheme was first floated, the idea was for top-up loans of up to £50,000 on houses at the lower end of the market costing £125,000 or less. But a potential buyer would still have to find a commercial lender to give a £75,000 mortgage.

Although it is still not clear who will operate the scheme on the ground, local councils - and particularly government-funded housing associations - are being targeted as the most likely agents to deliver the subsidies.

webTitle: Oklahoma City bomber asks to be put to death

fields.headline: Oklahoma City bomber asks to be put to death
fields.trailText: Timothy McVeigh, author of the Oklahoma City bombing that killed 168 people in the worst terrorist attack on United States soil, says he wants to die.
fields.body:
Timothy McVeigh, author of the Oklahoma City bombing that killed 168 people in the worst terrorist attack on United States soil, says he wants to die.

"I believe I am fully competent to make this decision," said the 32-year-old, who was sentenced to death three years ago. "I will not justify or explain my decision to any psychologist but will answer any questions related to my competency."

McVeigh said in a statement filed with the Denver court where he was sentenced for the 1995 bombing which also injured 500, that he wants the remaining appeals halted and that his execution should be within the next four months.

The former soldier, who is on death row in Indiana, has lost two appeals, pursued on the grounds of jury misconduct, reports that he had confessed to his lawyers and inadequate legal representation.

"I understand the appellate issues and, understanding those issues, I persist in my decision to forego appeal," he said. "It is not my desire by waiving appeal to delay my execution. I request that the court set an execution date or order the Bureau of Prisons to do the same."

Nathan Chambers, one of McVeigh's lawyers, said his client still has the right to make a request to the president seeking clemency.

"We believe there are multiple grounds left for appeal and ultimately a new trial, but he doesn't want to go on," he said. "I can't tell you why Mr McVeigh did what he did."

Jannie Coverdale, who lost two grandsons in the Oklahoma attack, said: "I don't know what to think. I have always believed there is more to this story than we've been told and when Tim dies the truth will die with him.

"I don't want him to die on his own terms," she said. "My grandsons didn't die on their own terms. They died when Tim was ready for them to die.

fields.headline: Plan to 'rebuild' NHS in Scotland
fields.trailText: Scottish health minister Susan Deacon today pledged to "rebuild" the NHS in Scotland around the needs of patients by cutting waiting times and bureaucracy.Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Scottish health minister Susan Deacon today pledged to "rebuild" the NHS in Scotland around the needs of patients by cutting waiting times and bureaucracy, and launching "the biggest health improvement drive ever seen" north of the border.

Launching the Scottish NHS plan - called Our National Health - Ms Deacon said it would tackle the "postcode lottery" of care, improve and speed up patient access to health services, and scrap internal market structures by merging health authorities and trusts.

"We believe we can and must rebuild a truly national health service: delivering national policy to the same standards of excellence across the whole of Scotland, from the cities to the islands," she said.

The 100-page plan effectively recasts health services north of the border in a distinctively Scottish hue, customising new Labour health policies to address specific Scottish health problems, such as heart disease and smoking.

First Minister Henry McLeish said the plan gives Scotland the chance to "address Scotland's needs with greater determination and focus than ever before I am determined we will use our powers and resources to make a real difference".

Ms Deacon said "improving health" was her top priority, as she announced a £100m national health improvement fund to tackle chronic cardiac problems and lung cancer rates that led to Scotland being dubbed "the sick man of Europe".

The plan unveils targets to speed up access to treatment, guaranteeing that by 2003 no patient will wait longer than nine months for hospital care, three months less than the current target, and introducing access to primary care services within 48 hours.

Unified NHS boards will replace trusts and health authorities, cutting around 100 non-executive board director posts. There will be a review of the management and decision-making structure of health services.

The plan promises to set national standards of care, quality and cleanliness for all hospitals in a bid to remove wide variations in standards across Scotland.

webTitle: Scotland's NHS plan - the main points

fields.headline: Scotland's NHS plan - the main points
fields.trailText: The main points of Scotland's Our National Health - A Plan for Action:
fields.body:
The main points of Scotland's Our National Health - A Plan for Action:

Action on waiting

The plan promises that:

 By 2003 no patient will wait longer than nine months for treatment (currently 12 months in Scotland and 18 months in England)

 By 2002 maximum wait for angiography will be 12 weeks from seeing a specialist, and 24 weeks from angiography to surgery or angioplasty

 By October 2001, women who have breast cancer and need urgent treatment will get it within one month, where appropriate

 By October 2001, the maximum wait for children needing urgent cancer treatment will be one month

 By 2005, no patient urgently referred for cancer treatment will wait more than two months.

Improvements in access

The plan promises that:

 Every NHS Board will set a programme for the redesign of services (like one-stop clinics), building on the 44 national pilot projects already underway

 NHS 24 will be rolled out in pilot areas in 2001 offering 24-hour access to health advice from nurses

 Scotland's 1,100 pharmacists will broaden the range of services they offer to include repeat prescriptions, with more health advice to be offered and accessed on the High Street

 One million pounds will be invested to improve the health services available in small and medium-sized workplaces

 More nurses will be given the training and skills to prescribe treatments, and the range of treatments will also be increased

 No patient will waitl onger than 48 hours to see an appropriate member of the primary care team

 By April 2002, people in remote and rural Scotland will see pilot projects to expand telemedicine rolled out in all health boards with a remote population.

Rebuilding a national NHS

The plan promises that:

 New unified NHS Boards will be created to integrate local decision making and increase local accountability

 A reduction in the number of NHS boardrooms from 43 to 15, and the number of ministerial appointees by one-third or around 100 posts

 Unified NHS Boards will have greater staff and local authority representation, and will have joint responsibility for both health improvement and the development of NHS services

 Single comprehensive local health plans in each NHS board area

 Stronger local identity for the NHS, and an end to the proliferation of names and logos

 A long-term review of the management and decision-making structure of the NHS.

fields.headline: Loaded publisher turns £15m profit
fields.trailText: IPC Media yesterday made a timely return to profits growth ahead of a year that will probably see either a flotation or trade sale of the business. By David Teather.
fields.body:
IPC Media yesterday made a timely return to profits growth ahead of a decisive year which will probably see either a stock market flotation or trade sale of the business.

The firm, which publishes magazines including Loaded, Marie Claire and NME recorded pretax profits of £15.1m for the year to October, up from £2.8m in 1999. The improved performance was largely attributed to an overhaul of management begun by chief executive Sly Bailey, who was appointed just over a year ago.

Chairman David Arculus said the business was preparing to enter a critical year. IPC was a management buyout from Reed in 1998 backed by venture capital from Cinven.

"When I came into IPC, Cinven gave me a five-year recommendation," he said. "We are just coming to the end of year three so we still have two years to find an exit. But this is a little like politics. You don't want to wait until the end of the term so we will start to think of our options during the course of 2001 and certainly would hope for either a flotation or trade sale."

Ms Bailey said IPC had demonstrated that it had turned the corner. Revenues this year were 2.1% higher at £388m. "We've spent a period of looking very hard at our brands, at where we need to improve our performance and invest in our performance," she said.

She said the next focus would be Loaded, the first in the lads magazine genre which has since been leapfrogged by FHM. The music & sport division in which it is housed has been strengthened by the appointment of Mike Soutar, former editor of Maxim in the US, as managing director.

Advertising revenues across the group were 8% higher year-on-year but Ms Bailey warned the market could soften next year. IPC also announced it would be ploughing an additional £15m into its internet division, bringing its total commitment to £40m.

webTitle: Putin flies into Cuba with a message of solidarity

fields.headline: Putin flies into Cuba with a message of solidarity
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, who starts a highly symbolic visit to Cuba this morning, has said the abrupt rupture of the close alliance between Moscow and Havana a decade ago was a mistake.
fields.body:
The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, who starts a highly symbolic visit to Cuba this morning, has said the abrupt rupture of the close alliance between Moscow and Havana a decade ago was a mistake.

"I don't think it was done properly," Mr Putin told Cuban state television in an interview before leaving Moscow. Calling for a renewal of historical ties, he strongly criticised the US economic embargo against the island.

Mr Putin's four-day trip is the first visit by a Russian leader to Cuba since the Soviet Union collapsed. But turning the clock back will be almost impossible.

When Mikhail Gorbachev came to Cuba in 1989, there were some 12,000 Soviet technicians and military personnel on the island, along with their families. Cuba sent almost all its sugar and other exports to the Soviet bloc. In return, the island received everything from oil to strawberries.

But three decades of official sloganeering about brotherhood and unity left very little mark. The Soviet technicians lived in separate compounds, rarely learned Spanish and sent their children to separate schools. The Cubans referred to the Russians as bolos - the Spanish for bowling ball - something large, round and ungainly. Today there is almost no cultural evidence of the Soviet presence on the island.

Mr Putin will find only 12 Russian diplomats working in the embassy, which dominates western Havana. He will see a picture of himself in the main entrance hall and may stumble upon, hidden away behind a pillar, a lone surviving bust of Lenin which was too large or politically sensitive to remove.

He will find that his host, Fidel Castro, has changed little in style, still firing on all cylinders against the imperialists to the north.

But the Cuban leader has been forced to mellow just a little over the last decade. Last week he announced he is now a Lennonist as well as a Leninist, as he unveiled a statue of the Beatles hero whose music was once banned on the island.

Cuba has also been forced to shift its trade. Russia, which does about £700m of trade a year with Cuba, lags far behind the island's main trading partners, Spain, Italy and Canada.

That is unlikely to change significantly. Mr Castro and Mr Putin will sign an economic cooperation agreement and discuss renewing unfinished projects from the Soviet era such as an oil refinery and a nuclear power station.

But it will take much more than words to get any of these projects off the ground and it remains to be seen whether Russia has the spare cash to invest.

"Many Cubans see this visit as being mostly about spare parts," said one Cuban foreign policy expert, referring to all the old Russian cars and bits of industrial machinery still used on the island.

The Cuban military, in particular, needs spares for all its Russian hardware. Moscow, meanwhile, wants to hold on to the antennae and dishes which form its main listening station for the western hemisphere at Lourdes, close to Havana.

But for President Castro, deeply embroiled in his long war with America, the visit does have a deep symbolic importance. The support he is receiving from the new Russian leader - especially the assurances that the severance of the long alliance was a mistake - will mean a great deal to a man so acutely sensitive about the judgment of history.

webTitle: Referee told to wash his mouth out

fields.headline: Referee told to wash his mouth out
fields.trailText: Man bit dog yesterday when Premiership referee Paul Taylor was handed an FA misconduct charge for "using insulting language" during a Second Division match last October.
fields.body:
Another torrent of on-field verbals has prompted a Football Association misconduct charge; for once, though, it is a referee left washing his mouth out with soapy water.

In a man-bites-dog scenario, Paul Taylor, who joined the list of Premiership referees in August, has been charged with "using insulting language" towards the Notts County striker Sean Farrell during the 2-2 draw with Wigan Athletic in October.

Taylor, who has 14 days to respond to the charge, sent off County's Mark Stallard and Andy Hughes for violent conduct during a particularly feisty Second Division match at Meadow Lane which descended into chaos after Hughes scored a penalty to restore parity late on.

Stallard was sent off after squaring up to three Wigan players in the wake of County's equaliser, and Hughes saw red for a late challenge on Alan McLoughlin. County later lodged appeals against the dismissals but both were turned down by the FA.

The Notts County deputy chairman Peter Storrie last night refused to give details of what was said, but backed the FA's decision. "This unfortunately was somewhat more than banter," he said. "It wasn't foul and abusive language. It was something a little different and much worse."

Taylor's first season as a Premiership official has been controversial from the opening day when, as the fourth official at Sunderland's game against Arsenal, he claimed the visiting manager Arsène Wenger physically attacked him in the tunnel at the Stadium of Light. The alleged incident took place as Taylor attempted to break up a confrontation between Sunderland's Darren Williams and the Arsenal striker Thierry Henry, who was riled by the dismissal of Patrick Vieira for the use of an elbow.

Wenger has consulted his lawyers and, while grudgingly prepared to accept a fine of four weeks' wages - almost £100,000 - he is appealing against a 12-match touchline ban imposed by the FA and is hopeful the number of games will be reduced when his case is heard at the governing body's headquarters in the new year.

"All I have heard is that I can have a second hearing," said Wenger yesterday. "My appeal has been accepted but I don't know when it will be heard. If the ban could be cut it would be a nice Christmas present."

The Wales midfielder Matthew Jones has completed his £3m move from Leeds to Leicester. The 20-year-old is expected to make his debut at home to Charlton on Saturday.

Crystal Palace have tabled a £1.5m offer for the Tranmere Rovers midfielder Jason Koumas, and the former Prenton Park winger Alan Mahon has joined Blackburn on loan for the rest of the season from Sporting Lisbon. The 22-year-old Mahon joined the Portuguese club on a Bosman in the summer.

webTitle: Liverpool discover the extra in Owen

fields.headline: Liverpool discover the extra in Owen
fields.standfirst:
Liverpool make the most of extra-time to reach last four
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText:
Liverpool 3 - 0 Fulham
Liverpool make the most of extra-time to reach last four.
fields.body:
Rest assured, even when the prize on offer is great and the route forwards invitingly open, Liverpool will still make things difficult for themselves.

Although they never actually seemed likely to lose a listless quarter-final, it was not until the night had been dragged into a period of extra-time that they seemed even remotely interested in winning it.

Liverpool now meet Sunderland or Crystal Palace for a place in the final of a tournament they once dominated.

"I'm simply happy to be through because I knew that this would prove a difficult night for us," said the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier.

Fulham's voyage of discovery had turned into a genuine adventure, a Boys' Own caper awash with heroes and villains. Yes, they came unstuck last night but they will shed few tears, safe in the knowledge that the next time they visit Anfield they will certainly be contesting Premiership points.

It is not difficult to understand why their progress has been so impressive for they do constitute a genuine team, a smart, authoritative unit within which the more flamboyant individual elements are submerged for the collective good. Their work ethic is sound, they boast discipline where it matters - at the heart of defence and in central midfield - and there is a general air of efficiency to Jean Tigana's side.

The same can usually be said of the modern Liverpool but on a cold and inhospitable night, the Merseysiders' potential was diluted by the loss of key men to untimely injury - that and the lack of cohesion so frighteningly apparent at the weekend when Ipswich had ended their lengthy unbeaten home sequence.

Dietmar Hamann and Christian Ziege did not make it and Michael Owen became the latest household name to discover that Houllier's desire to run with a Chelsea-style squad rotation system will occasionally bring the sort of disappointment that, bearing in mind the Frenchman's ruthless streak, is best borne stoically and silently.

Predictably, in the wake of Sunday's defeat, Emile Heskey was restored to the front line and he it was who caused the odd early flicker of consternation in a defence that was otherwise resolute.

Fulham's intricate passing game actually drew the best out of their hosts, for Liverpool seemed determined that they would not only dominate but dominate in style.

The chances mostly fell Liverpool's way. Heskey deposited a header on the roof of the net and Igor Biscan, on his full debut, steered in a shot that would have found its target had it not clipped a Fulham boot.

Fulham, understandably, were less ambitious but even so they almost took the lead after 14 minutes when Liverpool's notoriously generous defence toyed with the idea of handing out the gifts 12 days early. Sami Hyypia's back pass fell short and although Sander Westerveld reached the ball ahead of Lee Clark he could do no more than drive his clearance into the legs of the Fulham midfielder. Agonisingly for Clark, for Tigana and for those in white favours, the ball ballooned just wide of a post.

The play moved energetically between the penalty areas but, in truth, it was all cream and no cake. With Liverpool's football pedestrian and the Fulham front pair of Louis Saha and Barry Hayles denied the time and space they enjoy in Nationwide football, the game slipped into stalemate. And there it remained until extra-time, when Liverpool finally saw fit to apply a cutting edge to their approach play.

Owen ended the stalemate at the end of the first period, arrowing a drive into the roof of the net after his initial header had been blocked by Andy Melville.

Rather cruelly Liverpool were to add two more goals, Vladimir Smicer and Nick Barmby displaying the sort of enterprise that had been lacking for most of the evening.

Heskey deposited a header on the roof of the net and Igor Biscan, on his full debut, steered in a shot that would have found its target had it not clipped a Fulham boot. Fulham, understandably, were less ambitious but even so they almost took the lead after 14 minutes when Liverpool's notoriously generous defence toyed with the idea of handing out the gifts 12 days early. Sami Hyypia's back pass fell short and although Sander Westerveld reached the ball ahead of Lee Clark he could do no more than drive his clearance into the legs of the Fulham midfielder. Agonisingly for Clark, for Tigana and for those in white favours, the ball ballooned just wide of a post. The play moved energetically between the penalty areas but, in truth, it was all cream and no cake. With Liverpool's football pedestrian and the Fulham front pair of Louis Saha and Barry Hayles denied the time and space they enjoy in Nationwide football, the game slipped into stalemate. And there it remained until extra-time, when Liverpool finally saw fit to apply a cutting edge to their approach play. Owen ended the stalemate at the end of the first period, arrowing a drive into the roof of the net after his initial header had been blocked by Andy Melville. Rather cruelly Liverpool were to add two more goals, Vladimir Smicer and Nick Barmby displaying the sort of enterprise that had been lacking for most of the evening.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Health rules hit tobacco lobby
fields.standfirst:
Euro MPs vote for shock images on cigarette packs

Special report: smoking
Special report: the European Parliament
fields.trailText: Euro MPs vote for shock images on cigarette packs
fields.body:
Europe's powerful tobacco lobby suffered a big setback yesterday after Euro MPs backed tough new rules forcing manufacturers to put shocking images of cancerous lungs and rotting teeth on cigarette packets.

In a vote in Strasbourg, the parliament approved legislation obliging the industry, by 2003, to cover 30% of the front of every packet sold in the EU with a health warning. At the moment, in the UK, 6% of a packet's surface is taken up with a warning.

There was immediate retaliation from the tobacco lobby which claimed that several of the measures approved by the parliament risked thousands of jobs, many in the UK.

British American Tobacco warned that the decision to ban European factories from making cigarettes with a tar content of more than 10mg per cigarette for domestic consumption and export could be particularly damaging to employment.

A representative of BAT said: "This will act as a de facto export ban threatening the loss of 1,800 jobs in BAT factories, mainly in the UK, and a further 6,000 jobs among suppliers.

"We are calling upon the Council of Europe ministers - and Alan Milburn, the secretary of state for health - to help eliminate the export clause before it is too late."

The industry now has one last chance to try to derail the measures as the final text of the directive will be hammered out between EU health ministers and Euro MPs in the new year with the European commission acting as go-between.

John Bowis, the Conservatives' health spokesman, yesterday said that the directive as agreed could be challenged in the courts and argued that the decision to extend the rules to cigarettes earmarked for export was a step too far.

But MEPs were adamant that they had acted in the public interest and confident that agreement over the final wording of the text would be swift and uncontroversial. "There's quite a lot of common ground between the parliament and ministers and we should be able to see a final result by spring at the latest," said a source.

MEPs also predicted that the tobacco industry's attempts to wreck the legislation would fail. "We have come under unprecedented pressure from a tobacco lobby which is vehemently opposed to these new rules. Tobacco giants like Marlboro, Benson and Hedges, and Rothmans, have had their own way for far too long," said the Labour Euro MP Catherine Stihler. "They overturned Europe's tobacco advert ban on a technicality, but they will not get rid of these health warnings through legal loopholes."

However, the tobacco industry has already succeeded in watering down some of the rules. Makers won the right to continue using the terms "ultra light" and "low tar" to describe their existing brands.

Brussels estimates that tobacco related ailments kill half a million Europeans each year.

 A Nottingham university "student of the year" will tomorrow refuse to receive his award in protest at the university's decision to accept £3.8m from BAT. Jon Rouse, 32, winner of the MBA finance award from Nottingham's business school, has asked for the £50 prize to be donated to the Imperial Cancer Research Fund. "Accepting money legitimises an organisation that trades in a product that kills people," he said.

The business school set off the controversy by taking BAT's money to open an international centre for corporate social responsibility.

fields.headline: Fair trade
fields.trailText: The theory behind fair trade is that the people who actually produce the goods should get a bigger cut of the profits.
fields.body:
The theory behind fair trade is that the people who actually produce the goods should get a bigger cut of the profits.

An example which most people will know of is the fair trade coffee that can be bought in the country's supermarkets. Fair trade coffee was the brainchild of development charities such as Oxfam, which saw third world coffee growers living off a pittance while the middle men and coffee company shareholders made huge profits. The charities argued that local coffee growers getting more of the money would promote grassroots development. With the extra money growers might, for example, be able to afford to send their children to school or buy more tools, seeds and land and expand their operations. Essentially, they would be getting a salary which more accurately reflects their role in coffee production and would be able to spend it as they saw fit.

The market for fair trade products is growing all the time. Coffee, tea and chocolate are available from most supermarket shelves, but other products can be bought from charity gift shops and websites. Oxfam and Traidcraft are good places to start.

fields.headline: Ethical consumerism
fields.trailText: Being an ethical consumer means buying products which were ethically produced and/or which are not harmful to the environment and society. This can be as simple as buying free-range eggs or as complex as working out which products are produced by child labour and boycotting them accordingly.
fields.body:
Being an ethical consumer means buying products which were ethically produced and/or which are not harmful to the environment and society. This can be as simple as buying free-range eggs or as complex as working out which products are produced by child labour and boycotting them accordingly.

Pressure groups regularly flag up companies of concern and the Manchester-based Ethical Consumer Research Association publishes the Ethical Consumer magazine, but deciding what to buy and what not to buy can be as tricky as deciding which ethical fund to invest in. Products which fall into the ethical category include organic produce, fair trade goods, energy-efficient light bulbs, electricity from renewable energy, recycled paper and wood products with Forest Stewardship Council approval.

Being an ethical consumer can also involve watching your food miles: how much energy was used getting the product to you. For this reason, ethical consumers are encouraged to buy products which were grown and produced as locally as possible. Buying from the local farmers' market is one way of meeting this criterion.

Ethical consumption can be a powerful tool for change, with the recent success of the anti-GM lobby being a case in point. The problem at the moment appears to be a gap between demand for ethically produced goods and their supply. A recent report from the Co-operative Bank showed a third of UK consumers claiming to be concerned about ethical consumption, while only 3% of the UK market is devoted to ethical goods.
