webTitle: Theatre review: Cinderella - The Ash Girl

fields.headline: Brum Cinderella off to an oddball ball
fields.standfirst:
Cinderella - The Ash Girl
Birmingham Rep
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Cinderella - The Ash Girl
Birmingham Rep
Rating: ***
fields.body:
As her title implies, Timberlake Wertenbaker offers a new take on an old tale. No song sheets, cross-dressing or jokes about Aston Villa as you'd expect in a Brum panto. Instead we get an ambitious children's play with hints of the Brothers Grimm, medieval allegory and anthropomorphism; and, even if it's a bit overloaded, it has a quirky originality and kept a packed house so quiet you could hear a pin drop. A few familiar signposts are still there. The heroine, who kips under a cloak of ash, is bullied by her stepsisters and finally gets her prince. But she is prey to self-doubt and is under the thumb of her stepmother, while her prince is an exiled Asian isolated and unhappy in his new country.

Wertenbaker's biggest innovation is to suggest that the forest en route to the palace is populated by an animalised version of the Seven Deadly Sins, which are out to destroy humanity. She even adds a further allegorical figure, Sadness, who tries to tempt the ash girl towards death and battles with the Fairy in the Mirror for her soul. The result is a like a mix of CS Lewis and Sondheim's Into the Woods: an eclectic fairytale anthology. In packing so much in, Wertenbaker sometimes muddies the narrative. I couldn't work out why, if the cardinal vices were seeking to corrupt mankind, they didn't attack their prey on their way to, rather than from, the ball.

Where Wertenbaker scores is in her eye for eccentric detail. One of the stepsisters doesn't even much fancy the prince - "I only want a microscope," she petulantly announces. And the benign fairy, instead of being the usual wand-waving wonderwoman, is blessed with a studied vagueness. "I have to change you into something horrid," she tells the cruel stepmother, as if she can't quite remember what. The truth is that the Cinderella myth is so rooted in our culture that it can take any number of variations; and Wertenbaker's version, which advises you to say no to your mother if she asks you to do something stupid such as amputating your toe, has an anarchic subversiveness that should appeal to children.

Lucy Bailey's production and Angela Davies's designs also offer plenty of visual magic: letters whiz through the sky, arachnoids dangle over our heads and silhouetted figures process down castle steps as in an avant-garde Macbeth. Stephanie Pochin is a prettily introverted ash-girl, Rachel Smith is suitably snotty as her prince-spurning stepsister and, though I could have lived without the Seven Deadly Sins, I warmed to Alex Jones's Brummagem Slothbird, who scarcely had the energy to drag himself across the stage. On the whole, a pleasantly oddball evening to which kids can safely take their parents.

Until January 27
Box office: 0121-236 4455

fields.trailText: Figures from Friends of the Earth show that 22% of greenhouse gases come from domestic energy use. As such, making your house as energy efficient as possible is an important first step towards being an ethical consumer. This will include proper insulation, double or triple glazing and draft proofing.
fields.body:
Figures from Friends of the Earth show that 22% of greenhouse gases come from domestic energy use. As such, making your house as energy efficient as possible is an important first step towards being an ethical consumer. This will include proper insulation, double or triple glazing and draft proofing.

These days you can get your electricity from green sources. Internet start-up servista.com and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds are among those offering renewable energy.

Using energy saving light bulbs is also advisable. These cost more than regular light bulbs but last significantly longer.

Friends of the Earth will be publishing a league table of the greenest UK energy companies in 2001.

fields.headline: Zoe Rahman
fields.standfirst:
Central Bar, London
****
fields.trailText:
Central Bar, London
****
fields.body:
Zoe Rahman, a young, animated British pianist with a pigtail that threatens to get under her feet, is the perfect antidote to the fashionable view of the major labels that young people want cross-over, not straight-ahead, jazz. Rahman, who won the Perrier Young Jazz Musician of the Year award a couple of years ago, is a hugely promising musician of powerful technique, group sympathy and compositional skill, but for much of the time she's as straight-ahead as they come. The Central Bar in London's Old Street is the perfect intimate room in which to hear an inventive piano trio, except in one respect - it doesn't have a piano. Rahman had to use an electric keyboard, which detracts from her subtlety of nuance and dynamic control. But if her own considerable contribution wasn't ideally displayed, her group's collective expressiveness was consistently absorbing. Jeremy Brown is a quick, soft-toned, melodically original bassist, and Winston Clifford is one of the UK's most interesting small-group drummers - an ideal complement to any pianist. On Joe Henderson's Isotope (the leader apologising that the piece had to double as the sound-check), Rahman was still settling in.

She often fell back on a favourite device, the percussively repeated single note against shifting chords - though Clifford's brushwork was like a constant, encouraging whisper in her ear. The original ballad Never Enough evolved into an entrancing dialogue with Clifford's hand-drumming, and a Danilo Perez Latin arrangement of Thelonious Monk's Bright Mississippi found Rahman's phrasing increasingly assured, crisply expressed and balancing spare lines against dancing Latin-jazz chording. The up-tempo original Apple Pie filled the small space with its emphatically rolling, McCoy Tyner-like theme, and a haunting How Long Has This Been Going On confirmed that Rahman's youth and ebullient swing are no obstacles to patient, meditative harmonic exploration. Rahman tours the north with this trio next month, so watch out for her.

fields.headline: Handel 'opera' in a masque
fields.standfirst:
Alceste
Linbury Studio, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Alceste
Linbury Studio, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
As if Handel didn't write enough genuine operas, companies keep unveiling forgotten stage works disguised as such. Handel wrote his score for Alceste in 1750 as incidental music to a play by Tobias Smollett; there was so much music the play was mistakenly referred to by some as an opera. It went into rehearsal at Covent Garden but, probably due to a row between Smollett and the management, the project was pulled before it reached the stage.

Handel's score survives but Smollett's text is lost, so to perform the work the English Bach Festival have had to turn it into a kind of masque. The parts of the story that would have been declaimed by actors are presented in mime instead, and other Handel operas have been plundered to provide music for the extended ballet sequences. The resulting work, premiered 11 years ago but now brought "home" to WC2 for the first time, is a paradox: an attempt to recreate in a slavishly authentic manner a work that was never conceived in this format in the first place.

The English Bach Festival came into being nearly 50 years ago pledging to present operas of this period "as authentically as historical research will allow". It is valid to have these traditions preserved but, in sticking to inflexible rules, the company risks having the audience catch a whiff of formaldehyde. The baroque gestures and dance movements employed with great sincerity throughout Alceste (in Tom Hawkes's direction and Sarah Cremer's choreography) can't help but look awkward to a 21st-century audience. Although lovingly recreated by Terence Emery, the costumes - tall feathered headdresses for the men, crinolines drawn up like Austrian blinds to display the women's feet - also provoked giggles rather than gasps.

Musically, things were better, the small orchestra sounding neat and poised even in the Linbury's uncharitable acoustic. Conductor Lawrence Cummings shaped phrases energetically while driving the musicians along from the harpsichord.

The singing was rather mixed, but Yvonne Barclay charmed the audience with her soft tone in Gentle Mor pheus, and Graeme Broadbent made a solid, resonant Charon. The dancer Elizabeth Lea communicated Alceste's own story gracefully, while Roger Frith's lighting brought imagination to the stage. But the action he had to illuminate was earnestly unexciting - all posturing and no attitude.

The EBF may once have had a reputation for innovation, but this Alceste can only be described as a museum piece.

Further performances tonight and tomorrow. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Mortgages
fields.trailText: The Ecology Building Society and the Norwich & Peterborough Building Society are the main players in ethical mortgages.
fields.body:
The Ecology Building Society and the Norwich & Peterborough Building Society are the main players in ethical mortgages.

The Ecology only lends on properties which give what it calls an ecological payback. This means old houses in need of renovation, new homes built with recycled or sustainable materials, or homes which will be made as energy efficient as possible. Meanwhile, Norwich & Peterborough offers a carbon neutral mortgage. The building society will plant eight trees a year over five years for every home bought or re-mortgaged with its green mortgages. The trees, it says, will absorb the carbon dioxide emissions produced by the property, making it carbon neutral.

Norwich &Peterborough will also give you a discount on its standard rate if you improve the energy efficiency of your property. And if you're buying a new home it has a standard assessment procedure which rates the greenness of a property.

fields.headline: Does it change corporate behaviour?
fields.trailText: Evidence would suggest that yes, ethical investment does change corporate behaviour.
fields.body:
Evidence would suggest that yes, ethical investment does change corporate behaviour.

The ethical investment sector was, for example, influential in getting 13% of BP Amoco investors to oppose its plans to drill for oil in the Arctic.

Ethical fund managers also say companies are increasingly approaching them and asking for advice. This, they say, proves management has woken up to the ethical sector, knows it isn't going to go away and wants to know what to do to be acceptable investments for ethical funds.

Shell, for example, asked if a member of Hendersons' ethical team would sit on one of its socially responsible investment boards.

Companies, especially the big multinationals, are also becoming more transparent. Some will have environmental reporting in their annual reports. Others have set up sustainable environmental units to look at the environmental impact on the business.

fields.trailText: Transport accounts for 23% of greenhouse gases, much of it coming from private car use. There really isn't an environmentally friendly way to own and use a car. Vast amounts of resources and energy go into producing them and, as if that wasn't enough, they run on fossil fuels, the burning of which contributes directly to global warming.

Vast amounts of resources and energy go into producing them and, as if that wasn't enough, they run on fossil fuels, the burning of which contributes directly to global warming.

Walk, cycle or take public transport where available. If you have to drive - and let's face it, most people, especially those living in urban areas, don't have to drive - get a fuel efficient car which runs on one of the greener fuels, such as unleaded petrol, and use the car as little as possible.

webTitle: Do ethical funds produce good returns?

fields.headline: Do ethical funds produce good returns?
fields.trailText: Comparing the performance of ethical funds with other sectors can be tricky. The composition of ethical funds is unique, so comparing them with, for example, UK growth funds or the technology sector, will be misleading; a bit like comparing apples with pears.
fields.body:
Comparing the performance of ethical funds with other sectors can be tricky. The composition of ethical funds is unique, so comparing them with, for example, UK growth funds or the technology sector, will be misleading; a bit like comparing apples with pears.

A popular misconception is that ethical funds don't produce good returns, but research indicates that this just isn't true. Alan Kirkham of the Ethical Investment Co-operative measured the performance of ethical funds against the FTSE All Share index and the average unit trust and found them outperforming both.

By way of example, over the past year, Equitable Ethical grew over 50% and Scottish Widows Environment grew by nearly 30%. Over five years, these percentages jump to 163% and 195%, respectively.

In fact, ethical investors say their funds are more likely to produce good returns. They are investing in companies of the future, companies which are unlikely to face big legal challenges, or penalties for polluting, or negative publicity because of human rights abuses. As such, these stable, progressive companies will produce good, solid returns. And as the rest of the world watches and realises these companies are ahead of their time, so the public's interest in them, their share prices and the profits made by investors will soar.

The environmental and social performance of companies will, say ethical fund managers, become an increasingly important indicator of financial strength and performance. In short, the three will be linked. A company won't be able to do well financially if it has a dubious environmental and social record because legislation, taxation and penalties will eat into its bottom line.

And in many ways, they maintain, this is already happening. In the UK, a climate change levy and landfill tax are gradually driving up the cost of energy usage and waste disposal. Companies exist to make money, so if something is eating into their profits, you can be sure the board of directors will do something about it.

fields.headline: Anorak rock from Beautiful South
fields.standfirst:
The Beautiful South
Brixton Academy
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
The Beautiful South
Brixton Academy
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
In his birdwatcher's shiny anorak and baseball cap, Paul Heaton looks like the sort of bloke you'd report to the police if you saw him loitering in your local park. But being pop's top voyeur has paid off handsomely. Resolutely Old Labour, and living a life so unrockstar-ish in unfashionable Hull that it's virtually a fashion statement in itself, Heaton is a classic square peg who happens to have found a square hole with a silver lining.

Although Heaton permits himself a brief moan about poor sales of the new album Paint It Red, statisticians allege that one in six British households contains a Beautiful South album, which isn't difficult to believe when you hear the Brixton crowd singing the band's songs in unison. Nonetheless, only the most zealous fan could possibly describe their live show as a scintillating experience, and there's no avoiding the fact that this is rock'n'roll for the caring professions, with anything too boisterous or competitive carefully weeded out. Chaos and spontaneity have clearly had their necks wrung during rehearsals.

This being Brixton Academy, you can hear about one third of the lyrics, so the end result is like listening to the South's records on a stereo with one dodgy speaker. But no matter. The crowd are up for a bit of jumping about on the pub-rockish One Last Love Song, while the ensemble cranks up the beat for Baby Please Go.

The sudden departure of vocalist Jacqui Abbott has left a gaping hole in the line-up, not filled at all by a bloke dressed just like Heaton except that his anorak is dark blue instead of beige. This gives Heaton scope for a bit of gender-switching drollery in Perfect 10 ("He's a perfect 10 but he wears a 12.")

The best moments are when Heaton sings accompanied only by Dave Rotheray's acoustic guitar. Prettiest Eyes opened the proceedings on a typically ambiguous note, while the pair's encore of The River confirmed that the song's extended metaphors and plangent tune make it one of their finest. But there was no need to trek down to Brixton to discover that.

The Beautiful South play Sheffield Arena (0114-256 5656) tomorrow, Manchester Evening News Arena (0161-930 8000) on Sunday, then tour.

webTitle: Banks refuse to pick up full PO bill

fields.headline: Banks refuse to pick up full PO bill
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government faces an annual bill as high as £350m to create the Post Office based universal bank because 10 high street banks have refused to meet demands to pay £125m a year towards running costs, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The government faces an annual bill as high as £350m to create the Post Office based universal bank because 10 high street banks have refused to meet demands to pay £125m a year towards running costs, it emerged yesterday.

According to a letter obtained by The Guardian, the leading high-street players told Post Office minister Alan Johnson that they are prepared to pay, at most, only half.

They made their tough stand in a ten-point ultimatum just days before facing a summit with Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, who is understood to be determined to hammer out an agreement before Christmas.

The creation of the universal bank is at the core of Mr Byers' plans to throw a lifeline to the 18,000-strong Post Office network. Funding by the banks is crucial to its establishment. Mr Byers is to hold his last meeting with bank bosses next Wednesday in a last ditch effort to clinch support for the project.

The banks, furious at the prospect of funding the Post Office's future, also told the government that they will pay for the costs of the universal bank only for five years and want to make their contribution in one, up-front payment. The government has already agreed to limit the banks costs to £125m and let taxpayers pick up any shortfall in the annual costs, which are expected to be as high as £400m.

However, the banks have moved from outright refusal to endorse the controversial project to agreeing in principle to the plan. They fear government reprisals if they refuse, ranging from an official "windfall tax" on profits to a more aggressive approach from the competition commission which is investigating small business banking.

The government is understood to be more confident about the talks, after a slow start when the banks dubbed it a "poor people's bank." The universal bank is to offer bank accounts, branded "clear", for the 5m who do not have one but will need one when social security payments are automated in 2004.

Many bankers are convinced that the government will fail to entice all these to open accounts by its deadline and are concerned that they will end up bearing the cost of the project. This is why the banks, have told the government that they will refuse any involvement in the bank's development.

"All the development costs and risks would rest with the government and Post Office," says the letter, written by Tim Sweeney, the British Bankers' Association head, to ten of his largest members. The BBA refused to confirm the existence of the letter while the DTI refused to comment.

After months of disagreements between the banks, the documents show that a consensus has been reached between the ten players. They make three main points: the basic accounts the banks have been forced to set up will be used at post offices; the transaction fee charged by the post office to the banks will be set at 30p not the 49p proposed; the contribution from each bank will be "up to 50%" of the amount demanded. Mr Sweeney makes it clear that this is the banks' final offer.

fields.headline: Lloyds turns up the heat
fields.standfirst:
Abbey National's chief executive pressured to start negotiations
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The stage was set for a gruelling £18bn takeover battle last night as Lloyds TSB heaped pressure on Ian Harley, Abbey National's chief executive, to open negotiations about selling the bank.
fields.body:
The stage was set for a gruelling £18bn takeover battle last night as Lloyds TSB heaped pressure on Ian Harley, Abbey National's chief executive, to open negotiations about selling the bank.

As senior City sources speculated that they saw little hope of the current three-way standoff being resolved before Christmas, Lloyds TSB began its last attempt to secure a friendly takeover of Abbey National before firing hostile guns at its target.

Questions began to emerge about the make-up of the Abbey board as Lloyds TSB made it clear it was not yet ready to walk away despite having been rebuffed twice by Abbey in as many weeks.

The fire power of Lloyds TSB already appears to have quashed any remaining hopes that Abbey and Bank of Scotland will be able to complete their merger negotiations.

Lloyds TSB effectively appealed to Abbey's shareholders to lobby the bank to open talks about a takeover, which would result in 8,000 job cuts and branch closures after two years.

Lloyds argued yesterday that the terms of its offer for Abbey, valuing the bank at just over £18.3bn, was better than anything Abbey with BoS, or Abbey on its own, could provide for shareholders.

Describing the offer, comprising 1.5 of its own shares and 260p in cash, as "full", City sources believed this was indication that Lloyds was deter mined not to have raise its offer by much more.

Responding to Abbey's concerns that deal might be difficult to complete on competition grounds, Lloyds insisted last night that the markets in which it operated were "very competitive".

In what was interpreted as a move by Lloyds to try to clear the path should any regulatory worries be exposed, Lloyds argued that Abbey's customers would be able to use its 2,200 branches if its bid was successful. It pledged not to close any of Abbey's 722 branches for two years and extend its promise to never close the last branch in any town to Abbey's network.

It insisted the deal would keep compulsory redundancies to a minimum and highlighted its charitable donations of £31m last year.

While some leading Lloyds shareholders have questioned the rationale for its move on Abbey, Lloyds said it would "consider the reaction of shareholders to the position adopted by Abbey National's board and any announcement by Abbey National relating to Bank of Scotland".

The analysts at Fox-Pitt, Kelton said they were sceptical that the current "executive-biased, long-appointed" board would be rushed into a deal.

They calculated that unusually Abbey's board had fewer non-executive directors than full-time executives and had been appointed more than six years ago. Abbey said the lengthy statement by Lloyds contained "nothing new".

fields.headline: Ethical lifestyle
fields.trailText: The ethical arguments which you apply to your finances can be applied to every aspect of your life. When you invest, or don't invest, in a company you are sending signals about whether or not you approve of their activities. The same applies every time you buy something.
fields.body:
The ethical arguments which you apply to your finances can be applied to every aspect of your life. When you invest, or don't invest, in a company you are sending signals about whether or not you approve of their activities. The same applies every time you buy something.

Did you know, for example, that residential energy use accounts for nearly 25% of the country's overall energy consumption? As such, our hot water and central heating are major contributors to global warming. And what about the food you eat? Have you ever thought about where it comes from? If you're buying vegetables from Australia a huge amount of energy is used getting them to the UK - so why not buy them from local UK producers instead?

fields.headline: Philharmonia/Brabbins
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Composer Vladislav Shoot has had to endure the most debilitating circumstances at the most important stage of his career. Born in 1941, he was unable to support his family during the economic crisis that accompanied Russia's transition to capitalism, and was forced to move to Britain.

Tuesday's concert at the Royal Festival Hall marked Shoot's most concentrated exposure on the London stage, although his work has already begun to establish itself internationally. Most significantly, the BBC commissioned his 1998 High Cross Symphony, which was premiered by the BBC Symphony Orchestra and Martyn Brabbins.

With members of the Philharmonia, Brabbins was again the expert guide in two of Shoot's smaller-scale works for chamber ensemble: the 1992 Sinfonia da Camera No 4, scored for strings and tam-tam, and the 1997 Divertimento, for vibraphone, strings and solo recorder.

The Sinfonia was composed just before Shoot emigrated, and the music's tightly wrought lyricism may speak of the torments of his financial situation. Yet this was actually a musically productive time for Shoot. As he says, "The only thing that remained intact was music itself, for it didn't come in bank notes and couldn't succumb to inflation." In fact, the Sinfonia is more a technically accomplished essay than a tortuous lament. Compared with the overwhelming ferocity achieved by his older compatriot Galina Ustvolskaya, with a similar post-tonal language, Shoot's composition is tranquillity personified. Even the tam-tam is here a vehicle of colouristic restraint.

The Divertimento synthesises Shoot's concert idiom with the film music style he created in his last years in Moscow, work he did simply to survive. Written for recorder virtuoso Piers Adams, this was music of an overt but inelegant populism. Shoot conjured bright colours, with whistling string harmonics set against the avian piping of the soloist - but not enough to sustain interest beyond the obvious curiosity of the form.

Given the size and scope of Shoot's catalogue - and his predilection for larger forces - an orchestral showcase of Shoot's music would surely reveal more substantial sides of this intriguing output.

fields.headline: Pensions
fields.trailText: The ethical pension sector was given a major boost when legal changes, requiring that trustees disclose their stance on ethical issues, came into force in July 2000.
fields.body:
The ethical pension sector was given a major boost when legal changes, requiring that trustees disclose their stance on ethical issues, came into force in July 2000.

If you're a member of an occupational scheme, find out what your pension company's stance is. You may be pleasantly surprised. But if you're concerned, you and your colleagues could raise ethical issues with the trustees.

If you're not a member of an occupational scheme, ethical personal pensions are an option. Axa Sun Life, Clerical Medical, NPI Globalcare, Scottish Equitable and Standard Life all offer ethical pensions. But if you had your heart set on a different provider, see if you can buy one of their investment funds and put it in a pensions wrapper.

fields.headline: Banking and credit cards
fields.trailText: The Co-operative Bank, Triodos Bank and the Ecology Building Society are the three front-runners in ethical banking. They offer standard banking products including current accounts, savings accounts and credit cards, but conduct all their business with ethical issues in mind.
fields.body:
The Co-operative Bank, Triodos Bank and the Ecology Building Society are the three front-runners in ethical banking. They offer standard banking products including current accounts, savings accounts and credit cards, but conduct all their business with ethical issues in mind.

The Co-operative will not, for example, lend to oppressive regimes or companies making weapons. Triodos Bank gives a donation to the Soil Association for every organic savings account opened. And the Ecology Building Society lends to energy efficient homes.

The so-called social banking sector, comprised of building societies and credit unions, is another possibility. They don't give profits to shareholders and, especially in the case of credit unions, they make loans to people who would otherwise be financially excluded.

Affinity or charity credit cards which give a small percentage - usually 0.25% - of your spending to charity are becoming more popular. There is certainly nothing wrong with using these cards and the contributions are sure to be welcome by the charities, but it's worth mentioning that they typically charge among the highest rates on the market.
